PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the seventh and eighth reports of the committee for 1995 relating to the construction of a multi-level car park for the Federal Airports Corporation at Melbourne airport and housing development at HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The committee's seventh report of 1995 relates to the proposed construction of a multi-level car park for the Federal Airports Corporation at Melbourne airport. Melbourne airport is the second busiest in Australia and is subject to continuing growth in passenger movements. The existing short-term car park is suffering severe congestion and frequent closure. The Federal Airports Corporation submitted to the committee that it is necessary to increase the capacity of the short-term car park by providing a multi-level car park adjacent to the terminal.

PARA.TAB: The scope of the proposal examined by the committee includes a four-level, open-sided concrete car park. It also includes associated facilities such as office accommodation for car rental companies and police, accommodation for some high vehicles, lifts, stairs, pedestrian bridges, goods loading dock, landscaping and planting.

The preliminary cost estimate of the project is $55 million. The committee has recommended that the proposal should proceed. The committee found that current short-term carparking facilities and arrangements at Melbourne airport are inadequate. There is a need to upgrade short-term car parking to overcome current shortages and provide for future growth.

In response to a suggestion from the Public Transport Users Association that improved public transport from the airport to the city may obviate the need for a new building, the committee found that the majority of motor vehicles requiring short-term parking emanate from the wider metropolitan area and other parts of the state. The committee notes, nevertheless, that options for a longer term future rail link to the central business district have been identified and easements are being protected. Because the new car park will be some distance from the terminal building and will be linked by three walkways, the committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation should consider the provision of mechanical moving walkways.

A substantial building site between the terminal and the car park has been reserved for a future hotel. The committee has some misgivings about the suitability and practicality of locating a hotel between the terminal and the car park. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation should re-examine the arrangement of car park and future hotel sites to satisfy itself that the proposed sites are the best locations for both.

Two features of the car park include a loading dock and tunnel, which it is planned will facilitate the movement of goods to and from the terminal. Qantas raised a number of concerns about the tunnel and the loading dock, and the committee has recommended that, during the development of detailed designs, the Federal Airports Corporation should continue discussions with Qantas and other terminal users about the functionality of the loading dock and tunnel.

In the same vein, in response to a submission from the Melbourne Metropolitan Fire Brigades Board, the committee has recommended that the FAC should, during design development, consult the brigade about modifications to state regulatory fire safety requirements before they are submitted to the Building Appeals Board for approval.

The committee's eighth report of 1995 deals with a proposed housing development at HMAS Coonawarra, Northern Territory. The proposal examined by the committee involves the construction of 32 family dwellings by the Defence Housing Authority on HMAS Coonawarra. The site for the proposed housing is adjacent to existing family units which have been completed over the past two years. Upon completion, the new houses will be allocated to families of army non-commissioned and commissioned officers. Included in the project are supporting community facilities.

The estimated cost of the proposed work is $6.8 million. The committee has recommended that the work should proceed. The committee concluded that, as a consequence of the army presence in the north project, there will be a need for a continuing program of housing acquisitions or Defence Housing Authority sponsored new construction to be provided in Darwin to cater for planned relocation of Defence personnel. The committee found that, in order to reduce reliance on temporary rental allowances and to avoid over-reliance on acquisitions, there is merit in the Defence Housing Authority proceeding with the funding and development of the new construction.

The Northern Territory government pointed out to the committee that the site proposed for the housing development is prone to noise from a number of sources, including aircraft, speedway racing and road traffic. The committee is not convinced that a housing subdivision, situated in close proximity to two major roads and within a short distance from a speedway and underneath an aircraft flight path, will not have substantial noise problems either now or in the near future. The committee raised these concerns with the Defence Housing Authority and has approved the proposal only on the assurance by the DHA that, whilst recognising the potential disadvantages, they are outweighed by the advantages. The committee remains to be convinced of this.

The committee also raised concerns about the close proximity of the houses. They share one television between five houses. The committee raised the question of the payment of subcontractors with the Defence Housing Authority. The Defence Housing Authority is considering making it mandatory for builders to certify that these payments have been made. The committee believes this is an urgent matter and has recommended that the Defence Housing Authority should move swiftly to make it a mandatory requirement. I commend the reports to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the committee's report on the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 and Air Services Bill 1995, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 5 and 6 (1995).

SPEECH.PARA: The tariff proposals which I have just tabled contain alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Customs Tariff Proposal No. 5 1995 formally places before parliament, as required by law, a tariff alteration made by notice published in the Commonwealth Gazette on 31 March 1995 during the recent recess of parliament. Customs Tariff Proposal No. 5 1995 is operative on and from 1 April 1995. Customs tariff rates of duty have been subjected to a graduated phasing regime since July 1988. This government is aware of the consequences to industry of sudden and large reductions in the customs duty impost.

PARA.TAB: Blood packs and blood pack systems used for collecting, processing, storing and administering blood and blood components have traditionally been classified by the Australian Customs Service as infusion and transfusion sets for blood and other fluids and currently subject to 10 per cent duty.

This classification was successfully challenged in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, with the result that the AAT set aside the customs classification, considering the goods to be properly classified to a duty free item. The immediate removal of the 10 per cent assistance would have had a detrimental effect on local industry and is not consistent with the intent of the government's tariff phase down program.

This amendment reinstates the level of assistance for the subject goods by specifically providing for blood packs and blood pack systems used for collecting, processing, storing and administering blood and blood components in the tariff classification that customs originally considered appropriate.

Customs Tariff Proposal No. 6 1995 is operative from 1 July 1995. Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1995, act No. 8 of 1995, contained a number of administrative amendments to amalgamate tariff subheadings where customs duty rates were the same. The changes in proposal No. 5 to blood packs is one of the subheadings affected. This alteration is to ensure that the change previously made to blood packs is carried on after 1 July 1995.
Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cobb) adjourned.
Consideration resumed from 29 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends four acts dealing with superannuation for Commonwealth sector civilian employees: the Superannuation Act 1922, the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1994. It also removes gender specific terms from the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948.

PARA.TAB: The main purpose of the bill is to make amendments to continue the process of ensuring that the two superannuation schemes for Commonwealth civilian employees comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and regulations under that act. I expect the boards of trustees of the two schemes to elect that the schemes become regulated superannuation funds under SI(S) with effect from 1 July 1995.

The bill will also make some technical amendments to the acts to name the schemes, the boards of trustees and the funds as the commonwealth superannuation scheme and the public sector superannuation scheme, the CSS and PSS boards and the CSS and PSS funds. This will ensure that the generally used names have a legal basis and will enable ease of reference in other legislation. The opportunity has also been taken to include amendments to correct anomalies that have arisen and caused inequities—for example, to provide restoration of an invalidity pension that had been cancelled on a return to work that is terminated in the probationary period because of ill health.

The bill includes amendments to restore the original intentions of the 1976 act as a response to the changing employment conditions in the public sector. For example, the change to the definition of minimum retiring age in that act formally recognises that most members of the scheme are able to retire from age 55.

Also included are some amendments to assist administrative efficiency. For example, the boards will be able to rely on advice from employers rather than have to check personnel records for over 200,000 members. These amendments will not prevent the boards from correcting errors in such information nor interfere with members' appeal rights. The bill includes several technical amendments and drafting corrections resulting from previous amendments and to remove gender specific terms.

I now turn to the financial impact of the bill. The amendments to correct anomalies will increase the cost of the schemes slightly. Most of the provisions designed to assist administration efficiency will decrease administrative costs, or prevent increases in such costs. A further administrative amendment will reduce the cost of the CSS but not the overall cost to the Commonwealth as there will be an offsetting compensation cost. Because the anomalies occur only in unusual situations, it is likely that there would be no overall cost to the schemes or the Commonwealth from the proposed amendments. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 is essentially amending legislation, and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has outlined the details of it to some degree. It amends four acts dealing with Commonwealth sector civilian employees to ensure that the Commonwealth superannuation arrangements comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, otherwise known as the SI(S) legislation. It also covers regulations under that act. It corrects some anomalies. It restores the original intentions of certain provisions. It removes gender specific terms and makes technical and drafting changes to improve the administrative efficiency of the schemes.

PARA.TAB: SI(S) requires that the trustees of public sector superannuation schemes should elect that the schemes become regulated under SI(S) from 1 July of this year. Amendments to the act are to take effect from that date. The bill also includes various other formal amendments to related legislation. This legislation does give us the opportunity to explore in greater detail the substance of the government's policy in terms of superannuation and to draw to the attention of the parliament those shortcomings which are quite evident in the policy for anyone, except members of the government, who wish to examine them in some detail.

The genesis of the current superannuation policy dates back to 1982 when the former government established a task force, of which I was the chairman, to examine a whole range of fundamental changes to superannuation throughout both the public and private sectors of Australia. Subsequently, following the loss of the 1983 election, this work was continued by the incoming Labor government under the then Treasurer, who is now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). In June of that year, 1983, the first major changes were introduced to establish a new regime for superannuation. It is fair to say that the work undertaken by my committee initially did have some relevance to that outcome.

Over the years since then, we have seen a plague of changes to superannuation law in this country. In fact it is estimated that there have been over 2,000 substantial changes to superannuation law and regulations with the result that the community at large has found very great difficulty in absorbing this rate of change. Certainly the industry has reached a stage where it simply cannot take any more. In a sense, this is sad because in my view—and I have said this to industry on a number of occasions—we have created a situation where, by and large, those who should be involved in the development of superannuation policy in the industry have had to spend most of their time and resources simply responding to the initiatives introduced by the government.

Consequently, the industry has tended to become very reactive in its approach to superannuation planning and design and has left most of the initiatives in the hands of the bureaucrats and advisers to the government. I think this is a shortcoming which needs to be addressed and needs to be addressed very soon. In an area which is as complex as superannuation planning, in an area which is going to have enormous impact on the capacity of domestic savings to increase over time, with all the economic implications associated with that, equally as important is the need for the industry as a whole to be in a position where it can be proactive to the need for change and be in a position to go to government on occasions and put forward proposals for policy changes which are clearly to the benefit of the community.

I make that point in the context of a very changing community. The basis of the current superannuation policy is well and truly found in the traditional lifestyle of an Australia which, regrettably, has now passed. The principle which the government takes for granted in relation to long-term superannuation savings is that people will go into the work force at about 18 to 20; they will stay there for about 45 years; they will never lose their jobs; they will never get divorced; they will never have any kids; they will never get sick; they will never need retraining; their income will continue to rise inexorably throughout that period; and, glory of all glories, at the age of 65 or so they will finally get their gold watch and go into retirement with a substantial nest egg.

I can assure you, Mr Speaker, and members of this House that unfortunately that is not the reality of life today for any of us. In that context it is clear that you need to have a much more flexible approach to long-term saving and also to intermediate saving. The point has been made by ACOSS on a number of occasions recently, and I think correctly, that the emphasis in the government's whole proposal has essentially been to introduce as close to a universal system as possible, which may have the advantage in terms of macro-savings policy but equally carries with it the significant disadvantage that you are reducing the take-home pay and thus the disposable income potential of a substantial proportion of low to middle income earning Australians in the guise of saying to the Australian people, `When you retire don't worry; everything will be wonderful. You will be going out with a substantial sum of money.'

The whole base of the government's approach to this came out manifestly clearly in the Prime Minister's claim at the time of the last budget that the latest proposed changes to superannuation will see every retiree sailing off into the sunset with a minimum of $460,000. According to the Treasury's own estimates, to achieve that glorious amount a contributor would have to enter the work force—the mythical concept I spoke of earlier—in seven years time at the age of 25 and work full time on average wages for at least 40 years, and that is after the year 2002. Consequently, unless you are currently under 18 and can avoid any lengthy period out of the work force, the likelihood of you achieving anywhere near this mythical figure of $460,000 is, to say the least, highly dubious.

Again this is an example of how the Prime Minister tends to make an art form of using case studies such as this, which are at best the particular, and applying them to the general. It is my task before the House today to demonstrate that that is not the basis of a sensible long-term planning approach to superannuation, nor is it a policy which is necessarily going to be to the advantage of those very same people who the Prime Minister claims will have $460,000 at some stage in the future. The evident weakness of this approach is that, unless you are in your early 20s, in the foreseeable future you will be worse off under the government's proposed scheme.

What the government has effectively done is to mix the benefits of a national savings strategy, which no-one would dispute. Australia must reach a situation where its domestic savings profile is significantly better than it has been over recent years. Under this government the numbers have fallen, contrary to what the general impression may be. Domestic savings under the last 12 years of Labor have been appalling. It has only been in the last couple of years that we have seen effectively a one per cent increase to about 17 per cent of GDP from where it was before.

This point was made very clear by the economic consultant Vince FitzGerald, who advised some two years ago in a major government report on Australia's national savings that they had fallen to their lowest level this century. He excluded from that, of course, the Great Depression and both world wars. For most of the post-war period national savings were around 23 per cent of gross domestic product. By 1991-92 that had fallen to 16 per cent. As I said, it has now risen slightly to 17 per cent.

The 1995-96 budget was aimed at addressing that appalling savings performance. In fact, it was the very centrepiece of the government' strategy for re-election. Central to the plan is the reworking of the superannuation system from 1 January 1997, which is a long time away—again, over the hill far away. It reminds one of the legislation in this House on taxation reform which was going to be there, guaranteed; it was in law—l-a-w. We have exactly the same re-run on this. In that context a new three per cent employee superannuation payment was to be phased in through industrial awards. That was to be done because the government was not sure that it could control its vote in the Senate and was therefore not prepared to take the risk of what that may incur. So it has gone to the IRC and said, `Through your industrial award process we will now, over a series of years, reduce the take-home pay of every worker in Australia by three per cent.' This is in addition to the existing six per cent, bringing it up to nine per cent. The intention is that by the year 2002 the total contribution will be around 15 per cent.

The fundamental weakness of that approach is simply this: it will depend to a large degree on which union you belong to, under which award you happen to fall and if the union has the power and the capacity to influence the outcome as to whether you will get either that three per cent arrangement included in your final wage determination or whether you will end up being a loser. As I will demonstrate, the evidence is quite clear that there will probably be a lot of losers under this proposal.

When, before the last election, the public was sold the legislated tax cuts, which were to commence on 1 January and were worth $1.8 billion for the first half of the year and over $4 billion for each full year after that, they thought they were going to get those as tax cuts from 1 January 1996. At best, they are now being told that they will be paid out, on a needs basis, on the basis of a subsidy of up to $1,000 per superannuation contributor as the government's share. In other words, it is a `feel good' promise. It is not a `be good' promise but a `feel good' promise—and there is a big difference between those two in politics. But we are told that politics is so much a case of impressions and not reality—and the Prime Minister has made an art form of that.

However, as I have said, this whole package is not before the parliament, apparently it is not intended to be before the parliament, with the possible exception of amendments to the taxation law. But certainly the proposal will not be before the House and it will go through the industrial relations system. The fundamental question that has to be asked is: will this proposal benefit everyone, as the Prime Minister claims? I now want to demonstrate to the House beyond any doubt that the answer is clearly no.

While the employer levy was implemented by legislation, the proposed employee levy will not be. If you are not therefore covered by an award, you simply miss out. There are hundreds and thousands of Australian workers, especially those on low income, who currently are not covered by awards in Australia. In reality therefore, the government's decision means that, once again, it will be employers who bear the cost of superannuation, largely. There is no doubt, given the experience of wage demands before the Industrial Relations Commission, that all new wage claims between now and the year 2000 will factor in the superannuation component, together with its inflationary impact. That will be particularly so for strong unions. It will be the strong unions who will have the major controlling impact on the demand for labour and on the price which labour will be able to seek in that context.

As for the Prime Minister's claim that the proposal will see everybody retire and sail into the sunset with the minimum amount of $460,000. The fact of the matter is that Treasury estimates make it quite clear that the likelihood of that occurring is very slight indeed. Nevertheless, this is the way it has been approached.

I am very concerned that the Prime Minister, in endeavouring to sell the benefits of his package, has used a four per cent real rate of return, which is totally spurious. It is true that the ASFA funds over the past 30 years have earned 4.4 per cent, if you take account of price increases only. But when salary increases are taken into account, the real rate of return has been almost half of that—some 2.8 per cent. What we are seeing here, yet again, is the grotesque raising of unreal expectations right across the country by a Prime Minister who wants to use superannuation and the savings of ordinary men and women in Australia as a political weapon for the next election campaign. It is a disgrace and he should be absolutely ashamed at doing that.

The reality is that retirees between now and the year 2002 who would otherwise have had the benefit of income tax cuts starting on 1 January 1996, having been legislated in this House under that l-a-w principle that the Prime Minister told us about at the last election, will receive nothing except this very dubious superannuation promise, possibly some form of future subsidy from the government in 1998-99.

TALK.START.PARA: —He'll be gone before then.

—Absolutely gone, no doubt about that. For the self-funded retiree, there is nothing. Once again, the efforts of those who have, wisely and often with some difficulty, saved to provide for themselves have been totally ignored. The costs to the government's superannuation package under this new proposal, when existing tax benefits are included, will be at least $8 billion per year.

PARA.TAB: According to Treasury's own document, Savings for our future, the important thing is that the benefits are unquantifiable. In other words, unless you are presuming that bracket creep will be able to finance the government's proposals, there is nothing in the budget, including, as I said, the intention to legislate, which will provide any evidence as to where the additional $4.4 billion is supposed to come from. Again, it is pie in the sky. It is a promise in a rainbow. It is far from reality.

What is worse than that is that the cost of the superannuation package, again according to the Treasury's own document, will grow faster than the cost of the tax cut it replaces and will eventually exceed the cost of those tax cuts. The consequent result of that is that there will be an unquantifiable impact on revenue loss, as earnings on increased superannuation savings are taxed at the concessional rate compared with those applying to alternative forms of saving. Furthermore, increased contributions by the self-employed would add to the cost of the package in net terms.

What seems to have been ignored in all of this is the whole problem of churning. A real addition to saving can only be found if it is new savings—not the reworking of the existing savings dollar and not the removal of savings, say, from the banking system to put into superannuation. That is not real savings. That is simply a churning effect, which is often the outcome of policies which are badly designed, as this one clearly was.

What was the budget's centrepiece? What was the reason behind this whole great strategy, apart from trying to win an election? It was rightly based on two words: national savings. The question therefore has to be: to what extent will this proposal translate into productive investment and economic growth? Projections from the Treasury's retirement income modelling task force, RIM, estimate that the proposals will contribute a mere one per cent increase in savings by 2005. By 2020, this figure is expected to rise to 1.7 per cent, a less than generous figure. It never goes beyond that. Given that the FitzGerald report recommended a rise in national savings of five per cent as being the target that Australian governments should aim for, one has to conclude that the efficacy of this Labor proposal as a savings measure is, quite simply, too little and too late.

Given that the superannuation proposal is not really an effective savings measure, the question then has to be asked: who is going to benefit—apart from the government, of course? The obvious winners in this case are the ACTU and the affiliated unions thereof. They will be the ones who negotiate the package. They are the ones who negotiated this deal with the government in the first place.

Their proposed award route, and the fact that only employee contributions paid into funds to which employer superannuation guarantee contributions are made will be recognised by the government for its contribution, blatantly ignores the rights of individual employees to freedom of choice, of either their fund or the style of investment they want, and directs a generous proportion of future superannuation contributions into industry funds.

What does that mean for the trade union movement, the membership of which is falling day by day? The answer is quite clear. Through this mechanism, the financial future of the trade union movement is absolutely guaranteed because through industry funds they will now have access not only to that three per cent. When that is spread over the majority of the work force, it runs to hundreds of millions of additional dollars of investment, which is giving the trade union movement into the future an enormous level of economic and social power in this country, regardless of the size of their membership. That is the most horrific and worrying aspect of this whole package.

The Treasurer (Mr Willis), in an address to the Industry Funds Forum last week, justified the lack of provision for consumer choice as being compelled by `administrative simplicity'. I tell you what administrative simplicity is: it is all about monopoly. It is all about ensuring through the IRC that one or, at most, two superannuation funds are given effectively monopoly or duopoly control over all investment policy of all workers in a whole industry or group of industries. It also takes no account of the fact that you are going to see in the foreseeable future the aggregation of funds. Already there are probably too many. There will be fewer funds but they will be bigger funds.

Those industry funds especially will, in due course, become in their own right new Australian investment institutions. They will not need the AMPs, the National Mutuals or any of the other major institutions which are currently operating in this area. These new institutions will stand alone, but they will have enormous economic power. Through shareholdings in the companies where their workers are employed, they will be in a position to call the shots on Australia's economic future well into the next century.

These issues have not been raised by the Treasurer. These points certainly have not been raised by the Prime Minister. But these are the issues which the opposition is particularly concerned about. The aggregation of power in this country will ultimately be a danger to the Australian people, to their freedom and to the importance and relevance of this parliament. These issues must be looked at very carefully indeed.

The coalition supports the development by the industry of an effective transfer protocol between funds to help employees who are in more than one scheme and who often find themselves in a situation where the fund is actually going down year by year because no new contributions are being made but the costs, fees, charges and taxes are still being applied. The ultimate outcome is that the funds at retirement simply do not exist. That is why we have called upon the industry—as has the government, to its credit—to develop an effective transfer protocol between funds so that issues of vesting and portability can be addressed, to the interests of the contributors who are forced to save by the government through the compulsory system.

The coalition has long supported greater freedom of choice for superannuation contributors. This is where our policy and that of the Labor government are absolutely at odds. The government wants a compulsory system. It wants a system where people are forced into it, with no freedom of choice, either in terms of choice of fund they want to belong to or choice of the investment strategy which they would like their funds to apply within the individual fund.

In that monopoly situation, in that reactive environment which I referred to earlier, the industry has not had the opportunity to develop more flexibility so it can offer greater freedom of choice which we see as absolutely important. Surely, in the context of the Hilmer report, which we have heard so much about in this chamber and elsewhere, the same principles should apply to the superannuation industry as well.

There is nothing wrong with freedom of choice. There is certainly nothing wrong with greater competition. It is in everybody's interests. Ultimately, that is the only way you can reduce costs, fees and charges; and, on the other side of the equation, maximise the opportunities for a more effective system where the funds have to relate to the demands and the needs of the community and their contributors, not be in the passive role where the contributors are simply putting funds in a compulsory scheme whether they like it or not.

Given the realities of all of this, according to Treasury, the amount which will be available to superannuation funds is expected to increase tenfold by 2020, from the current level of about $186 billion. In other words, quite early in the next century, we are talking about trillions of dollars of investment through superannuation funds. That is the most likely outcome that we are going to see in the foreseeable future.

As I said earlier, the danger of this is that you are putting in the hands of a few fund managers economic power quite beyond the capacity possibly of this parliament or of most Australians to fully understand. It is a sad fact that, in that environment, there are risks which have to be addressed.

I want to refer now to the question of directed investment. Given the huge sums involved and the investment power the funds are obviously capable of creating, there will be a risk of political interference. The issue of directed investment may well raise its ugly head yet again, as it has from time to time in this place and elsewhere in recent years. The Treasurer recently gave this assurance:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the government's policy not to interfere in investment decisions of superannuation funds.
He went on to say that, as funds grow, trustees will need to look beyond traditional investments if they are to sustain high rates of return. However, he added:

This will be important not only to achieve the government's retirement incomes objectives but also to ensure that our superannuation savings are directed to maximising Australia's future economic development.

The danger is that a Labor government would intervene in order to ensure that this occurs, the direction he referred to will be part of the expected government policy. That is nothing unusual, because what the Treasurer said to the industry and what was said at the last Labor Party conference in Hobart are certainly not the same. In Hobart the party said—and this is its policy:

. . . the Government will take all steps necessary, including an indication of preference in tender documents, to maximise the participation in bidding consortia by Australian superannuation funds, especially industry funds.

In other words, the attitude of mind is alive and well within the Labor Party and that attitude of mind is to direct investment of superannuation funds at some stage in the future. The implications of that are very important for every single contributor, because the government is simply saying, `You make your savings through a compulsory vehicle. We will then direct the investors as to how those moneys should be spent in what we see as the national interest.'

PARA.TAB: We hear talk about money being directed towards infrastructure development, social objectives, the rebuilding of our cities and so forth. If that were ordinary taxation revenue taken from the Australian people as part of the outcome of a political campaign run through an election process, that may be sustainable, but this is not the same thing. These are the savings of millions of Australian workers. The reason that those savings have been taken is ostensibly to give them financial independence in their retirement. Yet there is this growing tendency in the government to say, `No, we will determine where those funds are going to be spent and, if the outcome is that there is a negligible return or no return, hard luck. Somehow or other costs will be shared with the next generation of superannuants coming through the system.' It is a very forced economic model and one which will bring considerable disillusionment to the Australian people.

As I said to LIFA last week, the industry must be forever on its guard against this sort of situation developing. However, `it is the industry's responsibility to prove to a public somewhat disillusioned by recent poor returns that it is able to manage the huge influx of funds in the community's interests. Power cannot be exercised without responsibility. Responsibility entails accountability'.

It is the regulatory process for which the government must be responsible to ensure that accountability is clearly there. The first stage of the accountability process must be in the annual reporting arrangements in place through the CIS regulations, which bring together the contributors, the trustees and the fund managers in a symbiotic relationship which will ensure that those whose funds are being managed are aware at all times of the purposes for which that money is being used and the outcome of those decisions.

The coalition superannuation policy has in recent months been questioned in this House by members opposite. I want to emphasise simply the points I made before. We have a policy which encourages people to be in superannuation. We have a policy which involves a mixture of compulsion on the one hand and voluntary support on the other. We have a policy which gives people much greater freedom to choose the funds in which they invest and in the management styles and the systems they want to apply. For example, people in their 20s may wish to have an investment profile which encourages greater risk but greater returns on their investment, whereas people in their 50s may prefer to have an investment profile with a heavy emphasis on capital accumulation and minimising of risks, because by that stage they are getting close enough to retirement not to want to lose their funds.

These are two very different investment models. In most funds today those opportunities do not exist. You put your money into the fund—you are required to go into the fund—and it is invested for you under the terms and conditions determined by the trustees, not by you as a contributor. Those changes we regard as absolutely fundamental if we want to have a society which is confident of the objectives of government policy, which is to maximise national savings while at the same time being confident that their investments are secure in their own interests and the interests of their family to guarantee them a retirement which they can look forward to, and at the same time which makes a contribution to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, with your indulgence, I wish to correct a reference which I made in response to a question yesterday from you as member for Wakefield. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) is the second opportunity we have had to debate superannuation issues in the past two sitting weeks. That is in addition to the opportunities we have had to talk about superannuation in the appropriation debates. In these circumstances, it is possible to explain the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Willis), the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) could not find the time to come into the parliament to conduct this legislation. I have great regard for the abilities of my friend the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), but I suggest he does not pretend to have established any credentials in the area of superannuation. I again make the point that once again the arrogance of this government knows no bounds. The arrogance it displays towards this parliament is despicable.

PARA.TAB: We could add that to the fact that with the previous piece of legislation in the previous sitting week and today not one speaker from the Labor Party was or is listed. No doubt the whip could, if he really wanted to, hurry around now and dredge up someone to come in to make a few innocuous remarks. During appropriation debates a whole raft of speakers opposite get up and talk about superannuation, which they claim is the centrepiece of this year's budget.

Here is a chance to talk about the nitty-gritty of the legislation and how we will get to what those opposite say their Prime Minister-cum-emperor says will be achieved by the superannuation policies of his government. This is the opportunity to see the legislation and how it will work, but where are the supporters of the government? They are missing, absent—not without leave but with leave, I suggest. So we have this stupid situation where people get up over there and rabbit on about the policy on superannuation promoted by this government and what it will achieve, but not one of them can come in here or will take the time to understand the legislation which makes those stated policy objectives possible.

This bill relates to one of the Commonwealth Public Service employee superannuation schemes, whereas the other piece of legislation I referred to a little while ago had to do with problems with small accounts. This bill was introduced into the House on 29 March. Members opposite have had plenty of time to prepare their remarks and try to understand it if they were genuinely interested in superannuation.

The bill's primary goal is to complete the process of bringing the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, the CSS, and the public sector superannuation scheme, the PSS, under the guidelines of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, which will be referred to as `the act' in later remarks. It is a goal with which the coalition has no argument. It follows that we will not be opposing the bill.

At the moment there is also a significant amount of discussion about superannuation, and I have referred to it in this parliament. Seemingly every speaker on the government side wants to mention it but none of them wants to understand how it is working and, more importantly, how it is not working.

The measures contained in the budget, and a renewed interest in the limited choice of superannuation schemes as well as portability, are among the reasons for my interest today and that of many in the industry and many potential superannuants. Whatever the reason, it goes without saying that superannuation is an issue of national importance and should be treated as such. This applies to public sector superannuation schemes, of which the CSS and PSS are examples, and the various private sector industry award schemes and the like.

Public sector schemes at both state and federal levels are traditionally very generous to their members. It is no doubt appreciated by those of us who have benefited over the years, but the fact remains that they are largely funded by taxpayers and they are largely built upon unfunded liabilities of many millions of dollars. The exception to this is Queensland where successive governments have maintained a fully funded scheme. I intend to touch on these matters in more depth later if I have time.

Superannuation is an important issue simply because Australia has a population which we describe as ageing. In 1992, 13.4 per cent of the Australian population were of age pension vintage. I am informed that the Department of Social Security predicts that this will increase to around 14.4 per cent by the year 2001 and finally reaching a peak of 25.7 per cent in the year 2031.

As government funds are limited—and I presume they always will be—the importance of individuals making provision for their retirement has never been greater. The number of self-funded retirees in our community is increasing greatly. The proportion of the population who are of pensionable age and who are receiving the pension or equivalent has declined from something like 86.3 per cent in 1980 to an estimated 77.5 per cent in 1992. It has been estimated that by the year 2031 the proportion receiving the pension may reduce to around 20 per cent of the population eligible, by reason of age, for a pension. Let us hope that by 2031 we will still be able to afford a pension system.

So it follows that the need for government to foster a fair, just and equitable system for self-funded retirees cannot be overstated. One of the most important starting points for many people in planning for their retirement is to be assured of a stable and predictable political policy and economic environment. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know only too well, this has not been the case over recent years; it has not been there over recent years. Year after year Labor has failed to develop a retirement income strategy, yet the government has been quick to grab the extra revenue it receives because of the superannuation contributions tax.

Let me remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker—and I am sure you have not forgotten—that in 1988-89 the government collected $7 million in superannuation tax. In 1994-95 the government will collect $1.9 billion and the estimate for 1995-96 is $2.15 billion. That is not a bad sort of a milch cow. It is no wonder people looking at their individual superannuation account statements see that they are going backwards, because the funds have not been earning well in recent times. Taken off the top of their five per cent contribution is the government's 15 per cent tax. So they are really not paying five per cent into their superannuation account; they are paying 4.25 per cent. That is why it is going backwards. People think five per cent is good, but when they do the compound multiplication they find it is not adding up because there is 15 per cent taken off the top. That is not a bad return for the government.

The increase in the estimated superannuation tax from 1988-89, when it was $7 million, to 1995-96 is a factor of over 30,000 per cent—not a bad little earner. We will have to ride that pig's back right into the next century if we should be unlucky enough for Labor to stay in government. Heaven help the taxpayers of Australia and the potential superannuants.

The building blocks of a genuine retirement income strategy are there, and they are not in dispute. I made mention of these points in the debate on the previous legislation, but they deserve to be listed again. A genuine retirement income strategy requires a stable and predictable political environment; security; incentives to encourage financial independence; better integration of the tax and social security systems; and the guarantee of a government safety net. Few would disagree with those fundamentals, I suggest. However, the fact is that for many people retirement policy these days is beyond comprehension. The changes to the legislation have been massive and seemingly unending. We have already had two bills this year.

The growth in complexity of superannuation law is nearly as great as the growth in complexity of taxation law, and that is saying something. The FitzGerald report on national savings summed up the mess which the government has created with superannuation when it said:

SPEECH.PARA: It goes almost without saying that further change to superannuation is not desirable in itself—continual change in recent years has engendered complexity and uncertainty and diminished confidence.

That was at the time of the FitzGerald report, which was more than a year ago, and it has not got any better since then. The challenge that remains is to keep it simple. The government obviously cannot come to terms with that. It cannot decide what its strategy should be to meet its total objectives. The government has eroded the community's confidence in superannuation in the process.

PARA.TAB: One of the results of Labor's persistent meddling and tinkering has been the growing perception that superannuation no longer represents an attractive savings and investment vehicle. Public confidence in superannuation needs to be restored. This will be a primary objective of the coalition's approach to superannuation.

I do not intend to discuss in any depth here the superannuation developments contained in the budget. However, I want to make the point that whilst national savings will increase as a result of the introduction of employee contributions—provided other savings habits remain static—there is still no real choice available to Australian workers in deciding which superannuation scheme to join; that is, in deciding whom to trust with their retirement money.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in post-budget interviews described the great returns Australians will receive from their superannuation when they retire—that is if they live to the year 2042 and start contributing now. He obviously does not realise that many workers are in superannuation schemes which perform dismally. In other words, they do not earn sufficient to provide the sort of end result that the Prime Minister so glibly predicts for 2042 or whenever it was. This is made worse because most workers have no choice as to which superannuation scheme their money can rest and prosper in.

The purpose of this bill is to amend four acts dealing with the CSS and the PSS, as I said. The amendments will ensure that Commonwealth superannuation arrangements comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act and regulations under that act. It will also correct anomalies, restore the original intentions of certain provisions, remove gender specific terms, and make technical and drafting changes to improve the administrative efficiency of the schemes.

SI(S) requires that trustees of public sector superannuation schemes should elect that the schemes become regulated under SI(S) by 1 July 1995. The amendments to the acts are to take effect from that date. The bill also includes formal amendments to the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948. Some of the provisions in these amendments continue to apply to persons who resigned or retired prior to 1976, which is interesting.

The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1994 amended the 1976 act and other acts to commence the process of compliance with SI(S). The bill proposes to amend the act to correct a drafting error. It will also amend the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 to remove gender specific terms, which I have mentioned before. These generally go along the same line.

Given the complexity and volume of superannuation legislation, there is a need for a technical correction bill such as this, and I have touched on the complexity of its incessant changes. If this bill is a precedent for like legislation, it should be welcomed.

The bill is the perfect opportunity for me to reiterate some concerns that I have made known previously. As honourable members would be aware, there are no employer contributions from the Commonwealth to meet future claims upon the CSS and only very limited contributions to the PSS. On retirement, the employer component of the CSS, and most of the PSS, comes from consolidated revenue. This means that for the CSS alone there was an unfunded liability of $33 billion as at 30 June 1992. This was a liability of $1,903 for each man, woman and child in this country. For the PSS, the employer contribution is only three per cent of salary. This leaves the remaining 12.4 per cent unfunded.

However, the government's potential liability does not end there. In the CSS, employee contributions are invested by Commonwealth Funds Management—the CFM—with returns to employees based on investment incomes. In the PSS though, employee contributions are invested by the CFM, but the return is guaranteed and not limited to investment returns. The Commonwealth thereby has to make up any shortfall that occurs, further exposing consolidated revenue to the need to pay out PSS members on retirement.

A fully funded superannuation scheme is the most desirable scheme to have in place. The strongest argument in support of full funding concerns the principle of intergenerational equity. It is more equitable that the cost of liabilities currently incurred should be met by the present generation and should not be left to be paid for by future generations. Future generations may simply not have the capacity to pay for the superannuation of preceding generations.

A lessening of future fiscal flexibility will severely inhibit the ability of future generations to make the necessary decisions on where taxpayers' funds can best be allocated. It is quite clear that the postwar generation—commonly referred to as the baby boomers—has created a debt burden that will blight our children's lives. This blight will occur because the children of the baby boom generation will be left to pay the unfunded superannuation and pensions of their parents, as well as the mounting health and nursing home bills. This is a key reason why future public and private sector superannuation should be fully funded.

Superannuation is also an important component of Labor costs, and governments should be recognising these costs and paying for them as they arise. There could also be the added bonus of giving governments increased resolve to keep staff numbers under control and inhibit governments from engaging in activities for which there is no real benefit from the community at large.

Fully funded schemes would also have the advantage that governments would need to keep schemes within the demands of economic realities. One of the few arguments against the full funding of public sector superannuation is that, while Australia is a net borrower, it does not make sense to borrow further in order to fund public sector superannuation. This is a valid point, and I suspect there are others. The reasons for establishing fully funded schemes are much more persuasive.

The government, when establishing the PSS in 1990, took the decision to partially fund the scheme to avoid a large increase in unfunded liabilities. When establishing the PSS, the government not only made it partially funded but also reduced the level of future entitlements due to fund members. This has been achieved by reducing the new entrant contribution rate—that is, the average employer contribution expressed as a percentage of salary—from 22.8 per cent to 15.4 per cent.

The Commonwealth is not the only Australian government to reduce the level of its own contributions. New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia have all created new public sector superannuation schemes which are partially funded and have reduced employer contributions. As of 30 June 1992 Victoria's unfunded superannuation liabilities amounted to $18 billion, which at $4,063 per capita is the worst in the nation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak today on Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I intend to focus my remarks on the economy of local areas, local governments, the budget's implications in those areas and some of the issues which I believe are still causing some problems in the economy in relation to regional Australia. Under the budgetary proposals, money was appropriated for housing and regional development, urban management, local government and industry, and I wish to cover some of those areas.

PARA.TAB: In urban management, the government has instituted a continuing and active role for the Commonwealth in Australia's cities through $247 million in additional funding for the continuation of the better cities program. That $247 million includes: $36 million over six years for continued better cities planning and detailed studies in priority areas where major capital investment is expected; $200 million over four years for capital investment in developing and renewing key areas of Australia's major cities to advance national economic, social and environmental performance—of this amount, $100 million will be allocated over the next three years through Better Cities for investment in key rail-based urban corridors in Queensland, and I am sure that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Ms Crawford), who is at the table, would take interest in that one—and $11 million over six years for running costs.

On top of that, there is an allocation of $2.4 million over four years to pilot and evaluate service improvements to important parts of the public transport system in the cities and $3 million over six years for urban design initiatives, including the Australia Prize for Urban Design awarded by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

There are incentives for local government to assist national economic, environmental and social objectives through the introduction of an expanded local government development program with additional funding of $48 million over four years. There will be an extension of the housing industry and urban exports strategy at a total cost of $12.8 million over five years, and $8.5 million will be spent over four years to improve the protection and management of Australia's coastline. These are all very important issues and need to be further developed over those periods.

In regional development, an additional $5 million will be spent over three years to expand the department's regional office network to support regional development organisations across Australia. There will be rationalisation of the functions and activities of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation, which is to be wound up, and $15.6 million will be spent over three years through the Office of Northern Development to fund strategic roads in the Northern Territory, improving access to indigenous communities. These are all very important matters in relation to regional development.

In relation to housing, there will be an increase in rent assistance of $5 a fortnight to families with children at a cost of $88 million over four years. Over five years, $12.7 million will be spent to increase the capacity of local government and the community housing sector to provide housing for Australians on low incomes and to support the development of the new Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

There will be savings from the social housing subsidy program of $10 million in 1995-96 and $16 million in each of the subsequent three years. There will be further integration of job placement, employment and training pilot programs within Working Nation and half a million dollars will be appropriated for Australia's participation in the 1996 United Nations habitat conference. Of course money will also be appropriated to the Department of Social Security for housing. It is these areas of housing and regional development to which I wish to address most of my remarks.

What we are finding with the structural change in Australia, particularly in Victoria and in the area that I represent, the electorate of McMillan, is that there has been massive structural change all occurring in a short period of time over about three years. Some of that structural change has flowed from changes in our electricity industry in Victoria. Our region is a pretty unique region of Australia. All the power stations of Victoria are coal-fired stations, except for one gas-fired station located in the municipality of La Trobe in my electorate.

The impact of change has been particularly difficult for the people in that community. It is a very small community of 100,000 people, but they have had to carry the load of the structural change. To put it on the record in the federal parliament again, the electricity industry has gone from a work force of 10,300 when it was owned by the government to a corporatised privatised operation now of 2,800 employees at the moment. With the latest packages being signed up at present, it looks like dropping to about 1,800 employees—from 10,300 to 1,800. That would have an enormous impact on any area, and it is having a devastating impact on our economy.

The community is handling it in a vigorous way. It is not laying down and saying all is lost. There are many things we can do and the community is responding very well. Some of those employees have been re-employed by private companies which are doing the outsourcing work for the power station companies. About 2,000 of the 7,000-odd who have left the SEC have found employment with them. However, employment for the others is rather difficult. To overcome problems of this nature, and I think the Gregory report that was released recently pointed this out from the census figures, some of this impact on particular areas needs to be addressed.

In Victoria at the moment the other restructure that has taken place has been in local government. It is probably the area, along with private industry, that will feel the full impact of implementing the structural change. But we have a particularly difficult problem in Victoria with the restructure of local government in that the Kennett government has set about the restructure in a very dramatic way. It has appointed commissioners to control the operation and has also passed legislation demanding that the commissioners act in a particular way and further cut expenditure.

Cutting expenditure is adding to our problem, along with the loss of jobs in the State Electricity Commission and what has happened there. In fact our local government has been asked to cut $6.2 million from a $23 million budget over a period of three years, which also means the loss of jobs. One hundred people have now lost their jobs in the local government area. With the outsourcing and contracting out, which has been made compulsory by legislation, many more jobs will go as the contracting out occurs and people will have to find jobs with the new contractors, if they are able.

Our major problem then stems from the question: where does local government get the money required to respond to some of the Commonwealth programs? One of the major initiatives of this government has been the Working Nation program. It has been very effective around Australia in assisting people to get back into the work force and giving them the training and the opportunities that are required in order to convince private employers that they do have a role to play in the economy. Our great difficulty occurs in that many of these programs rely upon some capital grant works in order to make them operational. Otherwise, if you try to employ 15 people in a supervised group with no capital you are virtually, in many cases, cleaning up weeds and planting trees. That has a very worth while end in its own right, however, there are many other objectives that I am sure the local communities would like to achieve.

That is the problem in our area. We have had a depressed area now for a considerable time. We have had a problem with the rate base for local governments. We have very run-down infrastructure, particularly in Morwell and Moe, where local government would participate in normal circumstances to assist the community. Because there has been no capital base, the unemployed of that region are expected to go and work in other regions of Gippsland, where the money is available, to provide capital for the works program.

In my electorate we have to the west the new municipality of Baw Baw. They have been very successful. It is a credit to their organisation that they have been able to put programs forward. I had the privilege nine weeks ago of launching a major program there with 103 former unemployed people. Well over $1 million in labour support was being provided, plus something like $700,000 for training support and management of the program. The municipality was able to put in a fair share of funds in order to have the works put in place. I am going along next Friday to inspect the process at half stage.

There have been other programs. The Walhalla railway in the Baw Baw shire has received two programs. A third program is about to start. There have been 30 employees for half a year, 26 weeks, on works on the Walhalla rail line. The community is working towards redeveloping a rail line for tourist purposes. When you consider that some 30 people have been paid for half a year by the Commonwealth with another 10 coming on stream, a considerable amount of money has been injected into the Baw Baw shire, as well as $400,000 for supervision, support and training. The local community has also been able to raise some funds. So several millions of dollars have gone into different parts of Gippsland in these training programs.

We have great difficulty in the municipality of La Trobe getting programs off the ground. The total sum of money for 12 programs was $25,000 from local government. When the program organisers or the brokers approached the local government they were informed that only a couple of thousand dollars would be available and that therefore there would be great difficulty getting 15 people for 26 weeks. This was of great concern. We did not seem to be able to get anywhere. We were able to convince the municipality recently that the former Moe City, the people in charge before the amalgamation, had put aside $150,000 for new work programs and, therefore, that new work money should be available. However, the commissioners decided that $25,000 was all they were able to make available.

The commissioners were obviously under pressure from the Kennett government to reduce costs and to make savings. They had set aside $80,000—there would be no action at the moment; perhaps they would have a look at it in the future. When we found out that that $80,000 was there, after a few meetings of the local football club and other organisations in the area we soon had a delegation to the commissioners and we were able to raise $30,000 locally to support a program. The commissioners responded.

The real problem in the area is the lack of a rate base. The power stations in the Latrobe Valley do not pay rates. They have not paid rates because they have been owned by the government. There has been the charity bit of $10,000, a bit here, a bit somewhere else. However, with the move of Mission Energy, a private company, to Loy Yang B as 51 per cent owners, they found they were paying by law $708,000 a year in rates. That $708,000 a year has been very beneficial over the last couple of years to Traralgon city and Traralgon shire. But now there are the new amalgamations and the sale of the power stations. I have always believed that once state instrumentalities are corporatised and privatised they should pay rates.

I wrote to the Premier putting a case to him about this. I raised the issues with him on 30 March, with a copy to Alan Stockdale, the state Treasurer. I put to him that the most obvious means by which his government could meet its responsibilities would be to begin paying rates on the local companies it has now formed with legislation and that the people in the Latrobe Valley should not have to wait for the full process of privatisation before the region sees its fair share of rate moneys returning to its coffers.
Mr Kennett replied to me on 12 April, and I will read that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Cunningham
Thank you for your letter regarding corporatised companies paying rates.
We are reforming the Latrobe Valley to ensure its future, that of its employees, and to bring the electricity industry into the 21st Century.

I do not understand why you and your colleagues believe the Valley's future lies in the past. Your personal failure to exhibit leadership in building something of long term value, is in stark contrast to the successful conclusion of the Hilmer discussions yesterday at COAG where Labor and Liberal Leaders committed to long term growth of opportunities for all Australians.
Yours sincerely
Jeff Kennett
I wrote back to him on 1 May, saying:
Dear Premier,
I refer to your letter to me dated 12 April, 1995.
In your zeal to attack me personally you have not responded to the question raised in my letter.
I once again ask: Will the Latrobe Valley's newly corporatised power companies pay rates to the Municipality of Latrobe?
I cannot make the question any simpler for you.
This is a legitimate question that the people of the Latrobe Valley deserve to have answered.
I look forward to your response to this question and hope that in future you will take a more professional attitude towards the serious problems facing the people of the Latrobe Valley.
He wrote back to me on 15 May, saying:
Dear Mr Cunningham
Thank you for your letter of 1 May 1995.
You are getting a bit sensitive in your old age. I did not attack you personally, and I thought my answer was quite clear.
Corporatised bodies will not pay municipal rates.
Yours sincerely
Jeff Kennett
That sat on my desk for a week, during which time I pondered that approach by our esteemed premier. Then on 22 May I received this letter:
Dear Mr Cunningham
RATING PROVISIONS FOR GENERATION COMPANIES
My letter of 15 May 1995 on this topic has been superseded.

Following further debate of this issue, by both the Cabinet, Party, and Ministers concerned, the revised position, to be incorporated by way of a House Amendment to the Electricity Industry Amendment Bill is as follows:
1.the existing municipal rating exemption for Victoria Power Exchange, Power Net Victoria and the SEC remains;
2.all land held by distribution companies and generation companies (in this context, including General Victoria) is to be rateable under the Local Government Act;

3.in relation to generation companies (and only with respect to land associated with power stations), if the parties do not agree the amount of rates, then an arbitration process through the Victoria Grants Commission will be triggered. One of the factors which the Commission must take into account in determining reasonable rates is to be the amount payable in accordance with section 27 of the Loy Yang B Act 1992.
Yours sincerely
Jeff Kennett

That letter certainly created a lot of interest in the local area. Reading it one way, all land will be rateable. However, I am now informed—and I have not yet written back to the premier—from discussions at the local level, when the local government sought clarification, that they do not really mean to pay the rates just yet and that perhaps, if they go and negotiate, they might get some money out of the state government. However, they do not really mean that rates should be paid until it is fully privatised.

PARA.TAB: We have a confused situation where at the moment I am seeking clarification from the premier, as are the people in the local government. However, I am worried at the silence from the local members of the state parliament in the region, both National and Liberal, who do not appear to want to offend Jeffrey in any way at all. We know that our commissioners at the local government level are appointed by the Premier and are working to legislation and that he is laying down the law. Therefore, they are never going to represent the local people on this issue.

Therefore, today I am calling upon those local state members to stand up for the local people and to start putting a case to this premier. This is a serious matter, not to be trivialised. Obviously, the Premier's letter of the 15th having been superseded, we know now that the Local Government Act is to be instigated, with all land held by distribution companies and generation companies to be rateable under the Local Government Act.

I am of the opinion—and I have advised the shire, the chief commissioner, that, if I were him, I would be seeking legal advice on the legislation that has gone through the state parliament, because my belief is that what Jeffrey Kennett is doing at the present time is trying to find new owners for what are clearly private companies. He has structured his legislation, they have boards of directors, they have revamped all the employee structures.

What the state government is doing now is trying to sell those organisations to private companies by trade sale. Trade sale does not mean that he has to put through new legislation again. So I am firmly of the view that it is worth while seeking legal advice and putting the pressure right back on to the Kennett government and saying to it, `When are you going to honour this commitment?' It means about $3 million a year.

Taking a line through the fact that one half owner of one power station pays $708,000 in rates, then I would expect that the other half owner, which is the privatised section of Loy Yang B, would do the same. Loy Yang A is exactly the same size power station and can contribute a similar amount of money. We are talking about $3 1/2 million of rate money.

If that honest position were taken, the government's programs at the federal level under Working Nation would be of great benefit to the Latrobe valley region. The municipality does not have the capital funds to match the program. We are calling on the state government at this stage to move this along and to order the managers of their private companies to do their business plans again and put on the deck the fact that they do have a responsibility to the local community by way of rates. They have destroyed the economy by taking the employment out of it. Surely we are entitled to our money back.

I make this plea today in the debate on the appropriation bills: the Commonwealth has appropriated moneys which are available for programs and, if there is a need for matching money in these programs of urban development in particular and housing, this is the opportunity for local government to participate. But it is being stifled by the fact that the industries in that municipality, owned by the government privately at present in a private structure, are not paying their way by way of rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Battling to make ends meet, apprehension about the future, the despair that comes from knowing that `this is as good as it gets'—this is life for too many of the people I represent. For the benefit of those who define economic recovery as that point in the economic cycle when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) acquires a $2 million home, I would like to quote from a letter I received recently:

SPEECH.PARA: I am worrying about happiness for our children, their future and also ours. I am worrying about not getting enough money to live a decent life, about not being able to afford much, about working too hard for too little money, about having no job security. The price of property has not risen much for a very long time. I am worried about not having enough money for retirement or for my family. I am 49 years old, my husband is 60 years of age.
This is the message echoed in letter after letter I am receiving. Another states:

My wage packet is going only to the essentials these days and I have not had a pay rise in two years (I gross no more than $27,500). It is hard when everything is going up. . . I only need one more rise in my health care insurance and I am opting out. I can't cope with any more price hikes.
Yet another letter states:
I feel most insecure at all times.

These letters do not represent isolated cases of hardship. They are typical! In a recent survey of more than 600 households in my electorate, I put the question: do you consider yourself to be more financially secure than you were three years ago? Seventy-one per cent said no, they were worse off. These people are the ones the Prime Minister has forgotten in his misguided euphoria, in his conviction that `this is as good as it gets'.

PARA.TAB: Financial hardship in a climate of economic growth is the very essence of the recoveries the Prime Minister oversees. They are recoveries in which some find themselves in a position to buy that house on the harbour they have always wanted, while others are struggling to pay their next bill. They are shallow, fleeting recoveries as fewer and fewer Australians get back on their feet before the bust. They are recoveries in which the economic sun shines briefly—and each time it does, it does so for an increasingly select few. Put together, they are dividing Australian society.

After a decade of Labor rule, the share of total income earned by the richest 10 per cent of Australians rose from 21.9 per cent to just under 25 per cent in 1993. Total income for the poorest 10 per cent of earners fell to 2.8 per cent. This division is also manifesting itself between the states.

National economic growth for the year to September 1994 was 6.3 per cent; South Australia's growth was 1.7 per cent. Unemployment nationally is 8.7 per cent; South Australia's rate is 10.3 per cent. Given time, South Australia could have generated the growth rates and the employment that we need to tackle the massive public debt left to us by the Bannon Labor government, but we were not given time. We were given interest rate increases, the Prime Minister's favoured tool for bludgeoning investors and consumers into submission when their enthusiasm threatens a current account blow-out.

The greatest failing of the Keating government has been its inability to sustain economic recovery. What makes this failing criminal is the fact that the remedy has been no secret: cut the budget deficit. This was the task that faced the Prime Minister as he pieced together his 13th budget. On the surface, it would appear that the challenge has been met. In the words of the Treasurer (Mr Willis):

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget delivers a surplus in 1995-96 of $718 million.
In the words of Alan Ramsey, a former Labor staffer, who is now writing for the Sydney Morning Herald:
To trust this Budget you have to trust Paul Keating.
The following list of broken promises, cons and mess-ups suggests that this is a huge ask.

PARA.TAB: On budget night in August 1988, Australia was tentatively emerging from the banana republic current account crisis that had seen the Australian dollar collapse to the lowest level on record. The world's greatest Treasurer—already revealing something of the pig farmer he was to mature into—sold his budget with the promise:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this is the one that brings home the bacon.
Within two years, Australia had entered the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. In this recession, Australians were to feel the pain of unemployment rates at 11 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In February 1992, the Prime Minister announced in the One Nation statement that he would cut taxes. They were to be delivered in two rounds: the first in July 1994; the second in January 1996. In February 1993, in election mode, the Prime Minister said of the One Nation tax cuts:

SPEECH.PARA: They are not a promise, they are law—l-a-w—law.
In May 1995, the second round of One Nation tax cuts, $5.8 million worth, disappear.
