PARA.TAB: In November 1992, on the subject of his next term in government, the Prime Minister tells Lateline:

SPEECH.PARA: What I am promising is not to put up tax!

Since the last election, the following tax increases have been implemented or announced: fringe benefits tax increased by 130.7 per cent; wine tax increased from 22 to 24 per cent; excise on unleaded petrol increased by 5c per litre; excise on leaded petrol increased by 7c per litre; tobacco excise increased twice; sales tax increased across the board twice; sales tax on new vehicles increased by five per cent; sales tax on certain building materials increased by 12 per cent; company sales tax increased to 36 per cent; and the Medicare levy increased to 1.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In the third year of a parliamentary term in which no new taxes were promised, the tax take will increase in the 1995-96 budget by $2,400 million. This is the second largest tax increase since the irresponsible Whitlam years.
So what is the promise of a $718 million surplus worth? It is worth as much as all the other promises—nothing.

The 1995-96 budget betrays the battlers like the people whose letters I have read; people who looked to the government to do what was necessary to ensure that the recovery would be sustained and to ensure that the economic sunshine would last a little longer than five minutes. To ensure this, the government needed to attack its budget deficit. This it did not have the political courage or integrity to genuinely do. At the beginning of his budget speech, the Treasurer claimed to have produced, in his words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a massive turnaround in the budget outcome of $12.9 billion . . .
Yet, on page 2 of the budget speech, the Treasurer admits:
The measures announced tonight provide a net fiscal tightening . . . of $3 billion in 1995-96 . . .

As this statement makes clear, the massive turnaround in the budget outcome was not achieved by spending restraint. It should be noted that, in real terms, government spending in 1995-96 will grow by 1.7 per cent.

PARA.TAB: After the net fiscal tightening of $3 billion, the remainder of the $12.9 billion turnaround the government has achieved is made up of the increased revenue that comes from economic growth, of $5.3 billion worth of asset sales and of creative accounting. Among the more creative of the government's accounting practices, one would have to list the following: $994 million in debt repayment from Queensland; $107 million in higher dividends from government business enterprises; $250 million from a reconfiguration of Telstra equity injections; and $75 million from a capital repayment by Australia Post. These are one-off payments which only the most creative of accountants would use in calculating the bottom line.

The real bottom line for the 1995-96 budget—the one that deals with recurrent government spending and government revenue—is in fact tucked away at the back of the budget papers. Excluding such things as asset sales and other one-off payments, the real deficit, as defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, is $8.2 billion. Fudge-it budgets have no place in Australian government. The very essence of a democratic system of government is accountability, and disinformation makes it impossible to hold governments accountable. Honesty must be reintroduced into Australian government and one of the first tasks of a coalition government will be to hold a commission of audit to find the true state of the Commonwealth books.

Rather than help South Australia get on its feet, this budget will hit us hard. In the budget the government increased the sales tax on sinks, taps, putty, paint, nails, kitchen cupboards and many other building materials by 12 per cent. In this way, the government plans to raise $523 million in 1995-96. Many of my constituents on low and middle incomes have bought older, cheaper houses with the intention of renovating. The government's new 12 per cent tax on materials used in building will stop many of the renovations planned in my electorate. With the building industry already slowing, jobs will be lost as a result of this tax.

The five per cent tax hike on new cars will have much the same impact and will be disastrous in view of South Australia's dependence on the car industry. The day after the budget, the wholesale sales tax on new cars rose from 16 per cent to 21 per cent. On 1 July, when the second of the across-the-board sales tax increases which were legislated for in the 1993 budget takes place, the sales tax on new cars will rise to 22 per cent. The result: the cost of the average family car will increase by $1,000.
One must question why the Prime Minister has changed his mind and also, once again, his word. In his One Nation speech in February 1992 he said:
From tomorrow the sales tax on new cars currently subject to the 20 per cent rate will be permanently lowered to 15 per cent . . .
With cheaper cars we will drive newer cars, which is good for the environment, good for road safety, and good for one of our most important industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the sales tax that was permanently lowered to 15 per cent has been raised to 16 per cent since the last election, has been raised another five per cent in the 1995-96 budget and will be increased by another one per cent on 1 July. This is permanency under a Keating government! I suggest that this tax hike on new cars—that is, cars that run on unleaded fuel—is indicative of the Prime Minister's real commitment to the environment.

PARA.TAB: For those who contracted to buy a new car before the release of the budget on 9 May, the $1,000 that they now are asked to pay on that originally contracted price is causing enormous hardship. I have been contacted by people caught in this situation and, having already stretched themselves to buy their car at its original price, they simply do not have another $1,000 to meet this new obligation. Yet, having signed a contract, they are required to proceed with the sale.

A reasonable government would have exempted those who have already signed contracts from this tax. It is a measure of this government's arrogance that it did not do so. I know many people in my electorate are already struggling to make ends meet. Another $1,000 for a new car will price them out of this market. The Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The most immediate effect of this decision will be to cut sales by up to 20,000 vehicles in what was already shaping up to be a difficult year for the industry.

This jeopardises the jobs of 37,000 South Australians employed in the car industry. Again, the three per cent tax hike for companies will jeopardise jobs at a time when sections of my electorate have rates of unemployment well above 20 per cent.

PARA.TAB: It is indicative of the government's lack of economic direction that before the last election it lowered corporate tax to 33 per cent with much fanfare. The government waxed lyrical about narrowing the gap between Australia's corporate tax rates and that of our Asian neighbours so that overseas investors would be attracted to Australia. By raising corporate tax again, the government has jeopardised this important source of investment and jobs.

For the small businesses concentrated in inner Adelaide the loss of cashflow because of the increase in company tax will be a barrier to expansion, putting a lid on job growth when South Australia is still suffering 10.3 per cent unemployment. In an electorate where so much employment depends on small business my fear is that this sector, in the wake of the hike in company tax, will take the Prime Minister's advice that `If they're feeling the pinch, they ought to say, "Small business is not for me."'

In the context of the struggle to make ends meet that so many of my constituents are telling me about, it is absolutely unacceptable that the second round of One Nation tax cuts has disappeared off the political agenda. As I said during the debate on last year's budget:

SPEECH.PARA: By not handing over the—
second round of One Nation tax cuts—

that it promised the Australian people, the government is effectively pocketing the benefits of the recovery, benefits which rightfully belong to those who bore the brunt of the recession: the Australian people.

It is middle Australia, too, that loses out in this budget. The tax cuts abandoned by the Prime Minister could have provided significant relief to the middle income range—those earning between $30,000 and $50,000. As a leading Flinders University senior lecturer in economics, Mr Graham Scott, has said, Australia's unenviable reputation as a high income tax country has been reinforced by this budget.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's latest promise is that the money people would have received from the One Nation tax cuts will be now paid into their superannuation fund. But those who retire between now and the year 2002 will not receive the full benefit of the tax cuts they have been obliged to forgo. And what of our self-funded retirees—those who were frugal and saved for their retirement? Those retirees pay tax and once again they will suffer from the Prime Minister's broken promises.

Too many people in my electorate are battling. This budget plays with their future as though they no longer matter. The current account for April was $2.252 billion in the red. This is the eighth current account deficit of more than $2 billion in the last nine months. The Keating government is allowing Australia to run a current account deficit of around six per cent of GDP, allowing Australia to run a current account deficit which runs second only to Mexico as being the highest in the OECD—a current account deficit which puts us in the danger zone where in the past the confidence in the Australian dollar has collapsed.

Remember the trigger for the banana republic recession and that recession we `had to have'? It was a current account deficit running at six per cent of GDP. Australians are living in this danger zone, and their future is being gambled on whether the government can achieve the asset sales it has relied on to balance this year's books. The government has brought its budget into surplus by relying on $5.35 billion worth of asset sales. So it is perhaps pertinent to ask: what is the government's record on asset sales?

Since 1990-91 the government has forecast asset sales of $8 billion. It has managed to sell only $3.8 billion worth of assets—less than half of that it had planned. Even if the government does manage to sell $5.35 billion worth of assets in one year, no progress will have been made towards increasing the pool of national savings, which was the whole point of bringing the budget into surplus. With asset sales, money will simply flow from private savings to public savings. It is ironic that the Treasurer, at the beginning of his budget speech, assured us the budget would:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . provide for the continued expansion of the Australian economy . . . it will do so by tackling the major constraint on growth: the long-term decline of our national savings.

As the Prime Minister travelled Australia hawking his 13th budget, he assured us, `It's never going to get any better. I mean, this is as good as it gets.' If this is as good as it gets, I urge the Prime Minister to take the same path he has told small businesses to take and say, `Politics is not for me.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to be able to speak in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and it is also—
—Your last chance.

—That remains to be seen. Whether it is the last occasion on which I speak or not, I certainly will not be saying anything that will give any comfort to the opposition. We have to sit here and listen to opposition members rave on, as they always do, particularly about taxation. We had the outrageous figure of $2.4 billion quoted by the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) as the increase in tax receipts. I guess the honourable member for Adelaide should think about the answer she got to her question yesterday to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean).

PARA.TAB: Although there were some minor tax rises in the budget, the reality is that most of that increase in taxation receipts for the next financial year will come from the fact that in the last two years there have been 560,000-plus new jobs created, which means that there are nearly half a million more people working in Australia than there were two years ago. If they are working that means they pay tax. I know a lot of people whose ambition it was to be able to pay tax, which meant that they wanted a job. A lot of those people now have jobs because of the policies of this government. Naturally, that means that tax receipts increase and as such revenue increases. We should all be very pleased about that. Indeed, the government is very pleased about that. So it is hardly justifiable to attack the government on increased tax revenue.

Of course, this budget has a number of positive aspects. Like all budgets, it has been widely reported, and, I guess, criticised in some areas. One of the major positive initiatives in this budget is that of superannuation. The superannuation initiatives outlined will boost national savings, as recommended by the FitzGerald report a couple of years ago. That is very important for our economy and Australia's future.Access to superannuation will be opened up for many more people. By the year 2002, most Australian workers will have access to 15 per cent superannuation—that is, a three per cent employee contribution, a three per cent government contribution and a nine per cent employer contribution. That is a major breakthrough, as superannuation is important because it provides workers with security in retirement—the sort of access that many of them did not have until this government was elected.

When this government was elected in 1983 only 40 per cent of Australian workers had access to superannuation; it is now 90 per cent. So the number of people who have access to a superannuation scheme has increased from 40 per cent to 90 per cent in 12 years because of the policies of this Labor government. There has also been an enormous increase in the number of women who now have access to superannuation. In 1983, 24 per cent of women had access and now 85 per cent have access. The number of working women who now have access to superannuation is more than three times what it was in 1983. Only Labor could have done that. We have been able to do that because of our commitment to social justice, our commitment to working people and our commitment to economic efficiency.

Clearly, it is desirable to increase national savings and to provide for people through superannuation schemes so that those people are not reliant on the age pension system. With an ageing population, it is very important for working people to have access to superannuation funds, through the schemes to be introduced by this government, when they retire, so that they are not an unnecessary drain on the social security system. A very important range of initiatives has been announced by this government not only in this budget but also over the last 12 years.
The $816 a year means tested maternity allowance, which is long overdue, has also been introduced, thanks to the negotiating efforts of the trade union movement.

The national childhood immunisation program is also very important. Some $11 million has been allocated to this program in the next financial year. This major program addresses health issues and provides social justice for families. We hear a lot from the opposition about families, but it is the government that actually has policies for families.

I would like to talk about the major initiative announced in the budget in relation to mental health. Over the last year I have chaired a caucus subcommittee on mental health. The federal government is taking a much more pro-active role in looking at mental health, which is an area of social policy that has traditionally been a state government responsibility. Mental health is a bit like Aboriginal health really. It has been a state government responsibility in the past, which is probably the reason why it has been a major area of neglect in respect of social policy.

Now the federal government, through the national mental health strategy, is taking a more pro-active role. In last year's budget the government provided about $260-odd million over the next four years. Some of that money has been allocated to state governments while some has been allocated to national programs in order to improve our mental health services. In this year's budget, funding of $13 million has been allocated over the next four years for youth suicide programs. That comprises $7 million in additional funding and the other $6 million will be earmarked from existing funding under the national mental health strategy. That will come from the money that was announced last year. The funds will be used to trial a number of strategies to specifically address the needs of young people in high risk groups. This includes those people who have previously attempted suicide; young people in rural and remote areas; people with a mental illness; and young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

These initiatives are likely to include pilot programs with GPs to increase their awareness about youth suicide and to enhance their capacity to deal with these issues, including preventing copycat attempts at suicide. Also, there will be incentive funding to establish and trial follow-up programs for young people who have attempted suicide; piloting of suicide awareness programs as proposed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities; further training and support of health professionals who come into contact with vulnerable young people and their families; and developing, collecting and publishing of data to increase knowledge and understanding of the risk factors associated with youth suicide.

The importance of reducing suicide rates was recognised by the Australian health ministers in the development of national health goals and targets. In 1994 those ministers endorsed a goal for reducing rates. Reports show that young men are six times more likely to commit suicide than young women. When there are anomalies and imbalances in statistics, as we often hear, there is clearly a problem which governments need to address. I believe that we are going some way to doing that in this initiative that was announced in the budget.

Another important initiative which was announced in the budget, particularly for my electorate, was an increase in funding for the development of Badgerys Creek airport, or Sydney West airport as some people call it. Some $762 million will be allocated over the next three or four years to accelerate—I will not use the term `fast-track'—the development of Sydney West airport. Obviously, this has been a very topical issue in the last six months because of the concern about aircraft noise in inner Sydney as a result of the third runway.

I am on the public record a number of times as saying that I am one of a number of people in the Labor Party and certainly from New South Wales who has never supported the third runway. We lost that debate back in 1989 when the government decided to build the third runway instead of taking a decision at that time to go ahead with the second Sydney airport. As it has turned out, the need for that second Sydney airport is clear. The government has now decided that we will have a second Sydney airport by 1999, despite the fact that we now also have a third runway at Kingsford Smith.

There are a number of problems of which the government needs to be aware—I am sure the government is aware of them—in relation to Badgerys Creek airport, or Sydney West airport. The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) was at pains to point out that, in developing Sydney West airport, we need to ensure that we do not repeat the mistakes of Kingsford Smith. If there is one issue in my electorate that has engendered a lot of concern and excitement lately, it is the prospect of the same sort of aircraft noise in western Sydney and in parts of the electorate, as there has been, around Marrickville, Leichhardt and Drummoyne in the inner city.

The government does not want this level of aircraft noise—nobody wants it—but we have to deal with it. We have to provide answers to the communities, certainly to those in the northern part of my electorate—from Hoxton Park to Warragamba and Silverdale, down to Theresa Park and even parts of Camden and Narellan. These people are genuinely concerned.

The Liberal Party ran a very effective scare campaign in parts of that region in the lead-up to the state election. It did not work that well for the Liberal Party because Labor won the electorate of Badgerys Creek at the state election. Funnily enough, we also won Gladesville, which is under the flight path of Kingsford Smith airport. I am not sure what that says about the politics of aircraft noise in Sydney.

Nevertheless, it is a serious issue and an issue which has raised a lot of concern in the community in my electorate. We are going to have a second Sydney airport. I have always supported the need for a second Sydney airport and the need to get on with Badgerys Creek, which was first announced in 1985—10 years ago. I still support the concept of a second Sydney airport, but we have to make sure that we do not repeat the mistakes of the inner city and have the chaos of the aircraft noise. We need to have some answers from the authorities on where the flight paths will be and what the contours will be. There will be a review of the 1985 EIS. By the end of this year, the residents around the areas that I mentioned will hopefully have a lot more answers on how they will be affected.

It is very hard to convince people in rural or semi-rural areas that they will be okay and will not be affected badly when, at the moment, they do not have noise from anything. They do not have any aircraft noise. They do not have trains or many cars driving around. They can actually talk to their neighbours 200 metres away because it is so quiet. They are obviously concerned about any prospect of aircraft noise, even if it is not in the 20, 30 or 40 ANEF category. We have to overcome that problem.

I am sure the opposition will try to play up that problem, as it already has done. I know the Liberal candidates from areas around my electorate have been trying to beat up the prospect of major aircraft noise problems. I guess it is up to the government and the department, through the various studies and through providing answers to those questions, to allay those fears. It is a very real concern for the people of western and south-west Sydney. Although I have always supported the need for the second airport, we need to make sure that it is not at the expense of the quality of life for the people in those communities.

The other area that I want to talk about is the opposition's obsession with tax increases—and I have mentioned that. There were some minor tax increases in the budget, as there should be. We often hear from the opposition that the government is dishonest and is a high taxing government. That is nonsense. We are one of the lowest taxed countries in the OECD. Figures show that our taxation rates are the second lowest to Turkey in the OECD countries. There is a good case to argue that we should be paying a lot more tax, particularly those people on higher incomes.

I know that the Western Australian Liberal Party believes that Western Australian business people should pay no tax at all. That was well documented in the early 1980s when the powerbroker over there tore strips off the then federal Treasurer and now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) because he was too hard on tax avoidance in Western Australia. We all know the history of that. We had the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, which assisted a lot of people associated with the Liberal Party in Western Australia. When I lived in Western Australia, the Liberal Party had a campaign slogan in the 1970s which was `Taxation is theft'. Let us not forget that.

Let us knock on the head this hypocrisy about taxation. We are the second lowest taxed country in the OECD world. I do not know where people expect governments to get revenue from if it is not from companies and the better off in the community. I certainly support the rise in company tax because I think we all have to pay our fair share, especially those in the community who are better able to do so. The government has very important social justice programs to implement, including those on access to superannuation, mental health, Aboriginal health and youth suicide. We need to have a fair and equitable social security system and fair, flexible and efficient labour market programs.

The money has to come from somewhere. Liberal Party members would have us believe that we pay too much tax in this country. Perhaps if some of their rich mates paid the tax they owe instead of avoiding it through fancy tax avoidance schemes we would not have such a problem with revenue.

The taxation rises announced in the budget are fairly modest. The boost in taxation revenue which the member for Adelaide mentioned is mainly due to the fact that there are more people working. I have met a lot of people who are out of work and they have said that their ambition in life is to pay tax. They are not paying tax because they do not have a job. I think that is a very worthy ambition. The government should be very proud that at least half a million more people in the last two years have jobs and are now paying tax. That is why the government expects over $2 billion more in taxation receipts this financial year.

There is a part of the budget that is of concern to a number of people in the labour movement—that is, the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. I share some of those concerns, but not because I believe the banks are necessarily sacrosanct in terms of needing to be owned by the government. We had the debate about the nationalisation of banks in the 1940s when Ben Chifley was Prime Minister. There are still a lot of people in the labour movement who believe that we should nationalise banks. In reality, that debate was lost in the 1940s.

It is not a question of whether banks, or airlines for that matter, should be publicly or privately owned. It concerns me that in the last few years we have often had the situation where the government has decided to sell off a public asset in order to affect the bottom line in the budget. The surplus of about $700 million in this year's budget is due to the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Regardless of the debates about whether or not governments should own banks or airlines, the point is that, if we keep selling off the family silver, what happens when there is none left. How do you affect the bottom line of the budget then? That is an area of concern. I am sure most members of the government would agree with me that there are some areas of government activity that are sacrosanct; whether they relate to banks or airlines is another issue. We could have an intelligent debate about whether or not governments should own banks or airlines.

I am sure the Labor government would not go down the track of privatising all schools and hospitals. Every year when there is another item on the agenda for the sale of a government asset, my concern is what might be next. The opposition cannot take any comfort from what I am saying—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Telecom?

—I am very confident that Telecom will not be sold by the Labor government, but we have to convince the Australian people of that. However, I can tell the Australian people that the opposition would have flogged these things off years ago. The opposition is hardly in a position to score points about privatisation.

PARA.TAB: We have seen what has happened with state governments. Mr Kennett and other Liberal premiers have sold off assets. They use the Hilmer report and competition policy as excuses for doing these things. The Hilmer report talks about competition policy. Hilmer told us at a Public Accounts Committee hearing that he was not debating the issue of public ownership versus private ownership. He was talking about competition, efficiency and not having monopolies and restrictive trade practices. No argument has been put forward to suggest that because something is privately owned it makes it more efficient.

We get letters from constituents and party members that raise concerns about asset sales. The government needs to keep that in mind and we need to draw the line on some of these asset sales and ensure that there is not any danger of government owned enterprises like Telecom or the ABC being sold off. A way of ensuring that the ABC and Telecom are not sold off is to re-elect Labor at the next election. We all know what the opposition would do to those government instrumentalities if it were elected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of entering the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995, I would like to extend my congratulations to the member for Wentworth (Mr Thomson) and the member for Canberra (Mr Smyth) on the outstanding maiden speeches they made in this House. The two speeches were very different, pointing to careers of great potential as representatives of their electors and as members of the parliamentary Liberal Party. I wish them well.

PARA.TAB: I apologise to the House that I have a bout of the flu. One thing about this airconditioning system, which can be compared to the airconditioning system in old Parliament House, is that it seems to be charged with the ability to ensure a good mix of the germs in Australia. Throughout a parliamentary sitting week, 148 lots of germs gather here. Everyone gets everyone else's flu in the course of a sitting week, and I am one example of that. However, on behalf of the battlers, I battle on.

The 1995 budget will go down in the economic history books as the one where Labor formally and finally parted company with its platform not just in relation to privatisation but also in relation to social justice and equity, as this budget will increase the gap between rich and poor, which has been this Labor government's tragic hallmark since 1983.

I noted the agony and anguish of the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) with regard to that issue of privatisation. He has now lost his preselection. He has been challenged with regard to that. He has referred to such things as the spivs of the Right in the Labor Party in relation to these issues.

This is the 13th budget of the federal Labor government. It is the unlucky 13th budget of the federal Labor government. It is the last budget of the federal Labor government. It completely extinguishes for all time Labor's light on the hill. It is not as good as it gets. It may be the Labor Party's best effort in government, but it has been greeted with anger by so many sectors of the economy, by so many people out in the real world.

The sad thing is that it increases real hardship for the people beyond the big unions, the big institutions, the top end of town. The cold hard facts are that this budget increases the taxes in Australia which impact on those who are not well off. It does that in a way which, for example, sees the Medicare levy go up from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent. That levy is not taken into account with the OECD comparisons. When you add in all the levies, Australia's taxation position is pretty grim when compared with the rest of the world.

This budget increases the sales tax on cars and on building hardware. It denies income tax cuts, and they are used in the community to pay off grocery and everyday living expenses. It tampers with the diesel fuel rebate scheme. I commend members who represent mining seats to have a look at the detail of the legislation now emerging with regard to this budget and look at the crazy situations associated with retrospectivity of considerable concern, specifically for the Pilbara operators in Western Australia.

This is a Western Australian hate tax for the iron ore industries. The diesel fuel rebate, currently eligible on the Pilbara iron ore trains, is going to be revoked for the trains running in one direction. So the full trains going down will be eligible for the diesel fuel rebate but the empty trains coming back will not be eligible. So we have a new tax on exports in Western Australia, which will affect other mines in Queensland and elsewhere.

The budget papers detail that real growth in taxation revenue will increase by 10.3 per cent in 1994-95 and, on top of that, by another 9.3 per cent for the next financial year. Given the current inflation environment, that is a giant rip-off by the government. It means bigger government, more taxation and lower disposable incomes for average Australian families.
I would like to point out that the overall state of the Australian economy deserves detailed examination. In that context, let me quote what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said on 2 December 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: I say any economy that can't travel at 4 per cent without spilling over into imports should give the game away.
. . . we ought to be able to run this economy at 4 per cent at least, and will need to bring unemployment down in a sustained marked way in the long term.
Given this quote, it should be noted that the growth forecast contained in this budget is some 3 per cent each year from 1995-96 through to 1997-98, and then drifting further down after that.

PARA.TAB: The current account deficit is expected to increase from 3.9 per cent to six per cent of GDP. In short, we will have a current account deficit, according to the budget, of a whopping and continuing $27 billion. In short, we cannot sustain four per cent, let alone get four per cent, growth without spilling over into imports, sucking in imports at a rate which will affect our current account deficit and our balance of payments. This has been confirmed again by the latest growth figures.

They confirm that Labor not only is incapable of delivering the performance the Prime Minister himself boasted of but has no intention of delivering that performance. It has in fact deliberately slowed the economy in a way which is not reflecting what is happening at the coal face. It does not reflect the anecdotal evidence, the evidence of members, particularly on this side of the House, who go out and meet their small business operators every weekend. This is a very grim situation. The statistics do not point that out in any real accurate form for some reason or other, perhaps because of the lead time associated with those statistics. But, whether it is the housing and building industry, particularly in south-east Queensland which has been kneecapped by this government's policies, or indeed a lot of small business operators—even the tourism industry—1995 has been an extraordinarily tough calendar year to date.

The Prime Minister said in 1992, `What I am promising is not to put up taxes.' This budget has absolutely exposed that to be unbelievable. It is worth carrying Budget Paper No. 1 around your electorate at the moment and carrying it with you to Howard Satler's program or John Laws's program to show them the actual adjusted deficit table. You will find it right up the back. The adjusted ABS budget deficit table No. 2 1995-96 shows a deficit of $8.232 billion. There it is in black and white—the government's own figuring in the budget statement.

Embraced in this is this situation with regard to taxation. Labor said during the last federal election that the Medicare levy would not go up. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has made that assertion day in and day out. Yet there in those budget documents was that whack of a 1.4 to 1.5 per cent increase, and its impact will be on people who are least able to afford private health insurance. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) may well laugh at those people dropping out of private health insurance, but that is creating its own agony, its own dynamics. It should be of concern to the government and anyone who would like to think about the strategy for health policy in this country before it is too late.

The Treasurer (Mr Willis) said that the government would never ever sell the Commonwealth Bank. On that, the government has been proved to be totally unbelievable. Just let me remind you that, in demonstrating the total lack of credibility of the government over the sale of the Commonwealth Bank and its duplicity, the Treasurer has since told us that the major parameters of the budget were set by Anzac Day. We know, because the Treasurer has since told us that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) decided on the first day of May, well after the budget was allegedly put to bed, that the government would proceed with the sale of the remaining share of the Commonwealth Bank.

We know, because the Treasurer has since told us that the reason for the decision was that it was seen to be psychologically important to be able to say that the budget was in surplus. In other words, the selling of the balance of the Commonwealth Bank was for the sake of appearances. It had nothing to do with the structure of the budget, nothing to do with retiring debt, nothing to do with boosting national savings and nothing to do with cutting government expenditure. It was being done for the sake of appearances.

I will tell you something else: you have deserted your own constituency with the sale of the balance of the Commonwealth Bank. You heard the member for Macarthur's anger and anguish over that particular matter today. We have been honest on this side of the House. We support the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. We support the sale of Qantas and we have said so over many years, responsibly and up-front.

What is left of your constituency? You have lost the Left over woodchipping. Now you have lost your old guard Right as well. So you have lost both Left and Right as you prepare for the next federal election. You are being tackled in your branches: why did you go this extra step with the Commonwealth Bank? Martin Ferguson tried to fudge it and cover up for you and give you a bit of condolence on the matter, but you have walked away from your platform. You have walked away from your constituency. It is a correct decision, but you have used it to manufacture a surplus which is not really there—and it is not there for another reason. Yes, it is the Qantas proceeds. Yes, it is the Commonwealth Bank proceeds, if and when those floats are completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fraud.

—But there is another factor, and I thank the member for Fisher for reminding me that it was the Queenslanders who came to the rescue. The electors of the marginal seat of Hinkler have suddenly found that a $900 million loan has been pulled back from the Queensland state Treasury to get the budget falsely—that one extra mile after 12 years hard Labor—from minus $200 million to plus $700 million.

PARA.TAB: The House may not fully realise that what happened—and Treasurer Willis has publicly admitted this—is that the government pulled back a loan early from Queensland, $900 million, just in time for the budget cut-off. That does not help Australia incorporated in one sense because what does Queensland state Treasury now go and do? It has to reissue the debt at the state level. So it was a neat little book entry between mates, between the federal Labor government and Treasurer Willis and Treasurer De Lacy and the Queensland state Labor government. The Queensland electors of Hinkler and Kennedy and other key seats would like to know that they have been used in that way to produce that false surplus.

Since the election and since the budget the increasingly desperate Prime Minister has gone out on something of a mini-election campaign. He was told by his troops, `Go out and sell the budget.' He has had great difficulty selling the budget because nobody has believed him.

One particular budget measure has an enormous effect on Australia's trade and requires examination today. It is the three per cent rise in company tax, worth $320 million next financial year and nearly $1.6 billion the year after that. It is more like a large bucket than a fistful.

For some time I have been focusing attention on the loss of market share in certain key markets in Asia. There is an intellectual debate as to what extent that is significant as the nature of the economies in Asia change. But the truth is that we are losing market share. In a broad way our exports to APEC countries have doubled since 1985. The APEC import market itself has almost trebled. Our market share in APEC in that time has slipped from just over four per cent to around three per cent, an effective 25 per cent loss in market share in 10 years when we have supposedly been prioritising Asia.

Let me put it another way. If we had our 1985 share of the APEC market, we would have exported an additional $9 billion worth of Australian exports last year. That would have been a very healthy contribution to our balance of payments. I should not need to remind the House of the enormous effect that additional exports of that magnitude would have on the state of our economy overall. I maintain that the reason we have been losing that market share is simple enough—lack of true competitiveness in tax treatment, in industrial relations, in transport and across our wharves.

Okay, one little step forward is being taken this weekend. We have the One Nation train leaving Brisbane for Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. Let us put that in perspective. That represents the completion of about 20 per cent of the current national standardisation and construction rail task. It is a good step in the right direction. What we did was to standardise Kalgoorlie-Perth. What we did was to standardise Sydney-Melbourne. What we did was to standardise Adelaide-Alice Springs. What we also did was to standardise Broken Hill-Port Pirie. Come in, spinner! Four-fifths of the major standardisation task was done by coalition governments.

However, I give credit where it is due. I congratulate the government on the completion of the Melbourne-Adelaide standardisation. I hope our Prime Minister does not derail that train when he grabs that throttle on Sunday in Melbourne. I wonder whether he has a union ticket to drive that particular train for the National Rail Corporation. I gather there will be a Falcon jet down and back. But I will salute that train as it comes through Albury-Wodonga at midnight the night before, and I am pleased to see this step forward.

But I would make the point that this increase in company tax from 36 per cent to 39 per cent is, once again, hitting out at our international competitiveness. It is putting our taxation regime further out of kilter with that of Asia. It is contrary to what the Prime Minister himself said would be his objective—and that is, in broad terms, to match Asia; to put down parameters which allow our companies to effectively compete with Asia.

I say that this is not just about the company tax increase; it is about the government's failure to really address the area of industrial relations reform and to busy itself with achieving true choice on industrial relations reform—which the coalition stands for. It is pretty simple—it is the right to belong to a union and the right not to belong to a union in the workplace. I think that is not an unreasonable tenet in Australia in the 1990s.

Attaching to that, of course, is also the right for employees to own shares, to get proper pay rises, and the like. In other words, it is a far cry from the poor circumstance argued by some union leaders which saw, very significantly, in the last fortnight, a major walkout on the ACTU by the Transport Workers Union. That reflects the anger and angst in the union areas and the lack of performance of the unions to really latch on to what the agenda should be in the 1990s. I am not anti-union. I simply say that there should be that choice, that degree of spirit of Hilmer competition, if you like, by having the right to belong to a union and the right not to belong to a union in key aspects of the workplace of the Australian economy.

Let me conclude with what in many ways the Prime Minister's own summation of the budget was. We all remember it. It was when the Prime Minister said that, if small business operators could not make a go of it now, they should sell up because `This is as good as it gets.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a threat.

—That statement should be Paul Keating's political epitaph, because he is so wrong. As the member for Dawson points out, that is a disgraceful thing to say, in that small business people, farmers, tourism industry operators, shopkeepers—the great and challenging sector of the economy that generates so much employment, the small business sector people who put their life savings and family futures on the line to carry this country through the recession—have to face a dismissive, arrogant and divisive Prime Minister, who goes around the country saying, `This is as good as it gets.' This may be as good as the Labor government ever gets but it is not as good as this country ever gets. Where we are now is far from being the best in terms of where this country can be.

PARA.TAB: This budget stands condemned as the 13th and unlucky budget of the federal Labor government. It stands condemned for its shonky arrival at a contrived surplus, and it has been well exposed as the fudge-it budget. It stands condemned for its tax rises which are one particular way forward to address the Australian economic circumstance. It stands condemned as something that is not providing the basis for our true international competitiveness. It is for those reasons that the Liberal-National Party will, quite correctly, vote against those savage tax increases embraced in this budget. Bye-bye to the 13th unlucky budget, and goodbye to this federal Labor government.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Before I call the next speaker, I might remind most of those members currently sitting on my left, particularly most of the newer members, of the need to respect the forms of the House and, in particular, standing order 56.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to enter into this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and to support the government's 1995-96 fiscal program. Underpinning the bottom line of that fiscal program is a bottom line surplus figure of some $718 million.

PARA.TAB: I want to spend a little bit of time making reference to that surplus because it has been a feature of contributions from members of the Liberal and National parties to seek to attack that surplus figure. The basis of the attack they have made on that surplus relates to asset sales, the proceeds of which are included in that bottom line figure of $718 million surplus.

It is a rather strange piece of logic, not to mention economic or accounting procedure, to want to extract from the budget income derived from asset sales. I say that because the procedure adopted in this budget is exactly the same procedure adopted in budgets throughout living memory. It is certainly the same procedure adopted in the budgets the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) applied during the 1970s and early 1980s when he was Treasurer and responsible for framing the budget. It is exactly the same process.

The logic those opposite appear to adopt is that we should not include any money we receive from the sale of assets in calculating the bottom line figure. That is a fairly novel approach. I wonder whether or not those opposite would take the view that we should exclude from our expenditure items the acquisition of equipment and assets which we intend to dispose of at some point in the future. If they want to adopt the logic that we cannot include the income derived from the sale of assets, then surely it follows that we do not include the expenditure outlaid to purchase those very same assets.

The point is that the budget is effectively a statement of income and expenditure. As such, it quite properly records all of those items on which we expect to make payment and it also records the full source of income we expect to receive, from whatever source that income is derived. That is clearly set out in the budget. It was clearly set out in the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to the House when he introduced the budget to the parliament.

If those in the opposition want to adopt the view that asset sales and asset acquisition, and equipment sales and equipment acquisition, should not be included, then they might like to extract from our expenditure the estimate of some $7 billion for purchase of equipment and capital items that is also embedded in that budget. But they do not do that.

I notice that the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) is in the chamber at the moment. I was here listening to his speech yesterday when he used a bit of that contorted and twisted logic to press his political point. If the opposition wants to extract the income we are going to receive this year from those asset sales, let it take out the money we are going to spend on asset acquisitions. If you do that, you will take out about $7 billion because that is roughly the procurement budget of the Commonwealth, excluding agencies such as Telecom. Take the $7 billion out and then do your sums and see what you come up with. Most of those opposite understand that point. They just decide not to enunciate it because it happens not to serve their political purpose.

It may also be that many of those opposite do not quite understand what a surplus budget is. This is borne out by the fact that in those many years they were in government they never produced one. They have not seen a surplus budget, except for the ones this Labor government has produced.

It is a fairly startling reminder of the sloth and lackadaisical approach to the management of our economy and Australian industry that those opposite adopted. The many years they were in office were, I have to say, comparatively easy years, a period in which world economic growth was far ahead of what we have been able to experience in the world in recent years—during those boom periods following the Second World War, the 1950s and the 1960s. During that boom period when the Liberal and National parties dominated government they did not have a surplus budget—not once. Not since Robert Menzies got the idea he would form the Liberal Party did he ever get a surplus budget, nor did any of his successors.

In fact, as best the records indicate, in that period since the Second World War this represents only the fifth time there has been a surplus Commonwealth budget. It is no accident that every single one of those surplus budgets has been a Labor budget.

It may not be just mischievous intent on the part of those opposite to mislead people about the nature of the surplus. It may be an absolute absence of any understanding of what it is you need to do to produce a surplus because they never did it in what were comparatively easy economic times.

The benefit of producing a surplus budget has been seen in the short term as removing some of the pressure in the money markets on interest rates and relieving some of the pressure on inflation down the track. That is a point which, if not understood by the Liberal Party in this country, has been understood by the analysts both in our markets and abroad. It is noteworthy that, I think it was the day after the budget was delivered, the senior analyst from Moody's in New York made the following comment on an ABC radio program about the budget:

SPEECH.PARA: From our point of view, going to surplus is a good idea no matter how it is achieved.
So I think this is an appropriate policy to take under present circumstances.

Moody's, one of the chief economic analysts in the world, viewed our budget and believed, in its words, that it was `an appropriate policy to take under present circumstances'. It went further because that interview also dealt with the current account. I do not propose to dwell at length on the current account, but it is worth noting the analysis of Moody's in respect of this government's performance, particularly in this budget, in dealing with the current account. The senior analyst said:

. . . the best way to try to deal with a current account deficit is to try and reduce the Government deficit. As a result, I don't know what else you could ask the Government to do to try to deal with a current account deficit, the size of which no one, as far as I know, had really predicted a year or so ago.

There you have the assessment of the senior analyst at Moody's in New York on the key aspects of the budget. There is no doubt in my mind, nor in the minds of the great majority of my constituents in Brisbane, that the budget has enabled them to have greater security in seeking home loans and in seeking to pay off those loans.

PARA.TAB: Since the budget we have witnessed a reduction in a range of interest rate packages across virtually all the major banks. That has been a factor of this government's budget producing a surplus, which the markets understand even if the Liberal Party does not. It has also been a factor of the changing world economic situation.

We have managed to do that while at the same time maintaining very substantial economic growth. Economic growth in the year just ended has been at about 4 3/4 per cent. That is a rate of growth which most would regard as unsustainable in the long term. It is certainly a rate of growth that no other Western economy is able to match. In the budget that we are now discussing, the projection for economic growth in the year ahead is 3 3/4 per cent; a figure which, on the figures announced this week, is clearly achievable. The outcome of a 3 3/4 per cent growth rate is one that every other country in the OECD would give its right arm to achieve. There is probably only one other country in the OECD that will achieve a growth similar to ours, and that is the United States of America. Not one European economy will achieve that outcome. Certainly, Japan will not be able to achieve that sort of economic growth in the year ahead. We will and that, of course, is a slower rate of growth than we achieved in the last year.

That produces possibly the most important outcome in terms of policy, and that is more jobs. This government, through its broad range of policies but not least of all through its budget policies, has seen the development of more jobs in this country in the last two years than in any period in the post-1960s era.

At the last election, we undertook to provide an additional 500,000 jobs for Australians over the three-year period. We have exceeded that in less than two years. In less than two years we reached a target which those opposite, the Liberal and National parties, said could not be achieved. They said we could not create half a million jobs in three years; we did it in two years. By the time that three-year mark comes around, that jobs target will clearly be well beyond 500,000. Indeed, it is already well beyond that 500,000.

As a result, the unemployment rate has turned. It has now fallen to around 8.7 per cent and is continuing to fall. That is good news for Australian working people and that is good news for Australian families. Those two points alone stand out: to ensure job security and opportunity for employment for ordinary Australian men and women, and to provide some certainty about the cost of money. This ensures that the charges they have to pay in the form of interest to the bank when they want to buy a car, a house, go on a holiday or for any other reason they take out a loan are not rising. In fact, interest rates are now on a downward trend. Those two fundamentals have been put in place and are supported by this budget. In the short time since the budget came out it is clear that our policies have had a positive impact on the market.

I commend to members of the House today's Australian, which has a front-page article depicting the growth in the economy. It demonstrates exactly the point I have been making, and it does so by sectors looking over the last year. There are some tremendous success stories there. Virtually across every industry sector in Australia there has been substantial growth and in key areas of the Australian economy very good growth. It shows, for example, the manufacturing sector in Australia, a sector which languished for decades under a moribund economy which the opposition ran, now growing in the last year at seven per cent. The hospitality sector, which is very important to the tourism industry and an important industry in my home state of Queensland, is growing at 7.6 per cent.

For me the most pleasing aspect is the growth in communications services, because I think the information technology and communication industries will provide a huge backbone for the future development of the Australian economy and the wealth, quite frankly, that our children will depend upon. The communications industry grew in the last year by a massive 13.9 per cent. That growth is no accident: it is the clear result of government fiscal policies and industry policies.

I turn now to a couple of the major initiatives outlined in the budget that I think are genuine, great Labor reforms. Foremost amongst those is superannuation. Superannuation was something that only a few years ago public servants and senior executives had but no-one else enjoyed. I can recall when the trade union movement, together with the Labor government, embarked upon a program of industry superannuation in the 1980s. It was decried by those opposite and by their colleagues in the employer associations.

You have to bear in mind that this was during the period when Australia had more money circulating than most of our entrepreneurs knew what to do with. At that time, the cry from the opposition, the cry from the conservatives, was, `We can't afford superannuation for all Australians. You'll wreck business and you'll wreck the economy. We can't afford it.' Their view was, and I believe still is, that we can afford it for their mates who are the business executives, we can afford it for people who are wealthy self-employed, we can afford it for public servants and we can afford it for ourselves—it is okay for politicians to have superannuation—but the moment we want to give it to every worker in Australia they suddenly say, `No. The country can't afford it for them; we can only afford it for the privileged one-third.'

That was the position in 1986 when we as a labour movement embarked upon a process of transforming retirement incomes, providing ordinary Australians with genuine hopes for a secure financial future. We took that one step further in this parliament with our superannuation legislation when it became clear that the industrial awards were not providing the full coverage that we had hoped. Again the Liberal Party opposed it, and again it was the same approach, `It's okay for us and our mates to have superannuation, but don't give it to the ordinary workers. Not on your nelly!'

In this budget we have taken it one leap forward. In this budget the government is committed to match dollar for dollar superannuation contributions of ordinary working men and women of Australia on a very generous basis—up to three per cent of their salary. That means that, for workers earning up to about $66,000, the government will subsidise, it will put money in to top up, the contributions that individual employees are making.

That dollar for dollar subsidy will apply in full up to that three per cent of wages for people earning about 1.4 times average weekly earnings, and in today's dollars that represents about $46,000 per annum. All Australians earning $46,000 or less in today's dollar terms will see their superannuation contributions matched dollar for dollar up to three per cent. That then tapers off to cut out people whose incomes are around $66,000. That is a very generous tapered income test.

I think one of the other great reforms in this budget is the introduction of the maternity allowance—a benefit, again, to ordinary families in Australia. It will be a lump sum in today's dollars of $816 payable in one payment to all families with children born after 1 February next year. Again, that is based on a very generous income test. It will go to families earning up to $61,000—a very generous ceiling—to ensure that the great bulk of Australian families will receive an up-front financial cash benefit at a time when there are significant costs. I can attest to those significant costs as I have a seven-month-old baby at home. I fully appreciate the value that that $816 will have to many Australians when they have a new born in the house.

Another area which I believe the budget makes provision for and which is proud Labor policy is the substantial allocation of funds to improve the protection of our environment. The budget allocates over $220 million. I am delighted to say a substantial proportion of that will go to a new project: a major initiative for coastal management in Australia. It is long overdue, I must say. I think coastal management, as part of the environment debate, has tended to fall behind the high public profile of trees and some of the more graphic pictorials. I am delighted to see that this government has committed a major amount of money—in excess of $50 million—to a coastal management program to protect that important part of our environment. Again, as a Queensland member I must say it is a part of the environment greatly enjoyed by people in my electorate.

Families come out of this budget, I believe, as substantial beneficiaries of our programs. They come out with greater job security—more jobs for the unemployed and more certainty of their own position being maintained. They enjoy the knowledge that interest rates are now clearly under control and falling. They can go to work in the comfort of the knowledge that on their retirement they will have some security through the superannuation system, which Labor and only Labor has fostered in this country. Never in the history of the superannuation debate has the Liberal Party had the wit, much less the commitment, to support the superannuation reforms.

Under Labor, families and individuals will know they have financial security and certainty in retirement. They know that Medicare is being preserved, that it will maintain its universal nature and that there has been the slightest of increases. The Medicare levy will rise from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent—a 0.1 per cent increase—to ensure what is, in my view, the best health system in the world. I have mentioned the maternity allowance. A national child immunisation program and improved cervical cancer screening programs are some of the fundamentally important activities this budget supports for Australian families.

I have no doubt this budget has been well received by the Australian people. It has been well received by the bulk of the markets and the financial commentators abroad who understand the importance of the surplus we have generated. It will provide an ongoing basis for economic growth and prosperity not only for this generation but, by virtue of superannuation, for future generations. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1995-96 budget is the 13th of this Keating Labor government. It comes at a time when Australia is facing some very serious problems—most notably a forecast of a $27 billion current account deficit in this almost completed financial year and very likely marked increases in inflation combined with a wages break-out that might result in the loss of many thousands of jobs in small business, which provides 47 per cent of all jobs and which has been the fastest growing sector of the economy.

PARA.TAB: This budget includes an extra $6.1 billion in tax on wages and salary earners, an extra $2.4 billion in sales tax on everything from screws and nails to new cars and an extra $2.4 billion in company tax. This is also a budget where, tucked away on an obscure page, we find the government stating that it expects the amount of interest it pays on its debt to be up a massive 31 per cent this year to about $9.3 billion dollars—that is an extra $2 billion or so over and above last year's figure—and Australians are continuing to live with this on the international bank card far too much. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) seems to be out of touch with reality and, most importantly, he has fudged the figures in this budget with his $700 million surplus that is really an $8 billion deficit—a point I will return to later in my speech.

The Treasurer remarked that passenger motor vehicle sales are at a high level. That is not correct. New car sales in 1993-94 were 475,000 compared with 471,000 in the last full year of the federal coalition government in 1981-82 when Australia's population was only 15.1 million compared with the 17 million today. In other words, over the last 12 years our population went up by 12 per cent but sales of new cars rose by less than one per cent. Over the 11 full financial years the Labor Party has been in government, the average number of new cars sold has been only 449,000 a year, which makes the picture even worse. New car sales have actually gone backwards in Labor's time in office.

I would like to concentrate on some of the effects of this budget on the electorate of Isaacs. Isaacs is notable in that it contains an older established area in the suburbs of Mentone, Mordialloc, Chelsea and parts of Cheltenham, and a much younger area focusing on Aspendale Gardens, Carrum Downs, Cranbourne and Patterson Lakes. Cranbourne is the third fastest growing area in Australia. The first budgetary measure of concern to my constituents is the imposition of a sales tax on building joinery products. As Les Groves of the Housing Industry Association said, this tax may well raise $550 million in the 1995-96 budget, rather than the $215 million forecast by this government.

Labor says that this additional sales tax will cost new home buyers only $400. Master Builders Australia and the Housing Industry Association, however, disagree. Studies done by the two say that the cost of a typical new home will rise by $1,000. The study says:

SPEECH.PARA: The building tax is not part of a tax reform package . . . it is just a goods and services tax by stealth . . . just more tax on home buyers and the building industry.

Many home buyers in Isaacs will have signed contracts for new homes but will find that the final bill from their builders will rise. When this happens, I am worried that many of my constituents will have borrowed close to the maximum allowed by their banks, building societies or credit unions and will suddenly find themselves having to go back, cap in hand, to the financial institution asking it for an increase in their loan figures. Obtaining approval for a higher loan may in fact in some cases be difficult for these people.

PARA.TAB: This new Labor sales tax on building materials will apply on screws, nails, paint, putty, adhesives, wallpaper, ceramics, glass, floor tiles, wall tiles, taps, nozzles, handles, parquetry and joinery. So it will also affect the large number of people who undertake kitchen or bathroom renovations or who want to paint their weatherboard houses. Mr Keith Daws of Carrum Kitchens is an example of a business hit hard by Labor. Mr Daws said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . since Christmas, with interest rates having gone up, it has just died . . .

Mr Daws leased a new saw in June last year, which costs him $800 a month, and for the past two months the saw has lain idle. Mr Daws, who has run his own business for several years, wants an environment where he has some certainty, but he says that all we seem to get is short booms punctured by even longer busts.

PARA.TAB: Mr John Caratello of Robecraft Industries in Mordialloc, whose business has been established since 1968, said, `Mr Keating wants to kill the backbone of this country.' Isn't it interesting that we have not heard government members quoting from members of the community in their speeches on the budget? This is one of the areas that really does concern us. It addresses the area of small business. Mr Chris Arnold of Complete Kitchens in Cranbourne, who has a staff of 16 people, says that he wishes the industry could have been given more notice of just what the government had been proposing.

Apart from housing, another important goal of many Australians is to drive a new car. The increase in Labor's sales tax from 16 to 21 per cent on budget night and then to 22 per cent on 1 July is a cruel blow to private new car buyers. One car dealer said to me that his business has turned into a morgue since the budget. Every passenger vehicle is affected. Once the price of the vehicle is above $34,403, the remainder attracts sales tax at 45 per cent—not 22 per cent.

A major car dealer in my electorate said to me that 30 of his customers were affected by the sales tax hike announced on budget night. He said that these customers had been waiting the usual time of between four and six weeks for their new cars. Three-quarters of these car buyers were not trying to beat any rumoured budget tax increases. They were just trying to place orders in the usual way after making a decision to commit to a new car.

Mr Simon Jefferson of Jefferson Ford in Mentone said that on the Saturday after the budget he sold 11 used cars compared with his usual total of about six used cars and six new cars. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) sure knows how to reduce the sales of new cars. Of course, the price increase of $600 to $700 for a smaller car or $1,000 for a larger vehicle will feed through to potential used car buyers. Because the increase in sales tax on motor vehicles applied from budget night, dealers' customers have had to pay immediately and in most cases unexpectedly $1,000 extra on what was, say, a $28,300 new car. Dealers' phones have been running hot from disgusted customers in this invidious position. Sadly, the types of calls any business loves—that is, inquiries about new cars—have been almost non-existent.

The government's attitude to the collection of sales tax is that its interpretation of the law must be upheld. Tucked away on page 4.15 of statement No. 1 is the flagging of some amendments to the law. In the words of the government these amendments `seek to maintain the wholesale sales tax base or to restore it to where it was prior to recent court decisions'. If a taxpayer takes the Commonwealth to court and wins a case, the Labor government will not accept the umpire's decision, arrived at after careful consideration of the facts. Instead, it will just amend the laws in the future so that an exemption from sales tax for, say, metal shelving does not extend to scaffolding. It is a `heads I win, tails I win' approach.

The Prime Minister has repeatedly claimed since budget night that the small reduction in fixed loan housing rates announced on 12 May by three banks and Westpac's one-third of a percentage point reduction in its variable home rate were evidence that this budget would lead to lower interest rates. This claim is a terrific example of the fact that if you repeat a lie long enough it will be believed.

Let us not forget that the Prime Minister of this country has been responsible for three rises in interest rates on home loans since August last year, pushing up the cost of a $100,000 home by $120 a month in extra payments. The Australian Financial Review of 15 May said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Westpac, far from signalling the start of a rate slide, has merely re-established its competitiveness . . .
Calculations (of home buyers) about how much to borrow will still need to build in the risk of a sudden rate reversal . . .

The chief economist of economic forecaster BIS Shrapnel said that rates will go higher before the end of the year. He suggested that the current interest rate lull would further increase Australia's current account deficit or the amount we owe in net terms to the rest of the world. This would push up the inflation rate, ensuring further interest rate rises.

PARA.TAB: The 29 May announcement of a $2.25 billion current account deficit for April will act to keep further pressure on the dollar. So far this year, with two months to go, Australia is effectively in hock to the rest of the world for a further $21 billion, up a staggering 59 per cent on the same period last year. On 16 May Mr Ed Shann, the Director of Access Economics, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't think rates have peaked as inflation is still likely to rise further.
It is still too early to tell when the peak in rates will be—the futures market has still allowed another 12 to 18 months.

We should all remember that in a recent survey of 25 of Australia's leading economists, 22 said they believed interest rates would rise before the end of the year. That will affect home buyers, who have already been hit badly by this Labor government. In the Financial Review on 29 May, Fred Benchley said:

Recent OECD studies indicate that Australian nominal interest rates may have remained high because markets have a poor view of the credibility of Australian authorities in controlling inflation. Put simply, investors have been demanding a risk premium.

I will say it even more simply: the people who really determine the interest rates we pay do not believe the statements of the Treasurer or the Reserve Bank. Small business employs 47 per cent of Australia's work force. It is a disgrace that shortly after the budget the Prime Minister had the gall to say in Brisbane, `This is as good as it gets.' He said, `Any small business proprietors who are finding the going tough at the moment should cease business'—in other words, stop trading.

PARA.TAB: The coalition certainly does not believe that in 1995 it is as good as it can get for small business. How can the Prime Minister say that this is as good at it gets, when the government he leads has just announced sales tax increases that will hurt small businesses in the housing and construction sector? This is a government that thinks an unemployment rate of close to nine per cent is heaven; in the United States, the rate is under six per cent.

A worse example of how this government treats small business and stops honest Australians from increasing their productivity by helping us compete with the United States, Europe and Asia has been hidden away on page 11 of the Treasurer's statement. The Treasurer claimed:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years evidence has emerged of an erosion of the PAYE tax base, where individuals have attempted to move out of traditional employer/employee relationships in order to avoid tax.
Accordingly, the Government will be amending the income tax law to ensure the intended coverage of the PAYE provisions can be enforced.

We have heard this all before. All of us remember this government's attack on legitimate contractors in the building industry. The contractors' good work has kept housing prices below what they would be if employees worked from only nine to five before becoming eligible for overtime. Employees, along with their employers, are mindful of the benefits they can get from entering into contracts. Witness how former hard-core unionists in the Pilbara iron ore companies in the west deserted their union en masse and became more involved members of their companies while winning significant increases in pay and conditions.

PARA.TAB: Where is the Treasurer's evidence that the pay-as-you-earn tax base of wage and salary earners has been eroding? In the last two years, gross pay collections have risen from $43 billion to $48 billion—by over 10 per cent. In both 1992-93 and 1994-95 PAYE tax collected was equivalent to 11.2 per cent of government revenue. In 1993-94 it dipped slightly to 11 per cent, but this year—in 1995-96—it is forecast to rise to 11.7 per cent. Where is the erosion?

Contractors have a right to be treated as contractors and not as employees. The Treasurer's words in the budget mark the start of another assault by the government and the ACTU on the three-quarters of the Australian population who work in the private sector. Yet the ACTU officially represents only a quarter of all private sector employees. As a local accountant said to me, the government is attempting to dictate how a business person should set up a business. This measure will destroy hundreds of thousands of legitimate businesses from having a go.

As I said late last year when local Braeside company John Richmond Manufacturing was under siege from Bill Shorten—one of the ACTU's recruits who was going around to local businesses aggressively trying to sign up new unionists, even if the employees had no history of being in a union—what gain is there for Australian companies if they are subjected to this type of union blackmail?

If that occurs, it will be one more nail in the coffin of local manufacturing industry jobs. Allied with a whole lot of other areas in which Australia is uncompetitive—our just increased company tax of 35 per cent compares with 16.5 per cent in Hong Kong, for instance—discouraging the use of contract labour just ensures that more Australian jobs are sent overseas. With some effort they could be retained in Australia, and that is without even considering the carrot that other countries hold out to entice Australian companies such as tax free breaks, cheaper land, no payroll taxes and no taxes on bank accounts—to name just a few of the incentives. We also should not forget that between 1982-83 and 1993-94 the cost of collecting tax revenue went from 94c in every $100 to $1.22 in every $100. So the tax office has been arguably less efficient.

The sale of the Commonwealth Bank was done without any consultation with Labor's cabinet, except the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), its back bench or the Australian public. The backbenchers found out about the sale of the remainder of the Commonwealth Bank at 6.45 p.m. on budget night, when the budget papers had been long printed. At least when the Labor Party in Victoria was forced to sell the then State Bank to the Commonwealth Bank, we all had a bit of an idea beforehand that this would occur. With this 1994-95 proposed Commonwealth Bank sale, there was no forewarning except the correct prediction from the astute Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). There are some real questions that need to be answered with respect to that situation.

Because of the proximity of the Moorabbin airport to the electorate of Isaacs, many of my constituents are operators of air related businesses and their employees. The budget proposes to raise an additional $23 million in 1995-96 from the customs and excise duties on avgas and turbine fuel to pay for Civil Aviation Authority cost recovery. The duty on avgas and turbine fuel is rising 0.9c a litre as of 1 July.
