The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia rightly suggests that this is yet another subsidy from the general aviation sector to the large commercial airlines. I call upon the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) to again look at how heavily his government is taxing the general aviation sector. Has the CAA, since its reorganisation, really cut costs in the way that it should?

In the financial year almost gone, the government will have managed to sell off $55 million in assets. In the 1995-96 year, it is proposing to sell some $5.3 billion in government assets, or 90 times its sales of 1994-95. With Qantas alone having been proposed for sale in each of the last four years, and never sold, my constituents could be excused for wondering how this government could again falsely count in these possible proceeds as delivering a budget surplus? The Treasury itself said on page 7.3 of statement No. 1:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an adjusted measure (eliminating asset sales) can provide a more accurate picture of the underlying position of the budget . . .

On this basis, the Treasury department comes up with a budget deficit of $8.2 billion. This outcome, when you consider the Australian current account deficit is projected to be $27 billion this year, is disastrous.

PARA.TAB: I ask people in the community to look at what was done in Victoria during the Cain-Kirner government years when it sold off assets to balance its budget. There is certainly a colouring of that in this budget. The Cain-Kirner government was rejected by the community in Victoria, and I think this government will find the same result if it continues to run its budgetary practices in this manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor Mr G.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this House to congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on the excellent budget that he brought down on 9 May this year. This budget is an excellent one for Australia, and it is a good one for the Geelong region—the area that I represent in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Just let me comment on the unbridled pessimism of the Liberal member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson). He certainly does attack the government on a wide variety of fronts, but one particular element of his attack related to levels of taxation. I find this surprising, because in Victoria we have one of the biggest taxing state governments in the Commonwealth. If we look back through history at the performance of the Fraser-Howard government, it indeed was a big taxing Liberal government. I am quite surprised that the honourable member for Isaacs should be wallowing in pessimism, as Liberal members often do when they rise in these debates.

The budget which the Treasurer brought down in May has several key goals and objectives. It seeks to continue the strong pattern of economic growth that has been evident in the Australian economy over the last three years and to bring that growth to sustainable levels over time. The budget seeks to reduce pressures on interest rates and to sustain the very strong employment growth that we have experienced here in Australia compared to other OECD countries. The budget gives a considerable boost to national savings and it contains a plethora of measures that support Australian families. Indeed this budget will deliver strong support to Geelong working people and their families and it will deliver strong support to Geelong business.

I am particularly pleased at the budget initiatives that will further Labor's social justice agenda, in particular, the programs of support that can be accessed by people from non-English speaking backgrounds. If we look at the general budget parameters, the government has brought the budget into surplus some three years ahead of expectation. This has moderated pressure on interest rates and has sustained economic growth and patterns of low inflation that have emerged in the Australian economy, and the budget projects the Australian economy to grow by some 3 3/4 per cent in the coming year. Employment growth in the year to March 1995 came in at 4.2 per cent. The government is well ahead of its jobs target of creating 500,000 jobs in three years; we have created over 600,000 jobs in a little over two years, and that is an excellent achievement for any government in the Western world.

Let me deal specifically with the boost to national savings which is contained in this budget. Here I direct my comments to members opposite because in 1983, after years of Liberal neglect, less than 40 per cent of employees had any sort of superannuation coverage at all; today 90 per cent of employees have superannuation. The figures are even more significant when we look at the participation of women in superannuation. Back in 1983 only 24 per cent of women in the work force had access to superannuation and now it is 85 per cent.

The government has a comprehensive retirement incomes policy which is based on an age pension, which has increased significantly in real terms since Labor came to power in 1983, and on the great plank of superannuation advances which have been effected by this government. The new initiatives will lift the superannuation savings for people on average weekly earnings to a minimum of 15 per cent of their wages. I know there are many working families in the Geelong region who will benefit considerably by the extension of superannuation to them.

I am particularly pleased with the agenda for Geelong families which was announced in this budget. The government has a long and proud history of support for Australian families. We have introduced an extensive system of family support payments and we have vastly improved child care for working families.

The measures contained in this budget build upon and extend the great advances we have made as a government in delivering support for families. The budget introduces a new maternity allowance of $816 for families having babies which will be paid to women at home or women in paid employment who have children. The parenting allowance, the Working Nation initiative, will be introduced from July 1995. Some 115,000 low income earners—battlers—will receive average gains of up to $59 per week.In the health area the budget introduces a national childhood immunisation program and provides $11 million for that purpose in 1995-96. It introduces a health promotion campaign costing $18 million over three years to assist Australian families, especially young people, in the health area.

The government's record on families sits in stark contrast to the opposition's purported support for families. It is a cause for concern that the Leader of the Opposition can come to this place and indulge in a massive exercise of hypocrisy when he talks about the coalition's concern for families. This is the same Leader of the Opposition who wanted at the last election to bring in an industrial relations policy that would see the wages and salaries of low income earners in this country slashed, and families suffer as a result. This was the same Leader of the Opposition who in this place and in public life over the past 10 to 12 years has consistently opposed any wage increases for low income earners in Australia. This is the same Leader of the Opposition who brought before the Australian people at the last election a massive program of slashing government expenditure and programs directed at assisting families in this country.

We witness unbridled hypocrisy by the Leader of the Opposition when he talks about the opposition's concern and support for Australian families. This contrasts rather sharply with the measures that have been taken by Labor in power since 1983 to deliver an extensive range of programs that support Australian families and, through the industrial relations system, protect their award provisions and incomes.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the nation's economic future lies in the growth of its regions. Like yourself, I represent in this place one of the great economic regions of the Commonwealth. The economic development of those regions is well supported by the budget measures the government has put in place. The economy of regions is supported in two very specific ways. The general economic context is very favourable for the growth of regional economies. Economic growth is predicted to increase by 3 3/4 per cent. We have managed like no other government in Australia's post-war history to break the back of inflation in this country, and inflation is projected to remain low in comparative terms to our trading partners. We have seen a moderation in the level of interest rates. Industrial disputation is low and the productivity of Australian enterprises is showing considerable gains. This means that there will be sustained demand for goods and services for the businesses that exist in regional areas such as Geelong.

I am very pleased with the specific regional initiatives that are contained in this budget. The government will provide $48 million over four years to support a local government development program. We will see a continuation of the regional development program in Working Nation which has provided $150 million over four years.

A very important provision of that program is the allocations that have been made for infrastructure developments in the regions. I am particularly pleased that the government has continued the better cities program, which has been of such benefit to Geelong. The Deakin Woolstores project, the housing redevelopment at Norlane and the transport interchange in the centre of Geelong were all projects which were funded by the better cities program. We have a few more projects on the drawing board, such as the civic precinct, which will add so much to the cultural life of the Greater City of Geelong. So I am very pleased that that program was continued.

I was also heartened by the government's measures in the budget to assist textile, clothing and footwear industries with the TCF 2000 industry development strategy. The government intends to outlay some $33 million over five years, and that program is aimed at improving the competitiveness of that sector. The particular areas that the program will be aimed at addressing are: improving managerial competency and leadership within those industries; ensuring that, within TCF industries, there is a strong commitment to quality; the adoption of best practice and benchmarking; and, of course, the training needs of that particular sector.

I am pleased to report to the House that, over the last six months, there have been announced in the Geelong region some very significant investment projects that will drive the local regional economy faster and provide job security for workers in the region. Rohm & Haas has just opened a new $5 million chemical storage facility as part of a $30 million investment in Geelong. Geelong Village Cinemas is undergoing a $5 million redevelopment, which will add much to the cultural life of Geelong. The transport interchange has an investment of $16.25 million. The Commonwealth is building a manufacturing industry training centre of some $20 million. Austanners has moved to Geelong in a two-staged redevelopment, with a total investment of $16 million.

I pay tribute here to the state government and the allocation of its $15 million to Steampacket Place. The federal government has put some $10 million into the redevelopment of the Deakin Woolstores. The BHP plant in Geelong has signalled an expansion of $23 million. The HiFert company has, over recent times, initiated investments of some $10 million. There has been $10 million invested in a new Hoechst in Lara, and a

SPEECH.PARA: Cadsan investment in a wool spinning facility of over $20 million. They are sizeable investments in the regional economy and signal a very important growth for the Geelong region in the next 12 to 15 months.

PARA.TAB: I was particularly happy with the justice program that was initiated in this budget. The government's Justice Statement seeks to make justice more accessible and affordable to Australian families, and we have undertaken to spend $160 million over four years to achieve this goal.

I do not wish to canvass all of the elements of that statement, but let me just pick up on a few. The statement has a focus on relationships. It doubles the number of places available in relationship courses. It increases access to family support programs for non-English speaking background families. It provides funding for eight more family therapy centres to assist with youth mediation. It also expands financial counselling assistance to families to assist them in the management of their income.

As far as family law is concerned, we have provided $4.3 million over four years to the Family Court to resolve disputes through mediation, rather than litigation. I do not think anybody in this House would disagree with that particular initiative. We have provided $16.8 million over four years to increase the number of community based mediators. We have expanded the Family Court's counselling service by $13.5 million, and we have provided that court with more staffing and more resources to deal with its backlog.

As far as violence prevention is concerned, we are establishing handover centres for safe transfers of children. We have provided $2 million over four years to family support programs to address violence in the home. This particular package of measures will be welcomed by low income earners and people in the Geelong area. It is a very important plank of our social justice agenda.

In closing, I make reference to the government's social justice statement that it produced with the budget in 1995-96, particularly the provisions it makes for access and equity to Commonwealth programs, particularly for people from non-English speaking backgrounds. The government believes that all Australians are entitled to benefit equitably from resources managed by the government on behalf of the community. Recently, after widespread consultations with people from the non-English speaking background sector, we have committed to deliver improvements in the area of access to labour market programs in the legal area and in the area of health and human services.

Over the next three years we will work closely with people from the migrant communities to extend their access to Commonwealth programs and the equity in the delivery of those services to all Australians. As I said at the start of this contribution to the debate on the appropriation bills, this is a budget for all Australians. Particularly, it is a good budget for people in the Geelong region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you hear members of the Labor Party talking about the budget and when you listen to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis), it is hard not to feel that the party and its leaders have departed Australia into some kind of fantasy land which bears little or no relationship to the lives of families and people looking for work who are out there battling to keep themselves afloat in an appalling situation which has developed as a result of the mismanagement that the Prime Minister and his colleagues have inflicted on this country.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party of old, the party that really cared for the working people and the battlers of this country, according to its own mythology, is gone. The Labor Party of old has died. The light on the hill that Ben Chifley spoke about has gone out. This budget continues what I think can only be called the great betrayal by the Labor Party of Australian working people and battling families.

The other day the Labor caucus had its attention suddenly drawn to the disrepair of Ben Chifley's grave, but it will have to search long and hard before it finds the wherewithal to reignite the light on the hill because that has well and truly gone out and been lost.

The great betrayal has occurred because the Labor Party is today led by the great betrayer, the Prime Minister, who indulges himself with a Louis XIV lifestyle and who has recently, as we all read in the press, quadrupled his investment in a company which is still struggling to survive under the difficulties it is facing. He has quadrupled his investment in ways which most Australians would find quite astonishing and astounding. It is no wonder that this budget is a budget which is grossly out of touch with the needs of the country and fails to address those needs.

Let us look at the measure of the betrayal in the portfolios for which I have particular responsibility, those of employment and family services. The number of unemployed people in Australia today is higher than it was when the Labor Party came to power. It is higher than it was at the peak of the recession of the early 1980s. The number of people who are long-term unemployed is higher now than it was at the peak of the 1980s. The number of young people—teenagers—out of work and looking for work is higher now than it was at the peak of the last recession of the 1980s. In areas such as inner Melbourne the unemployment rate amongst teenagers today is over 70 per cent.

The Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) go around this country saying, `We have broken our election promises on the good side. We have created over 600,000 new jobs since the election and way out there in the future, in the year 2000, unemployment will be down to five per cent.' Let us subject this figure of 600,000 new jobs to a bit of scrutiny and let us put it in a proper perspective. Let us ask how many new jobs there are in Australia today compared with the number of jobs there were before the Prime Minister's recession—the recession we were never going to have and the recession in the end that we had to have. Let us compare the number of jobs today with the number of jobs that there were before that recession. Let us cut back that number of 600,000 by virtually half because in Australia today there are only 327,000 more jobs than there were—

TALK.START.PARA: —Only.

—Yes, only. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence thinks that this is a good figure. Let me just enlighten him. There have been 327,000 new jobs since July 1990, not enough new jobs to keep up with the growth in the labour force since July 1990. Before the Prime Minister's recession the unemployment rate was seven per cent. What is it in Australia today? It is 8.3 per cent. The number of jobs and the growth in the economy has not been sufficient to meet the demand from the growing labour force in this country.

PARA.TAB: That is the great achievement that the Prime Minister is bragging about around the country today, and it is no wonder that people do not believe him. It is no wonder that his credibility is at an all-time low. It does not matter what he says about the budget, it does not matter how he misrepresents the situation in the country, people have seen him long enough. They have had 13 years to make an assessment of this man and they know exactly how to assess the rhetoric that he pours out and changes according to circumstances from week to week, month to month and year to year. The government has not even yet rolled back the effects of the recession. Unemployment is still higher than it was when the recession began.

The effect of this in Australia has been absolutely devastating—and particularly on the people who used to vote for the Labor Party, particularly in the inner suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne. We have recently had the study released by two highly respected academics, Gregory and Hunter, on the huge gap which has opened up between the more well-to-do and the less well-to-do areas of Australia's great cities. And what did they say about the Prime Minister's Australia and the 13 years of Labor policy? They said:

SPEECH.PARA: We were surprised and alarmed at the extent of the changes for the worse which have occurred since the 1970s

Their study points out that a key factor in this widening gap has been what they describe as the `very poor' employment growth in the Australian economy. They say that between 1976 and 1991, adjusting for employment growth, full-time jobs fell 12 per cent. They say:
. . . the shortage of jobs—
there are over two million people out there who want more paid work according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics than they can currently find—
has not been rationed evenly throughout society . . . It is a shock
to see that in 1991, and for half of Australian neighbourhoods—
the parliamentary secretary should listen to this—
the proportion of women employed in the labour market is substantially less than in 1976.

We have heard all this talk about growing employment opportunities for women. Those opportunities have been confined to certain areas of this society, but for half of Australian neighbourhoods the proportion of women employed in the labour market is less than in 1976.

PARA.TAB: This is the great betrayal that has been taking place in this country, and the budget was the opportunity to do something, to give recognition to the financial problems that are currently being faced by small business and by the battling families out there in the real world that the Prime Minister has lost touch with. And what was his answer to these families in this situation? To raise taxes. To make life more expensive for them. To cut back their access to child care. To rip $1.2 billion out of the Working Nation programs to help the unemployed. That was his answer to them, because he was more interested in what the reaction of the financial markets might be. He had to bring down a budget that looked plausible to the financial markets, and he has totally forgotten the impact of that budget on the real lives of families.

But what was the business reaction? What was the reaction of those people who are ultimately going to have to provide the jobs? What did they have to say about the budget? The budget was panned by every major industry and business organisation in this country. What did the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry say about the budget? I read from the press release it issued on budget night:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Budget has failed to meet the benchmarks which business stated were essential requirements for sound economic management.

By pumping up taxes, by ignoring the needs of business, the government places in jeopardy the economic recovery and future employment. Business will not accept any responsibility if unemployment rises or the recovery slows. I quote from the Business Council of Australia press release:
The Business Council of Australia has expressed disappointment with the Commonwealth's 1995-96 Budget presented by the Treasurer this evening. The increased revenue measures—
that is, the higher taxes—

of $2.4 billion fall primarily on business and are a disguised attack on the present and future incomes of ordinary Australians. They will reduce the income of self-financed retirees, and the capital value and future growth of the superannuation investments of those presently in the work force.
The Business Council of Australia went on to say:
These revenue measures are also an attack on jobs. The corporate tax increase will reduce the funds companies have available for investment and job creation.

That is the reaction of those organisations and institutions in our society which have the capacity and the desire to get out there and provide opportunities for all those people whose lives have been devastated by the economic mismanagement of the last 13 years. They say there is no encouragement in this budget to provide those opportunities.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday we had the release of the national accounts. Once again we had the fantasy land rhetoric of the Treasurer saying, in words that are familiar to us from the Prime Minister's rhetoric, `These are good numbers, these are terrific accounts.' This is how out of touch this man is that he can say, `They show a slowing in the growth of the economy.' That is great news for the unemployed out there: the government has not been able to put in place policies that will enable that growth to be sustained. That is what we have been saying about its economic policies for a long time now. It does not know how to secure sustained economic growth and, because it does not know how to do that, it has not been able to give people the opportunities and the guarantee and the confidence that more and more jobs will come into existence, the jobs that they are desperately looking for.

What do these figures show? It is interesting to read in today's Age the comment of Tim Colebatch—a journalist who is not disinclined to look at the good side of figures from the point of view of the government's policies. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is just unthinkable that we could end up in another recession. But it now looks as though the brakes were slammed on too hard last year. Confidence has suffered, real activity has declined . . . and a steep fall in job growth is just around the corner.

So much for the job growth that the Prime Minister has been promoting since the election. These figures show that the trend rate of growth has slowed sharply from an annualised growth rate of 6.4 per cent in the June quarter to 2.25 per cent in the latest quarter. More than two-thirds of the growth in the economy that these figures show over the last year occurred in the six months to September. Since that time, the economy's growth rate has slowed very sharply indeed.

PARA.TAB: The figures show that business investment in new machinery fell three per cent in the March quarter, after growing 32 per cent in the previous year; that imports climbed further; and that household savings—the savings of Australia's families battling to plan for the future—fell to 2.8 per cent of disposable income. That is the lowest level on record. After 13 years under the Australian Labor Party, with unemployment higher than it was at the last recession, with programs being slashed to fund the Prime Minister's pet projects, household savings in Australia are at the lowest level on record. Yet everybody agrees that this nation needs more savings.

All the Prime Minister can offer are incredible, unbelievable promises that he says will be delivered in about 30 or 40 years time. `Look to the future' is what the government's message is today. The government says to the people, `In 20 or 30 years everything will be terrific. We've got all these great schemes in place to fix it up. Don't look at the unemployment rate now. Don't compare it with the unemployment rate a few years ago. Don't think about the 70 per cent unemployment amongst youth in inner Melbourne. Just think what the unemployment rate is going to be after the year 2000.' That is if we ever get there, because the rate of growth over the last year, pumped up by the unbridled spending of the government and the Prime Minister, is now coming to an end.

As a result of the figures that are now coming in, responsible economic commentators are flagging the possibility of another recession. That totally reinforces the warnings from every major business organisation in the country that this is a budget which is bad for employment. Nothing is more vital to the future of Australian families than sustained economic growth with many more jobs coming through than are coming through at the moment. Why are those jobs not being created? It is because this is a hobbled economy.

Small business, which would love to create jobs, cannot do so because there are chains around its ankles. Those chains are made up of links. Those links include legislation with names like `Laurie Brereton's industrial relations legislation', taxes which have enormous compliance costs, and a tonne of paperwork which lands on their desks every time small business even thinks of taking on an apprentice or a trainee.

This economy is hobbled. The overseers of these hobbled small businesses rattling along under the laws and regulations that have been put on them are the Prime Minister and his mates in the ACTU. They are keeping a very close eye on what people in small business are doing today. They do not want to see enterprise flexibility agreements that are really flexible and that will allow productivity to rise in the workplace. They do not want to see young people getting training in the numbers that are so desperately needed out there. They want to see training schemes, regulation and industrial relations systems which preserve their power, because they are there cracking the whip. They have been cracking that whip for the past 13 years, and they have made sure that this country is run according to their interests.

As we have seen, people such as the Prime Minister have got a very good lifestyle out of that kind of government. But that kind of government has got nothing whatever to do with the lives of ordinary people in this country. That is why there is this tremendous response to John Howard. Out there, people see that this man does know: he lives out there; he understands these people and these families. He is the voice and the spokesman for all those people whom the Morgan polls show as seeing that this budget is much more likely to increase unemployment than to diminish it. He is the voice of those people. And, believe me, that voice is going to be heard very loudly and clearly over the coming months because the 13 years of gross and selfish mismanagement of this country, mismanagement which has created the widening gap between rich and poor, is just about coming to an end. The sooner the Prime Minister plucks up the courage to go to an election, the better. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Horne Mr R.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech we have just heard epitomises what I shall deal with in the introduction to my own speech on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). To the people of Australia, I would say that in the immediate short term following any federal budget there is always a lot of political posturing. I sometimes make the mistake of listening to the opposition and thinking that this chamber is purely about political point scoring. After all, the government is always going to support its own proposals and the opposition will traditionally challenge them. Facts are often dispensed with, and that is why it is important to get away from the political hype and from specific areas where changes have been made, and to look at the big picture. We are afforded that opportunity some three weeks after the budget.

PARA.TAB: After all, I am sure I do not have to remind this House that the budget is a big picture strategy. It is a means of balancing activity in all sectors of the community: business, family, our youth, the environment—they all get a mention. Therefore, it is important to look at the effect of the budget on economic activity in Australia today, because this budget is a big picture policy and it is delivering. To support my argument I am going to move away from this traditionally political realm to have a look at what the papers say. Whether we in this House like newspapers or lump them, they do have the advantage of being more objective than we are. They see through our political facade.

Before I do that, I would like to quote from a booklet that was printed at the same time as the budget entitled An agenda for families. It is a statement of what this government intended to do to support families. In part, it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing helps families more than employment and security of employment, decent wages and the opportunity for training and advancement. These are the keys to family support.

Let us have a look at some of the comments in today's papers. I have chosen from a selection of papers. I will start off with the Australian, which has an article by Tom Dusevic in which he talks about the GDP figures of yesterday. He writes:

PARA.TAB: Yesterday's March quarter national accounts showed that the per capita gross domestic product—a proxy for average living standards—rose by 0.2 per cent (after inflation and in trend terms) in the first three months of the year.
During the past 12 months, per capita gross domestic product has grown 2.9 per cent in real terms and 6.5 per cent since the last federal election in March 1993.
Strong growth in employment and increases in average earnings have produced an annual 7 per cent jump in wages and salaries across the economy.
With more family members in work, household disposable incomes rose 4.4 per cent during the past year.
But the rise in incomes has not kept pace with consumer spending, which has increased by 7.1 per cent in today's dollars.
Households are spending 97.4 per cent of their after-tax earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, savings are a problem. Of course, that is one of the reasons why this government addressed the issue of superannuation with a national superannuation strategy to support wage earners, low income earners. I might remind this House that a national superannuation strategy was last proposed by the Whitlam government. As a matter of fact, Gough Whitlam called for a national superannuation scheme to be researched and, as a consequence of that call, the Hancock report was handed down.

PARA.TAB: However, it was not handed down to the Whitlam government because by the time it was completed and presented to the parliament the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the then Treasurer. What was his response? When he received the Hancock report he said, `We don't need that. Let people look after their own retirement schemes.' That is all we have from the coalition about retirement.

Let us go to the editorial comment of today's Australian. The headline says `Sustainable recovery keeps rolling'. That is the beauty of a sustainable recovery: it does keep rolling. In fact, the nation has recorded 15 consecutive quarters of growth in GDP. The headline in today's Australian Financial Review, a paper that is not known for its support of the current government, is `Economy makes a soft landing—Data confirms slowdown'. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's economic growth has subsided to a sustainable pace . . .

Surely that is the criteria by which we must measure growth in our economy. It needs to be sustainable above all. Perhaps I could refer again to the Australian of today. An article under the headline `Willis predicts sunny future with sustainable 3.7 per cent growth' states:

PARA.TAB: The slowdown reduces fears that fast growth would put too much pressure on the trade deficit and inflation and lends weight to hopes that interest rates have peaked.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sydney Morning Herald thinks that the current state of the economy is so good that there is every indication that the government will go for an election, because its headline on page 1 is `Poll plan firms as growth slows'. So I am not sure where the previous speaker got his information. He certainly did not get it from the headlines of today's papers. Perhaps he got it from somewhere else. I can also refer to yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. In the money section there is the headline `Residential market begins to stir'. The article goes on to indicate how in Sydney and New South Wales in particular residential sales of housing are growing and the prospects are looking good. I believe that those sales indicate another index of confidence in our economy. Anyone who cares to read that article will come to the same conclusion.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at what else this budget provides for families, because we have heard much in the last few days about how traditional supporters of the Australian Labor Party are threatening to leave it. There is talk of families that might be considered to be Aussie battlers. An agenda for families highlights on page II the agendas for families. Of course, something we are very proud of is the maternity allowance for women. It is equivalent to six weeks of parenting allowance, currently $816. There is $5 more a fortnight in rent assistance, $4 more a fortnight in guardian allowance, simplification of family payments and improved services, and improved child-care arrangements.

If we want to talk about the coalition's policy on child care, let us go to New South Wales, my state. We have no record of the achievements of the other side in this place, but we do have a record of achievement—or should we say non-achievement—of the same party that was formerly the New South Wales government. That was a government that refused to participate in the national child-care agreement and that robbed the parents of New South Wales of in excess of 4,000 child-care places. I am very pleased to say that that matter has been rectified by the Carr government. It means that those places that are very important for young families of today, where many are two-income families, will be made available to the families of Australia.

There have been major improvements to the superannuation scheme and I have already mentioned John Howard's attitude to a national superannuation scheme. There is funding for vocational education and training for an extra 5,850 university places. This government is very proud of the fact that today there are probably 600,000 university students. Every one of them is federally funded and none are compelled to pay an up-front fee for an undergraduate degree—they repay by HECS later on when they start earning—and we are very proud of that. Even if those students go on and do a postgraduate degree, 85 per cent of those courses are still federally funded. Students can still pay by the HECS program, when they are earning. Their parents do not have to front up with the money to allow them to attend university. That is giving the children of the ordinary Aussie battler's family the opportunity to get a university education. I can tell you that in my generation, under a coalition government, that was not the case. It was the children of the Whitlam era who were the first to experience that. This government proudly supports that tradition.

There is a comprehensive policy in this budget for indigenous health. There is increased funding for the national childhood immunisation program. Unfortunately, people believe that some of the diseases that were quite prevalent in postwar Australia have gone; they have not. Those diseases are still out there, but some parents are neglecting to have their children immunised. This budget also includes measures to reduce youth suicide. These are the positive things that this government is doing. These are the things that indicate our care for families.

We need to talk about the confidence in our economy and there are many indices of confidence. Let us look at interest rates. It is a shame that the shadow Treasurer, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), is not here, because last year it was fairly common for him to get up and ask a question about interest rates. As a matter of fact, since the beginning of the last year, he has asked a question on interest rates at question time no less than 29 times—I am not sure how many MPIs he has moved on it—but there was not a peep from him yesterday when Westpac dropped its one- to three-year fixed interest home loan rate by .55 per cent. That was the second time since this budget was implemented that banks have indicated that they are prepared to support Australian families. They are supporting the budget strategy because they know the stability that this budget has introduced into the Australian economy. The housing industry will be buoyed by this tendency in interest rates. It will mean that the people who are employed in that very responsible industry will be assured that the strength of that industry will be ongoing.
These are the supports that we give families. I refer again to the article by Tom Dusevic in today's Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: With more family members in work, household disposable incomes rose 4.4 per cent during the past year.

There is no doubt that this is a good budget. With a budget like this, you can keep talking about the good news. We have heard that the opposition has suddenly discovered the Aussie battlers. I would probably put pensioners in that category—a generation of people who were neglected by the 23 years of coalition government. They certainly did not have a superannuation policy to ensure their secure retirement.

PARA.TAB: This government is accepting the responsibility of looking after pensioners. As a matter of fact, I can assure everyone I have no complaint about pensioners. After all, why would I? A married couple of pensionable age today can earn up to $32,000 per annum. Apart from their home, they can have assets up to $347,000 if they are home owners, or up to $429,000 if they are non-home owners, and still qualify for a part pension. The lower their income, the lower their assets, the greater the amount of pension they get. But the important thing is that they do qualify for the fringe benefits, and fringe benefits, as honourable members opposite would know, probably compute to about $1,500 per person per year. Of course, the assistance to single pensioners is comparable.

This is a budget that supports families. I could go on for hours about the positive attributes of the budget, but just let me relate a few things that I will be doing this weekend. Tomorrow I will be riding on the first freight train that will be traversing our great nation on a standard gauge railway line. It leaves Brisbane this afternoon and it comes through my electorate tomorrow morning at 6.18. I will get on the train and travel to Newcastle. That is the sort of thing that this government is proud of. It has taken us 200 years to get there, but a Labor government delivered it.

On Sunday I am hosting a luncheon for environmental groups, because in this budget there was something for the environment too—$53 million. It was a Labor government that was the first to put money on the table and say, `Let's save our coastline.' Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I know that you will be very keen to participate in that program too because, after my electorate, yours is one of the most picturesque and has some of the nicest beaches in Australia.

Let us talk about job creation. I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are also very proud of something that is happening in your electorate as a result of the jobs white paper. I know that 1,000 jobs are going to be created there. My electorate, my region, is also participating in that. These are the things that this government is proud of. These are the policies that support Australian families and this is the reason that this government will be returned at the next election, whenever it is held.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned about the impact of this budget on the constituencies for which I have particular responsibility, and those are the small business community of Australia and the women of Australia. It is interesting to listen to the voice of the member for Paterson (Mr Horne) getting higher and higher as he tries to defend the indefensible, and that is what this budget is. Before I get into the main text of what I want to say today, I want to answer one or two of those comments.

PARA.TAB: The centrepiece of this government's budget this year, the superannuation scheme, is probably one of the greatest deceptions ever perpetrated on the Australian public and it is nothing more than a revenue raising exercise. Believe me, for every single dollar that employers, or employees, put into a superannuation fund, the government immediately takes out 15 per cent. It is a great revenue raising monster and it is not delivering to the people of Australia a superannuation fund that will deliver to them security and equity in their retiring years.

Every week in my electorate I have people coming into my office expressing their deep concern about the operation of superannuation. It is not the principle that we are concerned about here; it is the way in which this government is operating that fund. I suppose the thinking behind it is, first, to get as much tax in as quickly as possible to try to repair some of the damage that has been done to this country's budget and this country's economy, and, secondly, to protect its mates in the union. That is what the superannuation scheme that this government is offering up is all about.

Child care is an interesting area. We have been told that the government has a commitment to increase the facilities for child care. Yet in this budget it has taken in excess of $300,000 out of the budget for child care.

As far as the guardians allowance is concerned—and I am still addressing the issues raised by the member for Paterson—guardians were given an extra $2 a week in this budget and an extra $2.50 a week for rent assistance. But when this budget is analysed in depth it turns out to be the old pea-and-thimble trick: they have been given the princely sum of $5.50 a week extra, but it is has been taken away in the child-care facilities—and I will get on to that in a bit more detail later. These are the very people who need to access child care, but they are going to be paying more for child care. So the $5.50 they have been given on one side of the ledger is taken away on the other.

The member for Paterson also talked about the improved sales of established homes. That is something I do have considerable knowledge of, having giving 20 years of my life to it before I came into this place. It is all right to skite about improved residential sales in the established market, but what this country needs is growth and development. It is the new housing sector that, to a large extent, drives at least part of this economy and that is where the jobs will be lost. It is easy enough to roll over established homes, but what happens to our tradesmen and tradeswomen? What happens to our support industries, such as the carpet suppliers, the drapes and internal fittings suppliers, and all the other people who rely so heavily on the new housing industry to keep going? And so it goes on.

The 1995-96 budget is the government's 13th attempt to get it right. It is the 13th time that they have failed the people of Australia. It represents yet another comprehensive failure, and I endorse the remarks of my colleague the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) when he said, `This is the unlucky 13th for the government, because it will be the last budget the Keating government will have the benefit of handing down.' That is one good thing. The Australian electorate and the members on this side of the house know that this is the final budget of the Keating Labor government. There will be no further opportunities for the electorate to be deceived by the smoke and mirror tricks that have been a feature of this budget and others delivered by the Keating government.

This budget has, for all time, put paid to the government's rhetoric that Australians live in a low tax country. Based on estimates for 1995-96, individual income tax revenue has increased by 153 per cent since 1983; company tax revenue has increased by 276 per cent since 1983; sales tax revenue has increased by 240 per cent since 1983; and revenue from the fringe benefits tax has increased by 431 per cent since its inception in 1986. The total tax revenue will have increased by 165 per cent over that period of time. Perpetuating the myth of low taxes is just another illustration of this government's thinking that they can pull the wool over the Australian electorate's eyes.

The government has also taken the lazy, easy way out—that is, to lump more taxes onto the business sector. There is no commitment to reduce the horrendous waste of human and financial resources applied to conforming with taxation regulation. Millions of dollars will continue to be wasted satisfying the thirst of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for big government and imperial extravagances. This budget has targeted the productive and dynamic small business sector to be the 1995-96 budget milch cow. More than any other sector of the economy, small business will carry the can for the budget.

The budget has implemented a range of initiatives that will lead to reduced employment, investment and business growth. The Prime Minister has already revealed exactly how in touch he is with business reality when, on 11 May, he leered sarcastically at small business saying, `This is as good as it gets,' and, `If you cannot make it in this climate, then get out and get yourself a PAYE job.' This was the Prime Minister's budget marketing message to small business. It was his response to the dismay being expressed by small business owners around Australia that, again, their hopes and aspirations had been dashed by yet another horror budget.

The 1995-96 budget has imposed on small business the crippling burden of a new 12 per cent sales tax on the family home, an increase of five per cent in the rate of tax on non-luxury motor vehicles, and an increase in the company tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent. What the government has not done is to remove the burden on business created by its decision to introduce quarterly instalments of tax liability. This arrangement seriously interferes with the cash flow of many businesses.

Other crippling burdens which the budget has imposed include an increase in the FBT rate, which is due to the increased Medicare levy, and an increase in the national corporate regulation scheme fees. The government has not provided any change to the level of the provisional tax uplift factor, which also seriously impacts on small business cash flows.

The Australian Labor Party has broken the promises it made to the electorate in 1993 that there would be no new taxes. This year's budget is electoral fraud on a massive scale. Worse still, it has been perpetrated in an environment where the small business sector has borne the brunt of the budget's nasties and is experiencing an alarming downturn in activity and profitability.
The extent to which this government is out of touch with the community was revealed on 30 May this year by the Yellow Pages Index report on small business. It revealed that:

SPEECH.PARA: During the three months to April `95, sales, growth, employment, profits and investment have plummeted. Australian small businesses reported their worst quarter since 1993.
But it gets much worse, as the Yellow Pages Index goes on to reveal that:

The sharp drop was in line with expectations signalled in the February, 1995 survey and continues the significant decline in small business growth since mid 1994. Expectations for the current three months to July are flat.

The May Yellow Pages Index confirms that for small business it has been a case of five minutes of economic sunlight only. What will rub salt into the wound for small businesses is the fact that if the government was in touch with what was going on in the business community during the budget's drafting then its budget strategies are a deliberate and premeditated attack on the small business community. If, as most in the community accept, this government comprises a tired, arrogant and out-of-touch cabal, the budget was framed during a period when the small business sector was declining markedly in activity, and the government had no idea. It was not listening to the concerns which were constantly being expressed by these groups.

PARA.TAB: For the small business community, the prime ministerial odds were simple: heads I win, tales they lose. My electorate of Pearce is typical of many around this country. In my electorate there are approximately 450,000 small businesses conducting all manner of business enterprises. They are now wondering what their prospects are for the future, and for the year ahead in particular.

Those in the building industry are confronted by the government's new tax of 12 per cent on essential components used in building the family home. This will drive up the price of new homes by at least $1,000, increase the cost of extensions and renovations and further reduce activity in an already severely depressed industry. The government is obviously oblivious to the fact that the number of dwellings financed during the 12 months ending March 1995 has declined by 32.1 per cent, while building approvals for the 12-month period ending April 1995 declined by 24.3 per cent. What sort of masochist would impose a new tax on an industry exhibiting that degree of decline?

Motor vehicle dealers in my electorate are confronted with a similar scenario. Their sales are being impacted upon by hesitant consumer demand and by the government's changes to FBT. The motor vehicle industry has already absorbed the lost revenue caused by the government's changes to FBT on work related expenses. The industry also has to finance cost increases due to interest rate rises. The flow-on effects of the depreciation of the Australian dollar against the yen are also having a very significant impact on this sector of the industry.

The Prime Minister has now reversed his previous shallow action to reduce sales tax as a political ploy to match the coalition's goods and services tax proposals prior to the 1993 election. The Prime Minister needs reminding that nobody in the small business community is buying his rhetoric that the sales tax on non-luxury motor vehicles was reduced to stimulate consumer demand and now that sales activity has reacted to that stimuli he can turn off the tap. Why would he contemplate such a move when the motor vehicle industry is under major external market pressures? The Prime Minister's chart of the market action must be upside down. Again, only an out-of-touch government would countenance such an action.

The list of budget imposts that will deliver reduced profits, higher costs, lower employment and lower investment growth extends to almost all industry sections. That is bad news for most Australians because it means more job losses, more loss of opportunity and more poverty for the very people that need the assistance.

For small businesses in my electorate and around Australia, it is a case that if company tax increases do not get you then the sales tax will. If the additional compliance costs associated with changes to the PAYE remittance arrangements and the new sales tax regime do not increase your costs, the increased national corporate regulation fees will. And on it goes. For every small benefit that has been touted in this budget, there is a corresponding negative. As I said, it is the old pea and thimble trick.

As I turned the pages of the various budget documents, the depth of the deception of the Australian community became more and more obvious. Equally clear was the fact that the government has again failed to deliver on essential micro-economic reform. That is now in the too-hard basket.

There is no hiding the fact that the chickens have come home to roost for this government. The excesses of the past 13 years are now starkly revealed for all to see. Its high taxing, big spending habits, when combined with a pandering to special interest groups, have left the government floundering for opportunities to deliver the type of budget statement required to ensure that the pain of `the recession we had to have' was not had in vain.

The government has taken the easy option, the high taxing, low cost-cutting option that will result in its demise at the next election. The most unfortunate aspect to the mismanagement of this government is that so many people who were dedicated to capitalising on the opportunities available to them and to their families will be made to suffer the consequences.

It is not only in the area of small business that this budget fails. It also fails women and it fails women's families. Tax increases are a major feature of the budget, and that will impact on many women and on their families. Additional costs on health, housing and motor vehicles will place added burdens on families and on women, who in most cases have the responsibility of balancing the family budget.There are a number of initiatives that appear to offer benefits to women. But a closer examination of them reveals that they will either deliver little or they are delayed, like the cervical cancer program, where $11 million is set aside but it is not delivered until the year 1999-2000. That is the kind of trick that this government has got up to; the kind of deception of the Australian people, and women in particular. Initiatives such as in Aboriginal health, which is a clear area of Labor government's failure; child care, where funds have been reduced by $325 million; and superannuation and access to justice are just some of the examples where the government programs deliver questionable outcomes. For most of the gains women will find there is a corresponding loss.

Specifically with respect to women, other measures will have an impact on them, such as the additional cost for the development of the family home. As I mentioned, the increases given to guardians and given to sole parents for assistance with private rent payments are more than absorbed in additional costs to access child care. Those are the very people in our community who need and rely on child-care services, because they are usually the sole breadwinner as well as the sole provider for the children.

We see a 5.6 per cent drop in funding for the Office of the Status of Women. Women form more than half of our community and that office is already funded with a very small amount—I would say a pittance—yet the government has seen fit to reduce the funding to the Office of the Status of Women by nearly six per cent. And so it goes on.

The contempt that the Prime Minister displays for Australians is illustrated by his attempt to sneak through a number of budget issues which in isolation may appear relatively innocuous but when viewed in the broader context are simply further examples of deceit and deception.

The measures, which have been carefully targeted at those individuals with the least capacity to resist or avoid their impact, have been prioritised to ensure that it is ordinary Australians who suffer the most at the hands of this government and its budget.

Each one of the initiatives that I have outlined should be benchmarked against the level of funding provided in the budget last year, and again this year, to fund the Australian Trade Union Training Authority. In 1994, the Australian Trade Union Training Authority received $10 million: in fact, it was $10.1 million. The idea of handing this over was to ensure the development and national coordination of the delivery of comprehensive, high quality training and education, to assist trade unions to meet the organisational, political, economic and social challenges of the coming decade.

The hypocrisy of this government is exposed when funds for its union mates are afforded a higher priority than funding for women's preventative medical programs or funding for domestic violence programs, or the cost of heating, hot water and electric lights for many elderly—and many other—Australians.

Small business can be sure that it will receive no support from this government. The coalition will continue to support small business in its endeavours, and the coalition will also work tirelessly to expose the fraud and deception that is a key mark of this budget. Australian women and their families will also be comforted by the knowledge that the coalition will ensure that, in future, priorities will be established that will ensure that the health and safety of themselves and their families is afforded a higher priority than Labor's pandering to its union mates and to minority groups within the community.

This budget has been set for short-term political gain. This is a budget that the government is going into an election with. It is not about the long-term future of Australian people and their families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take pleasure in rising in support of Appropriation Bill (No. 1). But, in doing so, I want to first outline an area of disquiet that I have with this year's budget. Those who know me, and those who have listened to and read contributions that I have made in this place on earlier occasions, would understand that the sell-off of the remaining government owned share of the Commonwealth Bank causes me a degree of disquiet and distress.

PARA.TAB: What we have to confront is the fact that there has been a changing attitude towards public ownership. I quite understand that I am in an underwhelming minority in this place in holding those views. But I believe that, if we are going to continue down this track, it will be something that following generations—if not this generation—will live to regret. I believe that if we do not take the opportunity that confronts us in decisions that involve our divesting our government ownership of certain business enterprises and the like—if we do not take this opportunity to properly debate the role of public enterprise—we will have great misgivings in the future.

At the end of the day, we have to understand that it was through public ownership that a number of fine things were achieved throughout this nation's history. I know that those who proposed a sale such as that we have announced in the budget are not denying that fact. But I think that what they should be looking at is the potential—even now, in the 1990s, and into the future—of using government's direct involvement in ownership of enterprise to direct this nation into the future.

One of the things that we perhaps overlook is the fact that there is potential in having the government involved in certain aspects of the economy to, perhaps, ensure that the introduction of new technologies is properly directed and that new technologies are used for the public benefit.

One of my concerns at the moment is that, as we see the burgeoning increase in such areas as electronic transfers, Internet and all these things which, a couple of decades ago, were not even in people's imagination, the fact is that overwhelmingly—not only in Australia, but also internationally and globally—these facilities are in the hands of private ownership and are, therefore, directed by a very few, and not necessarily for the public good but rather for private benefit. That is of concern. It is perhaps because we have not been able to adapt current public policy to be able to ensure that we can handle the way in which some of these new technologies that will have an impact on everybody's life are introduced.

Over the past few weeks, I have had discussions with colleagues about the impact that something like Internet will have on the work of members of parliament. Some of them have tried to indicate to me that they will avoid having to know anything about it. But even some of my older colleagues will no doubt have to be involved in Internet, whether it is through their work in this place or in later life, in their retirement. One of my colleagues tried to avoid it by saying that he could not imagine it would affect him when he was fishing on the banks of the local river, but I am sure that in some way it will even touch upon the fishermen and anglers of the world.

It is the power which the people who control this technology can have over people's lives that is of concern to me. Whilst we will put in a raft of regulations and legislation to ensure that there is a framework in which these technologies should be used for the wider good, I do not believe that we can, in fact, necessarily guarantee any such thing, since it is likely to be one of those areas where there will be all sorts of devices to get around that type of control. Whether it be as a legitimate competitor or not, government owned enterprise could have an influence over the direction of the development of technologies and, importantly, over the development of information technologies, where there will be a change in emphasis in the way that the public gets access to information.

Already, this budget was a first, because it was available on budget night through the Internet network. We will continually see more and more of this type of technology being used for information transfer. While I do not know that this sort of technology is necessarily going to save acres and acres of forests because it reduces our need for paper—because that has not been our experience so far with the use of technology—it will be an important source of access to information, because it can give immediate response.

Information stored in institutions in the United States and Europe will be able to be instantaneously accessed. A constituent of mine was telling me that, during the crisis in Oklahoma City of recent times, through the use of an Internet network he was able to get access to the FBI's Internet which gave the information that it was disseminating throughout America. He was even able to get a colour print-out of the photokit descriptions of those for whom they were searching.

This is a great sea change in the way that we are able to access information, and is just one illustration of an area where we should use the same imagination as those who started the Commonwealth Bank used, when that was seen to be a necessity—or that those who started Australian Airlines, TAA and its predecessors used. Such people of imagination could see that having those enterprises controlled by government gave direction to the way that they could influence the development of this nation. We really need to look for new areas where we can perhaps expand our public ownership, and not just see this as one-way traffic, whereby we are continually divesting ourselves of involvement in such enterprises.

The important thing about the measures in these appropriation bills and the measures that were announced in the budget is that they continue to encourage growth in employment. Unemployment still remains the major concern that the government has to address. It is our responsibility as a government to ensure that all Australians share in and benefit from the recovery we are experiencing.

My electorate—being on the northern urban fringe of Melbourne; being an electorate that, in the main, relied on manufacturing industries for employment—has, of course, been one of the major areas of Australia to suffer over recent times. In the region that I represent the fruits of this recovery are being seen. But it does not mean that the people who represent areas like the northern suburbs of Melbourne do not need to be vigilant to ensure the effort required to address unemployment

I see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) at the table. He was kind enough to come to my electorate earlier this year to discuss with a number of community groups and labour market program brokers the potential that confronted us to put together packages under a wide range of programs to address the problem of unemployment. That was a very successful gathering. It led to other workshops where proposals have been worked up, and a number are off and running.

I presented certificates a couple of weeks ago at a LEAP project which had the benefit not only of giving training to some 10 or 12 young Australians but also of addressing an environmental problem in the local area by improving the local community amenity. It is these types of projects and the training aspects of them that are very important. They need to be supported; they need to be continued.

When we see headlines like we saw in the Financial Review after the budget which emphasised `Working Nation cut by $1.2bn', we have to understand why that has occurred; why a statement is made that the Working Nation package is to be slashed by more than $1.2 billion in the next four years. There is a fundamental reason. The major plank of Working Nation was that we undertook to do certain things: to enter into a job compact with categories of unemployed people, and to provide them with certain services and programs. In fact, we are ahead of the targets that were set in Working Nation. So that headline reflects the success that we have had, that the things that we put in place are working.

The other thing that needs to be emphasised is that, in an article with that type of headline, we have to wait until the second last paragraph until it acknowledges that there will be continuing increases in funding—below the levels that were announced in Working Nation, but increasing. So, in this financial year that we will complete at the end of this month, some $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion will have been spent on labour market programs post Working Nation. Next financial year it will be $2.2 billion, and the year after, $2.3 billion. Let us not take the fact underlying that headline as being any reversal in the commitment that this government has to those that Working Nation targeted. The Financial Review article concluded:
The total number of long-term unemployed people has fallen by 25 per cent over the 12 months to March 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: The government should not rest on its laurels on this. We need to continue that trend downwards. We have to also understand that the underlying thread of this budget is about continuing that type of recovery and also looking at addressing long-term problems, looking to the future to ensure that many of the measures that we put in place now are addressing problems over the long haul.

PARA.TAB: Some of the major features of the budget include additional funding for the environment of $217 million over four years. The main proposal is the coastal policy package, at $55 million. There is also $55 million allocated over four years to accelerate the national forest policy statement—a very important consideration because we have to avoid the problems we saw late last year and early this year in getting a proper forest policy into place. We had the agreement of all the states, except Tasmania, but, because we had not put our efforts behind the agreements and provided the resources, we were not getting the benefit from those agreements. It is important that those types of measures are included in this budget.

In the area of health, we have modest proposals like the national child immunisation program, costing $25 million over two years, to raise immunisation rates among children. That is a very important aspect of public policy, something that had been allowed to drift off, but now we say, `We're committed to ensuring that important things like the national immunisation program get up and running.'

The Thursday before last we had the announcement of the Justice Statement, which was foreshadowed in the budget. It involves additional expenditure of $158 million over four years. Let us look at the way that that Justice Statement was developed. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), along with their colleagues the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan), soon after the last election put in place a process to put this statement together. It took a great deal of work. It is not something that can happen overnight. It has taken the two and a bit years since the election to put it in place.

It showed a commitment to trying to address the problems in the Australian justice system, problems that needed to be addressed not just for the 1990s but right through for the future. I applaud the efforts and the commitment that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made to ensuring that that Justice Statement got up and running. Remember that there is an additional $158 million contained in this budget. That is important.

We can go to other areas in the budget such as regional policy. There is an additional $254 million for the better cities program. For my electorate, the better cities program has been a most important program. The only involvement in my electorate is in the northern end of the Plenty Road corridor where there is to be an extension of the light rail to Mill Park and the Bundoora campus of RMIT and the proposed development of excess institutional land at Janefield.

Since the announcement of the better cities program, there has been continuing work and planning on the Janefield proposal. The light rail extension is nearing completion. The importance of the light rail extension is that it gives a valuable extension to the public transport network of Melbourne, not only to the urban fringe of Melbourne but to a campus of a respected tertiary institution. The Janefield land is alongside the new terminus of the light rail and alongside the eastern and western Bundoora campuses of RMIT. The development of that land gave an opportunity for the local stakeholders to sit down and be involved in the planning. Through the efforts of the Whittlesea Family Resource Centre, which is a federally funded body, we have been able to get together agencies that will be providing services to the local area, the people from the relevant state departments and the people from the better cities unit to start having those discussions that will see appropriate planning.

That new residential development has not only the potential for proper environmental technology to be put in place, which will mean this is a subdivision that more closely represents principles of ecological sustainability, but also the potential to ensure at the planning stage important resources such as child care; student housing, as it is alongside an institution; and other things that might be involved in employment creation. At the moment we are conducting a successful series of seminars and workshops to develop under the banner of Better Cities some solutions to these things.

Even though all this is occurring we still have from those opposite a cry that we have to slash outlays. This morning the Business Council of Australia said yet again that we have to slash outlays. At the same time that those things are being said, those opposite say the level of taxation is too high. But, as my colleagues on this side of the chamber repeatedly indicate, the fact is that Australia continues to be a low taxing nation. That is important. Nobody on the opposite side has come up with any supporting data for the alternative. We have to understand those things are important to the people of Australia.

It is about time those opposite came clean with the Australian public and told them where they would make the expenditure cuts they have pre-empted. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) talks about government members jumping up and down, fulminating and frothing at the mouth in trying to get him to reveal policies. I inform him that between now and the next election I will be jumping up and down and fulminating—I might baulk at frothing at the mouth—to ensure the Australian public is properly exposed to the types of policies that those opposite might put to us at the election. It is important that opposition members outline which of the programs—they are important, as I have exemplified, to a wide range of Australian people—they would cut. Which of the programs will opposition members slash under their indicated policies? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) this afternoon I will try, as I always do whenever I speak these days, to bring this nation's attention to probably the most important thing: put simply, we belong to a vanishing race. Professor Richard Blandy, in a landmark article in the Weekend Australian some time ago, gave the figures: this time next century, in the year 2095, there will be six million Australians only. There can be no more sobering statistic than that figure.

PARA.TAB: I think the answer lies in helping genuine families in Australia and giving them a fair go. Income splitting, raising the threshold or some other attack should be made to relieve the enormous growth in the tax burden upon this particular part of the Australian community. The Parliamentary Library recently put out a publication which indicated that a single income family of a husband, wife and two children paid 38 per cent in tax, which was the amount of tax paid by a single person. That same family will now pay 67 per cent, nearly as much tax as is paid by two single people.

It seems to me that every speaker on the ALP side has given almost identical speeches. I wish some of them would listen to some of their colleagues so that we would not have to listen to the same speech over and over. It strikes me that Labor members get writing instructions from their caucus and then they all race off like a mob of lemmings and give exactly the same speech. Every one of them has said how marvellous this budget is and how wonderful the economy is going. Their illustrious leader, Placido Domingo, in fact stood in this place and said, `This is as good as it gets.'

Let us see just how good it is when it gets as good as it gets. This country enjoys not only a negative birth rate—Australians are deciding it is better not to have kids; and that has to be a sad reflection upon the nation—but also the highest juvenile suicide rate on the entire planet. Unfortunately, in the bush, where people who live outside the big cities of Australia are being whipped to pieces, the death rate through juvenile suicide is six times higher than in the cities. A very happy country to be in, Australia!

Bankruptcies for the employer class, the business class, are whipping along at about 15,000 a year—last year there were 14,179 and the year before that there were over 16,000. To put that in perspective, the year the socialists won government in Australia, there were 4,575 bankruptcies. In 1973, the year when John McEwen, whose era was much maligned era, left the stage, we had 2,274 bankruptcies.

As I have said in this place on many occasions, I have lived very close to people whose lives have been shattered and destroyed. The president of the cattlemen's union outside of Charters Towers committed suicide not so very long ago, after he shot off a lot of his cattle during a dry period and when the banks were being their usual selves in their attitudes towards people on the land.

The bankruptcies represent those who declare technical bankruptcy. I know of only two people who have taken technical bankruptcy, yet I would know of hundreds, maybe even thousands if I try really hard, of people who have gone broke. They have walked out of their shop; they have walked off their farm. They have not gone out and been able to go on the dole, take that money and spend it to buy food and clothing for their families; they have walked out with a debt upon their shoulders of $50,000, $100,000 or even $200,000 that they will carry for the rest of their days. The bank has not bothered to foreclose because it has had nothing to foreclose on—it has taken everything off them.

I do not wish—and I do not have time—to go into the reasons why the government has, on many occasions previously, come into this place and given the reasons that we are in the situation we are in. Any sane person who felt that he could go into interest rates in excess of 15 per cent and 16 per cent and not wipe out the business and enterprise classes of Australia would have had rocks in his head; alternatively, he simply did not care.

All of those people sitting opposite must bear upon their consciences what has happened and what is happening today in this country.
