The employer class, the enterprise class, the small business class—I am not talking about big business; all it does is work for somebody else; it does not take any risks—has been torn to pieces. Economists say that there are 20 people going broke for every one that declares technical bankruptcy, but let us just work on a figure of 10. Nearly one million Australian families have lost everything in the last five years. Over 800,000—even if you use the figure of only 10 people going broke for every one person that declares technical bankruptcy—business families in Australia have been destroyed.

Last quarter the bankruptcy figures were higher than the quarter before and were higher than the similar quarter last year. So bankruptcies are on the rise. They are not on the decline; they are on the rise. That is what is happening to the business class—the boys who have gone out there into the hard, cold world and had a go. Many of the people who have not yet done that intend to—the employee class.

Between the June quarter in 1984—I am not blaming this government for what took place before 1984; I think 1983 really belonged to the last government—and the June quarter in 1994 the CPI figures rose 70 per cent. Average weekly earnings between the June quarter in 1984 and the June quarter in 1994 rose 62.9 per cent. So the average employee in Australia was 7.1 per cent worse off. That might not seem like a really big figure—I will say a few words about this later—but this government makes everything look good by borrowing huge amounts of money and then dumping them into the Australian economy.

Over the last 3 1/2 years the government has effectively borrowed $60,000 million and dumped it into the Australian economy. Retail sales have gone up; motor car sales have gone up; and unemployment has come down. Everything is looking good, with the exception of the current account deficit, demonstrating that with every day that passes the country gets poorer and poorer, and with the exception of the burgeoning interest rate debt that we are leaving future Australians. Our average interest payable has grown dramatically from under $4,000 million two years ago to over $9,000 million, as projected in this year's budget. I leave it to the imagination of people in this place as to what will happen if the debt keeps burgeoning at that rate.

Let me return to taxation. Taxation has to be increased to compensate for the fact that the government is borrowing all this money. The interest payable by the federal government has leapt from about $3,500 million to nearly $9,500 million. As someone has to pay for it, we have put interest rates up. As we have to bring the unemployment figures down, we have created all sorts of artificial mechanisms. In fact, the government has a veritable plethora of artificial mechanisms that are designed to reduce the unemployment levels. Some of them are socially acceptable and some of them are socially deplorable. They have had the effect of lowering the unemployment rate, but they have cost money.

Taxation in Australia has increased from $52,000 million a year in 1983 to $151,000 million a year in this year's budget. That is an increase in taxation of 290.4 per cent. This is against a rise in the CPI of around 70 to 80 per cent in the same period. So there has been a massive increase in taxation of the Australian people. A lot of it is hidden away. Telecom is suddenly being taxed. All of the government instrumentalities are being taxed. One has to look at Hilmer and say, `Is this simply a clever device so that even more enterprises throughout Australia can be taxed to the hilt in the same way as we suddenly started taxing Telecom?' I wonder whether we can figure out a way to tax the ABC.

That increase in taxation has taken out of the pockets of the average Australian 15.8 per cent of his disposable income. Unless he is on the social wage—a person who is earning a wage is not by definition in receipt of the social wage unless he is on an extraordinarily low income; that is, in the bottom five per cent—the wage earner in Australia has lost 15.8 per cent of his disposable income in the life of this ALP government. He has lost 7.1 per cent of his purchasing power because the CPI has run just a little bit ahead of average weekly earnings.

I do not have time to read articles from the Australian and the Financial Review demonstrating that the number of poor people in Australia who are in the lower wage brackets has burgeoned and exploded whilst the number of people who are rich has got smaller and those who are rich have got incredibly wealthier. I do not have time to take that into account. Those two figures add up to a decline in disposable income of 22.9 per cent.

Many of my friends who are just ordinary Australians say to me, `I can't afford to buy a new car.' I say to them, `Of course you can't. You're nearly 25 per cent worse off now than you were 10 years ago.' That is if you are lucky enough to have a job. But there are nearly a million Australians who are not lucky enough to have a job. If we exclude the last two years of the Malcolm Fraser era when we had a great drought—and I think we can say that drought was the worst one in Australian history, not the present one—only 7 1/2 per cent of the Australian work force were unemployed during the coalition's time in government. In the much maligned days when John McEwen retired from the scene, this country's unemployment rate was 1.8 per cent.

We now have an unemployment figure of 8 1/2 per cent, and the government skites about this. The book co-written by Mr Quiggan and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), a man of considerable courage and integrity, says that when the official unemployment figures show unemployment is 10 1/2 per cent, in actual fact the real figure will be 16 1/2 per cent. Now that unemployment is down to 8 1/2 per cent, I think our real unemployment figure is 14 1/2 per cent. They are not my words; they are the words of a Labor member of parliament. The government has this incredible definition that, if a person works for one hour, he or she is regarded as being employed, not unemployed.

Employees have lost 22.9 per cent of their disposable income since the Labor government has been in power. At least three-quarters of the hapless people who do not have a job can thank the socialists for their position, because they would have had a job if the situation before the Labor government came to power prevailed. Employers can look forward to bankruptcy—one in three businesses in Australia will go bankrupt—and the utter destruction of everything they have worked for in their entire life.

The root cause of all this is the fact that this country's economy is not growing, although it is growing in an artificial sense—as Mr Keynes so wonderfully put it. In a depression, it is good to pay one group of people to dig a hole and another group or people to fill that hole in. That is what this government has done. It has not dug a hole that will contain water which we can use to irrigate and make the Australian economic cake bigger. It has not done that. That would be a bit too clever for a socialist to understand.

The root cause of the problem comes from the fact that the real economic cake is not performing. We have the artificial economic cake which was created by borrowing $60,000 million over 3 1/2 years and then dumping it into the economy. It was also created by taxing people huge amounts of money and then using it to create artificially inflated retail prices—using the blunt instrument of interest rates to smash down the growth of imports. I do not know how the government expects to do anything else except increase our imports, because most of Australian industry has been closed down while the Labor government has been in power. There have been 500,000 employees lost from the textile, clothing and footwear industries alone.

The answers lie with the Australian dollar. Everything that I have ever read in my entire life says that, when a country has a dreadful balance of payments problem, it should lower its dollar or prevent imports from coming into the country. When Japan had a problem with oil prices some years ago, it crudely stopped imports. Beef was one of those imports.

Let us be a bit more sophisticated than that. We need to simply do something about the value of the Australian dollar. When the Australian dollar was allowed to free float in 1986, it dropped to 59c. We owed only $70,000 million then. We now owe close to $200,000 million. Things would be different if the dollar were allowed to free float instead of being propped up through buying from the Reserve Bank and artificially high interest rates. The last time I looked in the Far Eastern Economic Review, which is the best journal to look at, Australian interest rates for businesses were 10.5 per cent, United States rates were six per cent and Japan's rates varied, with the average being 3.6 per cent. So our trading partners are on six per cent and 3.6 per cent.

Let us take 6.3 per cent as being a reasonable figure for interest rates. We are almost twice that figure. If interest rates are brought down, obviously the value of the dollar will come down. This would mean that it would be enormously expensive for Australians to buy imported items and they would be forced to buy Australian products, which would stimulate growth in industry in Australia. I am not asking for tariffs to be imposed. I am not asking for Australia to have the protective walls that every other country in the world enjoys at the moment because the GATT arrangements have not been introduced. When the protection that exists already is tariffied then those countries will be in a happy position.

Many community projects need fast tracking—ethanol, Weipa, Century Zinc, Shelbourne Bay, the Duchess phosphate deposit and the cattle industry. I will not go into how and why. Some $750,000 million worth of projects has been held up. I praise the Prime Minister for his brief period of enlightenment which lasted about four months—enough for us to get the Macarthur River project on stream. That project is taking place at one of the bigger mines in Australia. We will never know why, when this was the first time he ever did anything right, he stopped it four months later. Presumably he was scared of the Greens or the Aboriginal industry—I emphasise that I do not mean people of Aboriginal descent with whom I am friendly.

There are numerous water schemes—the Bradfield scheme, the Kimberley Pipeline, the Daly and Clarence Rivers diversions—which will bring in $5,300 million each year into the Australian economy. Some people have said that they do not work, but that has been said about the Ord River project. That project cost $64 million and it is projected that, over the next two years, it will bring in $75 million every year—for the cost of a lousy $64 million which, even in today's terms, would be no more than $70 million. So the Ord River project will pay for itself every year. That has been the great argument as to why we should not continue with these sorts of schemes.

The Snowy Mountains project cost $4,000 million, but it brings in $2,300 million a year. The Fairbairn Dam project in Queensland was opposed by almost everybody in this place but the government brutally pushed it through—God bless it. That project cost $39 million and it brings in $65 million by way of cotton production and the sale of water to mines in the surrounding areas. If we took an aggressive marketing policy on wool we would earn an extra $2,500 million in the economy. With petrol it would be $5,000 million. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick Mr H.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be given the opportunity to speak in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I can assure the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) that this is my speech, my thoughts, and it has not been stylised by anybody else in the Labor caucus. Speakers on this bill have ranged widely in subject matter, as is the usual custom. One thing is common to those opposite: the constant harping on the negative aspects—the gloom and doom as I call it. Words flow freely as if scripted—arrogance, deceit, fiddles, gimmick, swindles, smokes and mirrors, conned, fraud, duped and shonky.

PARA.TAB: From those opposite percentages fall like winter snow in Tasmania. They appear ad nauseam in speeches. In percentage terms, increases or decreases are made to appear as having absolutely disastrous effects on the Australian constituents whom we represent in this House.

In all honesty, we will never see the time when a government can introduce a budget where all interest groups are happy with the decisions taken on their behalf. I well remember getting quite upset about the 1993 budget—my first in this House—over three budget decisions and the furore that erupted over that. I am annoyed by assertions from those opposite that we are cheating on the average Australian family. That seems to be the main tenor of their arguments. In my humble opinion, this is pure political rhetoric, designed for the media in an attempt to deliver what most of those opposite want their constituents to hear.

Despite what has been said by those opposite, this is a good news budget. There are some nasties, but in overall terms it is a good news budget. Like the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), I too wish to quote from the budget speech made by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) regarding what he said are some of the key things in this 1995 budget. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget that I deliver tonight has one principal objective: to provide for the continued expansion of the Australian economy.
It will enable the continuation of substantial employment growth, falling unemployment and rising living standards, while reducing pressure on interest rates, inflation and the current account.

With those objectives as the guiding principles, I fail to see how we can fail the battlers in Australian society. The battlers and all the other constituents in my electorate are being well looked after by this government.

PARA.TAB: In the time allocated to me today, I wish to concentrate on three specific areas in the budget because time does not permit me to speak on the whole range of budget matters. The three areas I want to concentrate on are: employment, education and training; human services and health; and justice. Nowhere has the commitment to battlers been more evident in these areas than by this Labor government.

Those opposite can rightly accuse us about the percentage rise in the Medicare levy, in some household building supplies and in business taxes, but that is where it stops. On the matters that I am going to talk about today, those opposite appear to be very quiet. It is true that we hear the occasional outburst regarding unemployment figures, or employment figures, where they accuse us that we are merely shifting and manipulating the figures. The previous speaker, the member for Kennedy, alluded to that fact.

If those opposite ever left their electorate offices and entered the real world, they would see signs of growth that should, and would, warm their Liberal and country party souls. As a backbencher, I cannot believe that the growth in employment of over 300,000 jobs in the last 12 months—a huge proportion of which has gone to the long-term unemployed—has not impacted on seats held by those opposite. I cannot believe it is happening in all the Labor seats and not in theirs.

This budget's commitment to the Working Nation program of $2.2 billion in 1995-96, rising to $2.3 billion in 1996-97, will surely address most, if not all, of the concerns of those who are now being classed as the battlers in Australian society. Strategies in place, and those proposed by this budget, will deliver both jobs and savings through an improvement in the economy and a more effective delivery of labour market programs.

Key reforms which have produced the savings include the individual focus on case management, which has achieved more cost effective results which are long overdue; efficiencies from competitive tendering for labour market program provision; and a higher level of early exits from course placements as jobs become available. If these are evidenced in my electorate, surely they are replicated in every other electorate in Australia. This is not just a load of parliamentary rhetoric; it is really happening.

I was privileged this week to launch a new employment project in Tasmania, whose goal is to find jobs for 650 Tasmanians. That is a huge number considering our small population base. The Beacon employment challenge, part of the Beacon Foundation, has won the largest case management contract for a non-government employment agency in Tasmania. It has won the tender to find work for 650 Tasmanians, which includes 350 young people. The organisation has the support of major employers and industry groups. Through individualised case management and widespread support throughout the community, that organisation and I are totally convinced that the target will be met, which is a positive sign.

There are other examples in my electorate of similar things happening—cooperation between local councils, training centres, state government departments, although they may be Liberal controlled, and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Industries are expanding and seeking more skilled workers and apprentices. As I say, positive things are happening in Franklin, but you would not know it by listening to those opposite.
In today's Tasmanian Mercury we see evidence of more positive news. One headline states:

SPEECH.PARA: Incat `bigger than Texas' says Clifford
The article states:
Tasmanian shipbuilder Incat will expand locally, interstate and overseas to cater for a growing world demand for fast ferries.

PARA.TAB: Incat wants to expand its Tasmanian workforce—

SPEECH.PARA: of 652 workers—
and double its apprentice intake to 250.

PARA.TAB: It also is negotiating to have its catamarans built in Spain, Italy and Norway and at shipyards in Western Australia, South Australia and Queensland.
Incat managing director Robert Clifford said yesterday the current level of production at Incat was sufficient to meet only about one third of the potential demand.
"We will be expanding here as fast as we can, but there are restrictions on what we can do here because there are no tradesmen; we've advertised across Australia and they don't exist," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: The article says later on that they will need 10 or 15 boats in Europe very quickly. Whom does Mr Clifford go to when it comes to training? The federal government, through its various training programs.

PARA.TAB: Other great initiatives in this area worthy of mention, brief though it will be, are: a $16.5 billion allocation for the higher education sector over the next triennium. This will provide an additional 1,950 places in 1996, a further 2,300 in the following year and a further 1,600 in 1998. There will be an allocation of $70 million in funding for Australia's vocational education and training schemes, which is a key factor in providing the link between schools, TAFE colleges and the work force. There is an allocation for a further $23.8 million in 1996 towards the implementation of the Australian vocational training system. Those who know the AVTS will know that it provides a wide range of education and training pathways to those entering the work force and leads to the attainment of nationally recognised competency levels—something that Mr Clifford is looking forward to. He said:
"There is a screaming need for training more apprentices, and our best employees are the ones we started training two or three years ago; it's paying off now."

SPEECH.PARA: So it is not all doom and gloom. There are positive things. There will also be a $34 million allocation in increased support for quality schooling and national equity programs. How can members opposite stand there and have the gall to say we are ignoring families and that the battlers out there in the Australian community are not getting a fair go when these things, through the Department of Employment, Education and Training, are being set in place, are operating and are successful? As I said, if it is happening in little Tasmania—`little' compared to the rest of Australia—and there are positive outlooks and positive things are happening, why is it not happening around the rest of Australia or are we all hiding our light behind a bushel, claiming doom and gloom and contemplating our navel?

PARA.TAB: The second portfolio I would like to concentrate on briefly today is the human services and health portfolio. Probably this department more than the Department of Employment, Education and Training has a series of budget allocations which will look after families. Total expenditure in this department will rise from $18.4 billion to $19.6 billion. What will this increase result in for our so-called battlers?

One very important program is the $18 million three-year program dedicated to finding new ways to reduce preventable disease and death, especially from tobacco. There is $24 million for a national childhood immunisation program and a $42 million national cervical screening program for women. Funding of $13 million is allocated specifically to redress the growing problem of youth suicide. There is a $4 million program involving research and education on hepatitis C. There is a huge increase of $58 million in funding to the National Health and Medical Research Council for research into breast and prostate cancer, mental health and Aboriginal health. There is an additional $56 million to improve the quality of nursing homes and hostels and to strengthen support for carers.

Yet there is this cry from the opposition that we are neglecting the battlers, that we are short-changing families. How can the opposition say that in all honesty? How can it cast this doom and gloom when these positive things are being set in train? Families must benefit and will benefit.

In the justice portfolio we see further evidence of what this government sees as its priority—assisting all families, not just the battlers. There is a statement in the justice document which says that families are a fundamental national resource; they are the lifeblood and the future of our nation. Here I would agree with the member for Kennedy. Flowing from the Justice Statement and the budget measures are numerous examples of initiatives that will assist families in a whole lot of legal and paralegal areas to deal with difficulties and disputes that might arise.

This is not just papering over the cracks; these are constructive initiatives. I would like to mention some of them. There is the doubling of the availability of relationship preparation courses to equip couples to identify problems before they become legal matters and thereby incur enormous costs not just to litigants but also to society in general and to the children of these families. There is additional funding to expand adolescent mediation and family therapy services in rural and regional areas—an area that is being neglected at the moment—and to assist more young people to resolve their problems with their families rather than leave home and take up the youth homeless allowance. These must be positive measures. There is no mention of them by the opposition.

There is also a funding proposal to provide additional funding to expand financial counselling services, enabling more people to have access to advice to help them with financial difficulties. In my electorate, which has a large broadacre public housing component, this will certainly benefit a huge number of people who are struggling to manage their finances. There is also funding to enable the expansion of family court counselling services by establishing and upgrading housing registries in regional areas of Australia. In the area of women's justice there is another group of initiatives. There is $12.3 million to establish a national network of women's legal centres to provide assistance to women in city and country areas with legal problems. There is funding to provide national access to toll-free telephone legal advice through these centres. There is the allocation of $2.4 million through the family support service to address violence in family relationships.

In the area of legal aid, a key aspect for me as a member is the fact that $13.9 million will be allocated to the Commonwealth community legal centre program to increase the number of generalist and specialist community legal services. I am lucky enough to have one of these next to my electorate office out in Bridgewater. These centres are doing a magnificent job out there in the community. If those opposite have not seen the benefit in their electorates I would advise them to go out and knock on the door and find out what they are doing. They are doing a magnificent job. Part of the justice portfolio is the government's Safe Australia strategy, which seeks for the first time to implement a national approach to crime to encompass all aspects of society: the government, business, the media, police, community groups and concerned citizens. The goal is to achieve a safer community.

In this 1995-96 budget the government has proposed a whole range of initiatives in these three portfolios areas which I have briefly addressed today. In my humble opinion, there is no doubt that the Labor government is firmly committed to ensuring that all families—irrespective of whether they live in Bellerive, Port Augusta, Rainbow or Bankstown—are catered for in all portfolio areas by a caring government. We are an inclusive government, not an exclusive one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has told us, `It's about as good as it's ever going to get.' For hundreds and thousands of mums and dads, that is a death sentence. For them, there has been no recovery. The very notion of recovery is that we have been sick, repressed and recessed. We know that this is the condition that ordinary Australian folk have been forced into by 12 miserable years of Labor oppression. We know that this is the condition that has been the result for ordinary working Australians. They have had a very good dose of Keating socialism.

PARA.TAB: For the working people of Australia, there is no recovery. The people who gave us the recession we `had to have' had a remarkable recovery. They have gone from ordinary citizens to being multi-multimillionaires—bigger and better villas, businesses and French antique clocks. In all fairness, they did not try to hide their recovery. The Prime Minister laughed when I pointed out that the aim of a free enterprise economy was for the people to be rich and for governments to be poor. Why would he not laugh? He was busy out-millionairing Bob Hawke, with a bigger and better house and a bigger and better piggery. He knew that he was strong enough to let the people know the facts. He knew he could bludgeon the system for his own purposes.

How about in my case—the Labor Party's established tax deductible campaign to spend money, to spread rumour and innuendo? As the Prime Minister and his government have prospered, they have sold off at an ever increasing rate the things that Australia has built up that should be used to retire the debt that they have created—not in order to spend the proceeds and whittle away what has been saved over the years.

Now watch again as interest is focused on the philosophy and principles that distinguish and divide the major political parties each from the other. I will again be accused of smoking a pipe, being rude to a bus driver and talking on my portable fax machine; and some pawn will be paid to be rude and run against me in my electorate. I can handle all that. But what I cannot bear, what I cannot abide, is the senseless destruction of this great country and its people. That is why I am here, that is what we fight against and that is why there will be a change of government at the next election.

The Prime Minister said, `This is as good as it's going to get.' Well, it is not good enough for my country. New Zealand and the Czech republic both started behind us and now they finish in front of us. The rules of free enterprise are as immutable as the laws of gravity—and those who breach them make our country suffer. Those rules of free enterprise tell us that our wellbeing is the sum total of our natural resources, plus our physical and mental energy, multiplied by the effectiveness of our tools. Better living standards depend upon better tools. Tools come from the savings and the savings come from profits and thrift of individuals. They are the rules of free enterprises.

Collectivism destroys small business and creates monopolies. Under a collectivist government like ours, big business may flourish, but small business is despised. Hence, the Prime Minister saying that those people in small business who struggle—because of his own socialist policies—will have to become wage earners. He said, `Go and get a PAYE job.' Why was he so keen to see small business people, using their entrepreneurial skills for their own benefit and the benefit then of the nation, become employees instead? I will tell you why. It is because he gets the tax money quicker.

The Treasurer (Mr Willis) said in his budget speech that there was going to be a crackdown on small business by the tax office, a crackdown to turn small business people into employees for the purpose of taxation. We only have to look at Budget Paper No. 2 and that splendid statement of expected revenue to see that the expectations are that the collection of PAYE tax will grow in this coming financial year from $46 billion, or $46,000 million, which is what we paid last year in PAYE tax, to $52.7 billion. That did not happen because we have had a sudden growth in the number of employees. It just has not happened. It is a direct expression of the success of the tax office's bludgeoning of small business at the behest of the government. That is how those extra collections will be received. As I said, for ordinary folks, for ordinary mums and dads and for small business people there is no recovery.

It is interesting that the person who put extra taxes on the family home, the family car, the nation's health and Australian jobs is none other than the man who told us again, `You would never have it so good'—good old Paul Keating, the man who not only tells us lies but also has now put this country at risk—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Mackellar will withdraw that comment.

—I withdraw the comment. I make the point that the man who bends the truth now is acting on his own assumptions, and that is dangerous for the nation. Just when we thought the Prime Minister could not find anything new to tax, he has managed to put a whole new tax on building materials—12 per cent on building materials that we never paid tax on before. We will now pay tax on things like taps, nails and plaster—the sorts of things are used to build the family home. Do members remember that during the last election the Prime Minister said that this government would never put on a GST? Well, we have just got one—on all the sorts of products that he said he would not put a tax on. We have got it from this Prime Minister. From the man who told us `no new taxes, read my lips' we have a brand new tax at 12 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Minister Brereton was asked the other day about the additional tax that has to be paid on the family vehicle—you know, the new car you thought you could afford. He told us there would be five per cent tax added to that. Yet Minister Brereton told us that was perfectly right. He was just restoring the tax. In other words, there was a moral right that they should charge 21 per cent tax because that is what you used to pay. But that is the way of collectivist socialist governments. You collect as much as you can by taxation and then you spend it in a way that makes the most people dependent on the government.

Have they not done well? We now have six million Australian people in receipt of one form of government handout or another. We have only eight million people in the work force. There is something fundamentally wrong with that for ordinary Australians, but that is exactly what a collectivist government wants. It wants to make people dependent on the government and not resilient and able to stand and make their own decisions.

Let us look at the way the government handled the dependent spouse rebate, for instance. Remember how that used to work? You had a dependent spouse, so the government gave back some of the taxpayers' own money. Then we had the debate about whether that money should be paid to the taxpayer or whether it should be paid directly to the dependent person. That was exactly the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member for Mackellar will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed. I formally warn the member for Cowan for his interjection.

—I ask the Prime Minister a question. Why is it that household savings have fallen precipitously to 2.6 per cent of disposable income, as revealed by the latest national accounts? Is this not about half the prediction on household savings made in the budget? What implications does it have for the government's forecasts on the current account deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the opportunity to look at the national accounts in respect of household savings, but the problem we have had in this country is that household savings have declined. They have declined, in part, because of the experience of over a decade of double digit inflation.
—It is this quarter we are talking about.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—When nominal savings were taxed, there was no way that people were going to save—to be taxed on a higher level of inflation so that their real interest rate was taxed away in that environment. As a consequence, we have seen household savings fall. I do not think the Leader of the Opposition should take too much notice of one quarter. There is only one way that we are going to add to savings, and that is of course by doing something on a long-term basis—for instance, through superannuation.

PARA.TAB: The policies which the government has put into the budget will have a truly profound impact on savings, and you can see this in respect of superannuation. By 2002 every person in the community will have had put away on their behalf 15 per cent of their income. At the moment it is five per cent. It is five per cent in 1995; it will be 15 per cent by the year 2002, only seven years away. This is going to make a very great difference in being able to make such a change.

I might just remind the Leader of the Opposition that, in 1976, the Hancock committee recommended a national comprehensive superannuation scheme. Three years later we saw his then government's response saying that it was too hard. As Treasurer he issued a press statement saying that the government had decided not to introduce the scheme of national superannuation recommended by a majority of the committee. That is the then Treasurer. Then he said:

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the Government believes that the freedom of choice individuals currently enjoy in arranging their own affairs in respect of incomes should be retained.
That is, the freedom to go on the age pension and the freedom for the high income earners to be taxed concessionally on five per cent of their income—huge tax concessions. He went on to say:

For many people already making what they feel are worthwhile investments for retirement, whether in the form of insurance savings or assets, the imposition of a compulsory contribution to a national scheme might not be welcome.

So there was no idea then about doing something about savings, even though it was clear by then that national savings had started to fall. I also remind the House that, when this government came to office in 1983, there was only 40 per cent coverage of people in superannuation. That today is 90 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Additionally, the coalition is now saying that it will cap the benefits introduced by the government in the budget. Let me tell you what this means. I have a table here from Treasury which says that, under the new co-contribution scheme introduced by the government, the benefits for employees of small employers at the end of their working life will be $461,000 but, if the SGC is frozen from March 1996, as proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, the benefit will be only $143,000. In other words, people on average weekly earnings who work for small employers would be $318,000 worse off at the end of their working lives; in other words, a 68.9 per cent reduction in the benefits coming from the government scheme in the budget. Employees of large employers would get $461,000 under the government scheme and that would reduce to $173,000 if the SGC were frozen, as per the Leader of the Opposition's proposal. So people would lose $288,000 of benefits, a reduction of 62 per cent.

The Leader of the Opposition is up here saying he believes in more savings. He said, I think on 2UE, `Conceptually, of course, we favour national savings,' but, as always, the Leader of the Opposition has trouble putting concepts into practice, as he had with the floating exchange rate, the deregulation of the financial markets and the cut in tariffs—all those things. He always believes in them conceptually. But isn't it funny that something happened on the way to the forum? John Hewson had it all in Business Review Weekly a couple of years ago. He said, `We get into the cabinet room and then some anecdote said by a National Party member in the bar the previous night would knock us over.' No wonder Mr Howard has looked like Jack Benny through half of his career. So we know that he conceptually believes in savings. The Hancock report came to him as Treasurer and he knocked it over.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the member for Goldstein!

—Now, after a Labor government has had the sensitivity and the capacity to drive through a program which started in 1985-86 with the first superannuation arrangements, then the superannuation guarantee charge in 1991 and now the change in this budget to a 15 per cent scheme, he wants to take $318,000 off people on average weekly earnings who would otherwise benefit from the government's scheme, and add to a scheme of $2 trillion in national savings.

PARA.TAB: Let the public understand that again Mr Howard is in favour conceptually of savings, but in practice is opposed to the principal savings vehicle the government and the nation can now introduce and, in the doing of it, is not only denying us a large pool of savings, but costing people on average weekly earnings at the end of their working lives $318,000. So much for the Leader of the Opposition's conceptual support for savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and refers to the national accounts released yesterday. What are the implications of the national accounts figures for the Australian economy and for Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not often quote the republicans who run the Australian Financial Review these days, but let me quote them today. In the editorial it says:

PARA.TAB: From the point of view of both business and the wider Australian community, this is encouraging news.

ANSWER.PARA: This is the national accounts. They said that because over the year GDP had slowed to a sustainable 3.7 per cent with GNE coming back to 5.5 per cent; we have the happy picture of business investment in there at 15 per cent and—wait for it—with the private consumption deflator at 2.2 per cent; the broadest measure of inflation, the non-farm GDP deflator, at 1.4 per cent; and average earnings on a national accounts survey basis at 2.2 per cent. So it is 3.7 per cent for growth, 15 per cent for business investment, 1.4 per cent for the broadest measure of inflation and 2.2 for the private consumption deflator.

PARA.TAB: Just before the 1993 election the Leader of the Opposition said Australia was about to drop into a depression. Then, when we were growing at six per cent in the year to September, the sky was falling in. The sky is falling in at six per cent growth; the sky is falling in at 3 1/2 per cent to four per cent growth. Then we were going to have a horror budget, he said. Then he said interest rates would rise, and then he said, in a piece of poll-driven cynicism, that we have had five minutes of economic sunshine. Today's Financial Review states:

ANSWER.PARA: With the national accounts for the March quarter now showing that the Australian economy is growing at a solid and possibly sustainable annual rate of 3.7 per cent, Mr Keating has potent evidence with which to attack the claims by the opposition leader, Mr Howard, that the Australian economy has slipped back into darkness after five minutes of sunshine.
Exactly. Quite right. It goes on to say:
Given the more promising interest rate move, as well as yesterday's encouraging growth figures, a strategy based largely on attacking the government's economic performance is unlikely to work.
That is dead right on three counts. The article went on to say:
There is no doubt they are good news for the federal government.
More importantly, they are good news for Australia, good news for the country. It is the worst dreams of the Liberal Party coming true: budget well received, the economy slowing back to a—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —You are giving yourselves away. The budget has been well received; the economy is slowing back to a sustainable rate; average weekly earnings, 2.2 per cent; the consumption deflator at 1.4 per cent; and growth at 3.7 per cent. For those opposite it is just too horrible for words.

PARA.TAB: Also, people are asking how come, when Mr Howard said on radio there was only five minutes of sunshine, the sun is continuing to shine. When the economy was growing at six per cent, we needed the 15+ on for the sunburn. The opposition leader said that only 18 months after he said that we were in a depression. Then the sky was going to fall in—my friend from North Sydney is laughing; my friend, it would make a cat laugh—at six per cent. At 3.7 per cent the economy is now sustainable, and those opposite are now saying that it might be slowing too much. The thing is that they have a gag for every moment.

The punch line is: what is the budget's growth forecasts for the year? Mr Speaker, you guessed it: 3.7 per cent. Yesterday's national accounts were right on line with the budget forecasts, which is good news for the country. As the Financial Review said quite tellingly about Mr Howard:

ANSWER.PARA: The line about five minutes of sunshine has slipped. From the point of view of both businesses and the wider Australian community, this is encouraging news.
Let me concur with that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer, who will be aware that the household saving ratio is at a record low, a matter about which the Prime Minister is blissfully ignorant. Treasurer, is it true, as stated by the government's own savings adviser Dr FitzGerald, that employees are likely to run down bank savings in order to pay for the government's proposed compulsory superannuation changes, leading to a switching in savings? Do you also agree with Dr FitzGerald's statement that the government should broaden savings incentives to encourage workers to retain investments in banks and shares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the national accounts show that there is a reduced level in household savings, that the household saving ratio is down to 2.6 per cent. But I think it is also worth noting what the statistician, after having noted that, had to say. He stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Caution should be exercised in interpreting this ratio in recent years because major components of household income and expenditure may still be subject to significant revisions. The impact of these revisions on the saving ratio can cause changes in the apparent direction of the trend.

So, in terms of the household saving ratio, which is a derivative outcome and, therefore, bears the impact of any errors involved in the calculations which lead towards it, we need to be cautious in putting too much weight on such numbers. Nevertheless, there is, undoubtedly, over time, in terms of the figures that we have available, a downward trend in household savings. But as the Prime Minister has been pointing out, what the government is very much about is turning that trend around.

PARA.TAB: The decisions that we have announced in the budget in relation to superannuation are, of course, an enormous step forward in improving household savings in this country, taking the superannuation contribution from the current six per cent by the employer to 15 per cent, including three per cent from the employee and the matching contribution from the government.

The shadow Treasurer referred to the fact that there could be some switching from other savings. Of course, that is true. There may well be some switching from other savings and allowance is made for that in our calculations. In the calculations that we have announced about the boost to savings coming from both the superannuation guarantee charge—that is, the employer contribution—and from the employee's own contribution and the government's matching contribution, allowance has been made for the fact that there can be a switch of some 30 per cent from other savings.

That allowance comes out of a study by Treasury as to what is an appropriate amount and that is built into the forecast of what the boost to savings will be overall. That means there is full account taken of the point raised by the shadow Treasurer. The boost to savings of some four per cent of GDP by the year 2020 coming from all of those factors and the two per cent boost to savings by early next century are significant changes in household and national savings and mean that we will be seeing a great improvement to savings performance by the nation coming from the household sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four per cent; ha, ha!

—I hear some stupid chuckling from the front bench opposite, presumably because he thinks four per cent sounds small. If the current household saving ratio is, in fact, 2.64 per cent, four per cent looks like a fairly big addition to me. Of course, that is not the only element of saving. There are other elements of saving that are reducing public sector dissaving, which is being achieved through the return to a budget surplus. Only this side of the House has produced budget surpluses. They were in the four years at the end of the 1980s when the now Prime Minister was Treasurer and we are again returning to a budget surplus for this forthcoming year, 1995-96, and for the years thereafter to 1998-99.

PARA.TAB: We are looking at a lot of years of surpluses against none ever from those opposite—not one surplus ever. In the five years that the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer there was not one surplus. In the whole of the 23 years from 1949 to 1972, there was not one surplus from the coalition government. That return to budget surplus will considerably improve national savings by eliminating public sector dissaving. That is a major boost to national saving; that is very important, indeed.

The third area of saving which is important is corporate saving. With company profits being high, corporate saving is relatively substantial. But it is the public sector dissaving which has been a major factor. That is now being eliminated and the household saving area, which has been scaling down, will be dramatically returned to positive growth by the superannuation measures that we have announced in the budget.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Industrial Relations: Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas Islands

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the minister to media reports about the threatened shortage of food supplies on Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas Islands due to the Western Australian Stateships dispute. Can the minister tell the House what steps the Commonwealth is taking to ensure the transport of supplies to Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas Islands? While I am on the subject of industrial relations coalition style, is the minister aware of reports of attempts to prevent Western Australian workers having the choice to transfer to federal awards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am most concerned about developments in the Stateships dispute, including the developments that have occurred today. The Western Australian transport minister, Mr Charlton, has a great deal of explaining to do to the voters of Western Australia as to how he has engineered this dispute in cahoots with his Western Australian cabinet colleagues.
—What about the MUA? They are the ones who are on strike.
—The member for Hume!

—Yesterday the Western Australian State Supply Commission found that there had been major breaches of supply guidelines in the Stateships tendering process. The headlines in the West Australian today tell it all.
—You have no sense of propriety, Laurie.
—I warn the member for Hume.
—The article reads:

ANSWER.PARA: A damning State Supply Commission report has found that Stateships committed major breaches of its guidelines when it entered into a stevedoring arrangement with anti-union magnate Len Buckeridge's BAAC Proprietary Limited. The report said Stateships entered the deal without proper regard for public tendering. It said Stateships did not call public tenders, failed to get approval to waive the public tender and exceeded its $500,000 exemption limit.

I am well aware that Mr Charlton's cabinet colleague services minister Minson is on the record as saying that, in his view, Eric has not done anything wrong. Of course, that might be his opinion, but the voters of Western Australia will be the best judges of that. It is the voters of Western Australia who are suffering at the moment along with the residents of the Cocos and Christmas islands. Only today Mr Charlton has refused the offer of the Maritime Union of Australia to exempt the loading of food supplies destined for the Cocos and Christmas islands. He has refused to accept the exemption.

PARA.TAB: I have written to Mr Charlton today, urging him to accept the union's offer and so allow the ship to depart tomorrow evening. It is a very serious offer. The union is on the public record today as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: In the interests of the people of the Cocos and Christmas islands, we will stevedore these vessels of Stateships on this occasion for nothing, with volunteers to get the cargo off them and get the cargo on them and to go to the Cocos and Christmas islands.

That is the offer which has been rejected by the Western Australian minister. I can tell you that neither I nor my colleague the member for the Northern Territory, in whose electorate the islands are located, will stand by and allow these islands to be used as pawns in this dispute. We will not allow them to suffer as a result of this disgraceful performance of the Western Australian government.

PARA.TAB: The Cocos Island's co-op has today chartered a DC8 aircraft to urgently transport food supplies. For our part, the Commonwealth government will match the co-op on a dollar for dollar basis to meet the cost of transporting the required food. The Commonwealth Department of Transport is also seeking to obtain alternative shipping to guarantee supplies to the Christmas and Cocos islands. The sooner the people of Western Australia learn the full truth about the relationship between the Western Australian government and Mr Buckeridge's BAAC the better. For the moment there is really a rotten stench from this whole affair that blows way across the Nullarbor.

In answer to the second part of the honourable member's question, it is not only Mr Charlton who has been fomenting industrial turmoil this week. The Western Australian Minister for Labour Relations, Mr Kierath, has been up to his ears in it as well. I have here a document which describes the key features of Minister Kierath's industrial legislation amendment and repeal bill 1995. He has circulated it today. One of its principal aims is to punish Western Australian employees and to punish Western Australian unions who seek to move to the federal IR system. Under these provisions, in such a circumstance a union making such a move would lose all of its rights under the relevant state awards. These are the unions—

TALK.START.PARA: —The battlers.

—These are the battlers, yes. These are the people trying to do a decent job representing some of the lowest paid people in our community; these are the people on the basic award rates which those sitting opposite would rip away from those workers, from those battlers.

PARA.TAB: Under these provisions, any union seeking to take an opportunity for federal registration would be effectively deregistered in Western Australia. The unions' right to represent workers in Western Australia under those circumstances would be lost forever. Who decides this? It is decided by the minister—Minister Kierath. There is no accountability to any industrial tribunal and no reviewability by any court of law. The end result of all this is that Mr Kierath would become the minister for demarcation disputes—the very demarcation disputes that he himself creates. I can assure honourable members that there are plenty of other provisions in this legislation that are just as appalling. For example, there is a provision for strikes to be illegal without a ballot. In other words, a worker who refuses—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with a ballot?
—I will tell you what is wrong with it.
—What is wrong with a ballot unless you are running it?
—We know your record in ballots.

—I will tell you precisely what is wrong with it. Under these provisions, a worker who says he or she will not work—for instance, in the circumstance of unsafe or dangerous workplace conditions—is liable to hefty fines. That is what is wrong with it.
—If you are the—
—Order! I warn the member for Mackellar.

—There are many more examples. I will conclude by saying that all these provisions will only lead to further industrial turmoil in Western Australia. They should be roundly condemned by all Australians—as should the efforts of the Leader of the Opposition, who stood in this House supporting his state colleagues in Western Australia only earlier this week.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In his One Nation speech of 26 February 1992, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: From tomorrow the sales tax on new cars currently subject to the 20 per cent rate will be permanently—

Given that you have now increased tax on cars to 21 per cent, soon to go to 22 per cent, what did you exactly mean when you told the battlers of Australia that you had permanently lowered their tax on cars?

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right.
—Is it the case that the only permanent thing about your promises is that sooner or later you will break them all?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a bit of stuff here for you.
—Have you found it yet?
—Here it is.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. The Prime Minister will put that away. He knows better.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Name him!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—Resume your seat for a minute.
—Now what did you do to our side when we did that?
—Order! The Prime Minister does know better. I would ask him to come to the response of the question.

—I am sure that opposition members thought it was worth waiting for. There is always something in my notes here; it just takes a couple of seconds to get it out. Honourable members might recall that we had a very large round of consultations in the One Nation process.
—What a joke.

—In those consultations, we spoke to all of the major industry groups, as this government has done since the economic summit in 1983. It was not like the joke that we used to have when we saw business community representatives traipsing into Parliament House a day before the coalition budget, which was already at the printer. They would go through this sham process of consultation.
—What has that got to do with your lies?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition.
—Well, you allowed him—
—That is it. One each way.
—Mr Speaker, do not be hard on him, please.
—No.
—I have to keep him going a bit longer. During those consultations we spoke to the motor industry. At that time the motor industry was going through a very typical cyclical decline in sales.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!
—We believed that there was a possibility of picking the motor industry back up again and we considered reducing, on a one-off basis, the sales tax on motor cars to 16 1/2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left will not interject.

—That we did. Guess what happened? With the pick-up in the economy, motor vehicle sales picked up enormously, so much so that we now have a waiting list of six months for some Australian cars. Given the fact that our policy was always a counter-cyclical policy—that is, to deal with the cycle—as the cycle picked up, the government changed it. I do not think anybody in the motor industry is at all surprised by this.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not see any statements of outrage or indignation coming from them. I will tell you one thing that none of us, except one person in this House, has ever done; that is, to go to an election and five months later withdraw $5 billion worth of tax cuts.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—You! You! You!

TALK.START.PARA: —There is only one person who has ever done that and that is John Howard. Mr Speaker, as the newspaper article, which I showed the House earlier, from your distinguished constituency showed, I am sure that in the postwar years the member for Bennelong is the only person who has worn an admonition like that on the front page of any Australian newspaper. I will let the banner speak for itself.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen criticisms of the budget on the basis that asset sales are used in the budget figuring to achieve a surplus in 1995-96? What is the government's response to these criticisms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for his question. I have seen such a criticism coming from various people on the opposition side. I must say that I find it most curious that they now seek to make this sort of criticism given that what we are doing in terms of the inclusion of asset sales as negative outlays—which are appropriately accounted for in the determination of the budget bottom line—is absolutely on par with conventional treatment both here and overseas. If we buy an asset we record it as an outlay and if we sell an asset it is appropriately recorded as a negative outlay. There is simply nothing wrong with treating asset sales in the way that they have historically been done in this country.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances, it is extraordinary that we heard the sort of language that we did from the Leader of the Opposition when he made his budget reply speech in this place. He stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Everybody knows that this glittering surplus—
he is talking about the surplus of $700 million—
is being achieved by the essentially fraudulent devices of including the asset sales in the budget figuring.

For the reasons that I have already mentioned, that is a quite extraordinary statement coming from someone who was a Treasurer for five years. It is the conventional way in which asset sales should be treated. There is nothing improper whatever in doing that.

PARA.TAB: What would be improper is if we tried to hide the fact that we had asset sales and if we announced that we had a budget surplus and people had to weave their way through the budget papers to the back to find that there were any asset sales at all. We were quite up-front about that. It was mentioned explicitly by me very early in my budget speech. It was right in the front of the budget papers. Therefore, there is not one skerrick of truth in this allegation of using a fraudulent device.

I find what has been said by the now Leader of the Opposition particularly interesting. He was criticising us for achieving a surplus in this way. He was asked on the 7.30 Report whether he had ever produced a budget surplus and his answer was, `Once—a domestic surplus in 1980.'

He was talking about the budget balance once overseas outlays and revenue are excluded, a new definition of a surplus. If you take big slices out of the budget—all the overseas outlays and overseas revenue—you are left with the domestic factors. In one year, the Leader of the Opposition had a surplus. Terrific, and what a surplus it was! It was a domestic surplus of $39 million. It was a really terrific performance.

How did he achieve that domestic surplus? He had to resort to something known as asset sales. He raised $181 million from asset sales. In other words, the whole of his domestic surplus was dependent on his selling assets—that is, they had to be used to get the calculation. If there are any fraudulent devices going on around this place, we know where they are coming from. How can the Leader of the Opposition be so hypocritical as to accuse us of fraudulent device when he himself was quite happy to include asset sales to achieve a miserable domestic surplus once in his five-year period as Treasurer?

When the now Prime Minister was Treasurer, we had four surpluses by the end of the 1980s. If you look at domestic surpluses, we had five of them but if we were to adopt the Leader of the Opposition's definition of a surplus we could claim an extra one. For this year, if we are going to talk about domestic surpluses being the relevant criterion, the surplus of $700 million becomes a surplus of $3.4 billion. That is our domestic surplus in 1995-96 against $39 million in 1980-81.

The hypocrisy of the opposition with regard to this measure is almost beyond belief. It is quite clear that what we are doing is absolutely above board. If you want to use the opposition's definition of what constitutes a surplus, we will wear that and it will be a very good outcome for us.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I would like to know how the Prime Minister reconciles the March quarter national accounts, which reveal a 3.7 per cent growth rate, a budget forecast of a growth rate of 3.75 per cent, and a $2 billion balance of payments monthly deficits, with his statement:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . any economy that can't travel at 4 per cent without spilling over into imports should give the game away.

As we are not travelling at four per cent, more particularly as imports continue to swamp in—and they are not just capital equipment—and as the majority of Australian battlers reckon that you should give the game away, does the Prime Minister understand the words he has used in the past, or is he perchance just fundamentally illiterate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get that point? At least he can read. When the economy was growing at 6 1/2 per cent in the year to September quarter, we did not hear any accolades for the government from you. You were saying it was unsustainable while your leader was saying, `The sky is falling in.' That is what you were saying then. Now the economy is growing at 3.75 per cent and you are saying that it is not at four per cent. You had better make your mind up.

PARA.TAB: The key element of the employment and growth equation in this country is investment. We have seen a 24 1/2 per cent investment growth over the course of the last year. In these national accounts, we can see 15.1 per cent for business investment in the year to this last quarter. It is the only way to lift the capital stock of Australia to produce the goods and services that will allow Australia to run an economy in excess of four per cent that does not spill into imports.

The other side of the equation is lifting savings, and that is where the budget surplus and superannuation come in. The current account problem is essentially, underneath, a savings problem, but it has been reflected in the fact that our capital stock had declined.
It is worth looking at one of the charts in Budget Statement No. 2. It shows you where the capital stock fell apart in Australia—from the mid-1970s to the early 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not when John was in power?
—That's right—when the member for Bennelong was Treasurer.
—Oh, yeah; you would say anything!
—Well, have a look at it. It is in Budget Statement No. 2. It is graphically illustrated for you.
—You would just say anything.

—Well, have a look at it. Don't rely on my word. Have a look at it. What the Treasury had to say in that analysis in Budget Statement No. 2 was that the growth in the public sector, which occurred under the Whitlam and Fraser governments—outlays of 23 per cent of GDP to 30 1/2 per cent of GDP at the time of the Fraser government under Treasurer Howard—and the explosion in wages to 18 per cent under the former Treasurer, that change, dislocated Australian private investment and the capital stock literally fell to pieces. That is where the current account exposure came from. That is why the current account deficit was six per cent of GDP in 1980-81.

PARA.TAB: From that time onwards, it has been about two per cent of GDP. We have had a two per cent of GDP current account larger than our capital inflow and our savings could afford. That has been reflected in the fact that through that double digit inflation savings fell and the capital stock was dislocated as private sector investment in this country was virtually cut to ribbons under the treasurership of the now opposition leader. What the 1980s were about were rebuilding the profit share, rebuilding profitability, to get investment and employment up. That is why there was a large growth in equipment investment in the late 1980s—

TALK.START.PARA: —You blew the current account three times.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—and it came out again, you can see it, in 24 per cent and 25 per cent. I just notice in Business Review Weekly this month—`Warning for Howard in CEO poll'. Some of the gloss has gone off him. It says that 150 CEOs were polled at random from the top 1,000 companies. They say, `Business is better disposed towards the government in general and not quite so pleased with the opposition.' Why are they—because of 24 per cent growth in business investment and 15 per cent continuing here in these national accounts.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite have never seen the likes of it when they have been in office, not in the 1970s. No member of the now opposition has ever presided over investment figures of that kind, ever. But because they were unable to and because private investment was hit by a wage explosion and a big lift in the public sector's call on savings, we saw the capital stock fall to pieces. That is why we had a current account debit of—let me tell the Leader of the National Party—six per cent of GDP in 1980-81. It only dropped back to 4 1/2 per cent under the weight of Mr Howard's recession in 1982-83.

There is a long, lineal history here of failure in government by the coalition. I have good cause to reflect on your capacity as against your former leaders Mr Anthony and Sir John McEwen. But let me say this: they were around at the scene of the accident. They were around at the scene of the crime, when this all happened. Yet you have the gall to get up and ask why we are not producing enough goods and services. Answer: 23 years of coalition government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. What is the government doing for people who are described by some as `battlers'—people who are sometimes in work, people who are sometimes out of work, people battling to hang on to a mortgage, and people battling to find jobs for their children? Mr KEATING—We notice today the coalition front bench all using the word, including the last question from the Leader of the National Party, `battler'—a cynical, poll driven piece of nonsense coming from a party which did everything, and has always done everything, to destroy the rights and the capacities of working Australians. Can't you imagine the word `battler', that sort of patronising and condescending phrase, being used at the Bridgewater Tennis Club over cucumber sandwiches—of course not them with the BMWs and the Porches lined up out the front, not them with their new graphite racquets as they have a little bite of their cucumber sandwiches.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Somebody in an advertising agency has given you twirps this word. When you talk about battlers, are you talking about the teenage battlers on the $3 an hour you proposed for them, or the adult battlers with no award protections, or the battlers that the Minister for Industrial Relations referred to on the Fremantle waterfront, or the unemployed battlers you want to punch off the dole after nine months and the $10 billion cuts to government spending?
—That is an absolute lie.
—The Prime Minister will wait just for a moment. The member for Sturt will withdraw that.
—But it is a lie, Mr Speaker.
—You will withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker.
—I warn the member for Sturt. He knows better.
—Or the retiring battlers the coalition wants to dismantle—

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of the order. Under standing order 142, ministers are supposed to answer for matters for which they have responsibility. The Prime Minister is doing nothing here except engage in language which denigrates this place. He is engaging in nothing but a tirade of abuse.
—Order! There is no point of order. Resume your seat. The Prime Minister is responding directly to the question.

—Today on radio the Deputy Leader of the Liberal party would have, at least on probably 50 or 60 occasions, used this term. This is pretty rich coming from the Dollar Sweets man, who in the 1986 national wage case argued for a reduction in all award wages to $25 below the lowest award rate then applying. This is the same party that is arguing for the battlers whom they wanted to put a 15 per cent, completely undercompensated consumption tax, GST, on at the last election. This is the same party that wants to abolish bulkbilling for battlers—the people on low incomes who need to go to doctors, who cannot afford to cover the 15 per cent residual and who are bulkbilled. The same people want to knock $10,000 million out of Commonwealth government spending, which can only come out of transfer payments to the poor, the low paid, the sick, the elderly or the schools because they have given up, they said, any use of any reference to changes to revenue or receipts. They have also said that they would oppose the Working Nation changes to get unemployed people—as if they are not battlers—back to work.

PARA.TAB: On all of that cynicism let me give these facts: the best measure of average living standards in Australia is real household disposable income. Why is it the best measure? It is because it includes wages, salaries, supplements, pensions and social security benefits, and it includes them on an after tax basis per person. What do we find? Between 1983 to 1995 real household disposable income increased by 40 per cent. Because the population has grown since then, it is more relevant to look to the numbers per head. Disposable income in the last March quarter was $3,568, compared with $3,058 in the March quarter of 1983; that is, it was up 19.8 per cent. That is a 1.7 per cent per head increase every year in disposable income.

In contrast, under the last coalition government real household disposable income per capita increased by only 2.1 per cent. So the government has had more growth in household disposable income in one year than the coalition government had in eight years. That is, the government has seen real household disposable income rise by 40 per cent in the period since it has been in office—a massive improvement. Yet these people go on radio, stand in the House and talk cynically in poll-driven terms about battlers when the best they could do was one-eighth of the performance in the growth of household disposable income that occurred under the government.
Let me again refer to this very key point, which was made by the US Secretary for Labour, Mr Reicht, last week. He said this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh no, not again. You read this page to us on Monday.
—Order! I remind members of the House of the provisions of standing order 55.
—He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the job choice between America's low unemployment with falling real wages and Europe's high real wages with high unemployment was . . . a diabolical trade-off.

Let me concur with those words and say that we, in this country, have a much better balance between wages growth, income growth and employment. That is why, if it were said that any American labour secretary or European labour secretary could point to a 40 per cent increase in household disposable income, I am certain that could not be the case. That is because we have had now 1.9 million additional jobs in 12 years, we have taken a labour market of six million people to eight million people and, at the same time, we have seen this increase in their household disposable income per capita of 20 per cent over the 12 years.

PARA.TAB: That gives the lie to these words—as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said on This Country—that `things have never been as bad for Australians; things have never been worse.' What a cynical, terrible, deceptive thing to be saying on a radio station. To be out there saying that to Australians is to deny the undeniable of nearly two million jobs and a 40 per cent increase in household disposable income. To be out on a radio station saying that Australians are now doing worse than in most countries is just a complete untruth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Butler House; here is Butler House. Look at this.
—Order! The member for Mayo.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!
—Let us nail the lie for the lie it is—that we have had in this country an increase in disposable income of 40 per cent—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!
—over the course of the last 12 years, which could not be replicated in North America or in Western Europe. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition should be admonished for his remarks.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Moments ago you demanded that I withdraw the term `lie'. The Prime Minister has used the term twice in the last 10 seconds and you have completely ignored it. I ask you to make him withdraw.
—The sense in which the honourable member for Sturt used the word which is considered parliamentary was directly—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we've got the plot.

—Order! In the sense that I was listening to the Prime Minister, it was not directed to any person. I have allowed that in the past when, amongst others, I think the Leader of the Opposition may have done so.
—When?
—Order! Has the Prime Minister finished? The Prime Minister is in conclusion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hawker

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would just give you the ruling that you gave on 17 August 1993. You said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I have found that on a number of occasions speakers have ruled that the use of that particular term—

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating interjecting—
Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Wannon has the call.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hawker

TALK.START.PARA: —I continue:

INTERJECT.PARA: or any derivation of that term, is unparliamentary. As far as I am concerned, that will be the ruling that I uphold in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just ruled on that. Resume your place. The Prime Minister in conclusion.

—Household disposable income has risen by 40 per cent since 1983, and we have seen the labour market grow by just on two million jobs. When you juxtapose that with coalition members saying that they want to see teenagers on $3 an hour, no award protection for adult people, for unemployed people no dole after nine months, $10 billion of cuts to government spending, and capping retirement incomes under superannuation—these are all the things, as I said before, that make it clear that the words uttered by Liberal Party frontbenchers and National Party frontbenchers, and particularly the Deputy Leader of the National Party on radio today, are a complete and total distortion, untruth and sell Australia down the drain.

—I address my question to the Minister for Transport. The airline industry and its acolytes, the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority, have made many attempts to expand the capacity of Sydney airport by such means as new flight paths over the Sydney Harbour Bridge, a fourth runway, reduced curfew hours, reduced separation standards and removal of regional operators. How will the government's proposed privatisation arrangements safeguard Sydney residents from such expansion in the future? How can anyone believe any assurances after many years of false and misleading statements concerning the costs and environmental effects of the third runway? How can the government justify the removal for at least 50 years of the option of redeveloping Sydney airport, the continuation of massive subsidies to a monopoly leaseholder by immunity from normal planning, rating and taxation regimes and the costs of the surrounding infrastructure provision and urban consolidation disbenefits?

—As the honourable member is aware, the Commonwealth government determined that it should reserve all of its existing powers in respect of the control of flight paths, operational standards, environmental requirements, curfew considerations—indeed, every one of these issues which are of such concern to him and his constituents. We realise that, in the public interest, it is absolutely necessary for the safeguards to rest here with the elected representatives in this great parliament of ours.

PARA.TAB: The 50-year leases on the airports will not carry with them a right of the lessee to develop the airport without recourse to a set of standards set by this parliament and regulated by the department, with a minister available in this parliament from time to time to account for the manner in which those safeguards and standards are enforced.
