As the House well knows, I have been very critical of many aspects of airport administration, particularly in respect of Sydney airport, over recent years. I am very pleased to be able to indicate that we have taken a good range of steps to tighten the controls. It is for that reason that we have had that series of announcements since the opening of the third runway—a third runway which the honourable member, like me, opposed at the time—to restrict the operations from it. The first announcement related to the restricted flight paths and was announced by the Prime Minister and me. That stopped planes fanning out all over Sydney and has, I can say, seen planes overwhelmingly fly with laser-like precision down a very narrow flight path. That does not make it any easier for the people under that flight path, but it means there are fewer people in total affected.

It also means that we can concentrate our efforts, which involve the expenditure of $260 million, to deal with noise amelioration for those premises that are so affected. That program is proceeding under the administration of my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services, with a great deal of success. Already there is a massive program being conducted in schools and public institutions to provide that sound proofing.

Similarly, we said that aeroplanes must go to the very southernmost point of the runway when taking off to the north and that they must take off with the steepest possible departure track. That means, of course, that aircraft are much higher at the time they get to the residential areas. Again, it is a measure this government has taken to try, to the best extent possible, to protect those people living on those flight paths from the noise nuisance. In comparison with these measures, those sitting opposite would reopen the third runway and—

TALK.START.PARA: —The east-west runway, not the third runway.

—The east-west runway, and expose an extra 100,000 people to the noise menace. Having said that, the measures do not stop and start with restricted flight paths, steep take-offs and use of the long taxiway. We have gone further than that.

PARA.TAB: We have banned the use of 737 aircraft during the curfew hours. I know that is something the honourable member would applaud. In addition, we have indicated that all curfew freight arrangements have to be transferred to Badgerys Creek airport when it is eventually developed as a curfew-free airport. We have also allocated in this budget some $762 million for the development of that airport and for the transport links to it. These are all, once again, aimed at alleviating the very grave difficulties that are being experienced by people in the honourable member's constituency.

We are intent on making sure that we do not have a similar situation occur in the future in western Sydney as we have seen, through a lack of planning, in the inner metropolitan area with the development of the third runway, which all of you sitting opposite supported. It is for that reason that we have a range of environmental studies under way into water, air and noise. A whole new series of contours is being developed using the responsibilities which are, and will remain, those exclusively of the Commonwealth.

I can give the member for North Sydney one further safeguard. He approached me recently about his own constituency's lack of representation on the newly constituted consultative committee on airport noise, which will have the job of policing the bureaucrats in all of these activities. After he wrote to me, I indicated to him that I would give some consideration to it. That committee will be having its first meeting next Monday under the chairmanship of the Hon. Joe Riordan, a very fine chairman indeed. I am writing to the honourable member today inviting him to nominate a representative in order that his constituency is directly represented in that policing program. I am pleased to be able to indicate that my colleagues the member for Parramatta and the government whip, who raised concerns about this, will also be directly represented in that process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House of any measures which show the success of labour market programs, including those under the Working Nation strategy?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I must say that access to the labour market programs, including those under Working Nation, greatly improves the chances of people getting employment. The comparison that has to be made here is between those going through the programs and those who do not have access to the programs or would not go through them.

PARA.TAB: From my department's post-program monitoring, we see that, if you participate in short-term training programs, your chances of getting a job are increased by up to 50 per cent. If you go through the jobstart program, your chances double. If you are long-term unemployed under jobstart, they more than double. If you go through a traineeship, you have an 88 per cent chance of a positive outcome. If you go through a NEIS program, you have an 84 per cent success rate. It also shows that case management is improving the chances of employment.

That is essentially what the government's Working Nation initiatives are about. They are about better enabling the long-term unemployed to compete, as well as boosting the size and the skills of the work force. But what does the opposition say about it? It says that Working Nation is not working. It has refused to indicate whether it would support the programs that we have funded. Its shadow spokesman has called it a bureaucratic leviathan.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a nightmare; that is what it is now.

—He now says that it is a nightmare. What does the OECD say, however? The Treasurer attended the recent meeting of the OECD in Paris. Have a look at the report that has come down, because Australia is given very strong endorsement throughout the report. There are positive references to this country's initiatives all through it. It endorses better targeting of labour market programs. We are doing it. It also mentions case management, the opening up to competition, subsidies to encourage employers to take on the long-term unemployed, the skill formation initiatives, the training wage and changes to the income support arrangements. It even welcomes the industrial relations reforms. So let us have none of this from opposition members, who cannot ever bring themselves to make a positive statement about anything that this government has done.

PARA.TAB: I noticed yesterday that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was making reference to The Life of Brian and to always looking on the bright side. But the other line from that famous film is: `What have the Romans ever done for us?' In terms of the background of achievement, do you ever recognise anything that has been done? There is no recognition from you. You are never satisfied in terms of achievement. You have got no alternatives. You are always opposing things. This great born to rule coalition is born to oppose these days. Little wonder no-one takes you seriously. I conclude on the point that Labor has the policies which will produce the jobs. The Liberals, it would seem, have a job producing the policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. A crucial issue on the Hindmarsh Island bridge declaration is whether you made the decision to ban the bridge before you had a chance to consider 400 representations, on Friday, 8 July, or, as you have claimed and stated in a press release, the day after, on Saturday, 9 July. An Aboriginal woman, Betty Tatt, has made a statutory declaration that, on Friday, 8 July at a NAIDOC ball in Adelaide, Doreen Kartinyeri announced that she had heard from you that you had decided to ban the Hindmarsh Island bridge. When did you decide to ban the bridge? Was it on 8 July, as stated by Doreen Kartinyeri, or was it on 9 July, as claimed by you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I will first of all say just exactly what this issue is about. Here we are seeing the member for Hindmarsh being merely a compliant tool of the member for Barker in his attempt to get back on the front bench. I can tell honourable members in one fell swoop what this is all about. The Courier-Mail on Monday reported:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Mr McLachlan's interest in the Hindmarsh Island bridge affair was far from extinguished—
In fact, his political humiliation at the hands of his sworn enemies—Mr Tickner, Mr Keating and the Attorney-General, Mr Michael Lavarch, had fuelled it to new heights.

In this we see the shadow minister throwing away her responsibilities to stand up for Aboriginal women and issues of principle and to deal with the truth of this matter, and instead getting into a campaign of smear, smear, smear. Indeed, the Leader of the Opposition has been very much a part of that in his attempt to besmirch the reputation of Professor Cheryl Saunders, as he did on the Alan Jones program on 22 May.

TALKER.NAME: Dr LAWRENCE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The quality of health care in Australia is a matter of great significance to governments, to health professionals and, most vitally, to all Australians who need health care assistance. This statement reports to the House the first results of an important study—the Australian hospital care study—which presents a challenge to governments and to health professionals. I will describe these results and set out the approach that the government plans to take to respond to the challenge of producing better quality care, the need for which the study has starkly defined.

PARA.TAB: The Australian hospital care study was commissioned and funded by my department as part of the professional indemnity review. The review was set up in 1991 to look at the adequacy of compensation and funding arrangements for health care misadventures in Australia and will produce its final report shortly. As part of its task, the study looked at adverse events affecting patients in Australian hospitals, both public and private, to which they were admitted in 1992. An adverse event is defined in the study as an unintended injury, which results in a disability, which may include a longer hospital stay, or death, and which is caused by health care management rather than the patient's underlying disease.

The study looked at how many adverse events there were, their causes and factors contributing to their occurrence, the levels of disability resulting from the adverse events, and how preventable they were. It must be emphasised that a good many adverse events are difficult to prevent. When people are very ill and treatment is complex and intensive, when they have multiple conditions and when they no longer have the advantage of the robustness of youth, it can be expected that some proportion of cases will result in injury from the treatment itself.

What we need to focus on are the adverse events which are judged to be preventable. It is worth pointing out that adverse events are highly correlated with increasing age, but are not correlated with gender, birthplace, aboriginality, marital status or whether the patient is public or private.

This study, with its focus on the preventability of adverse outcomes, is a world first. It is a vital milestone for improving public and private hospital outcomes for consumers by better measurement of performance and appropriate improvement in practice.

The first results of the study—which has been carried out by a consortium from the universities of Adelaide and Newcastle—have only just become available. I am making these results available, at least in this preliminary way, at the earliest opportunity as I believe that Australian health care consumers, professionals and policy makers have a right to know the information as early as possible. Governments and the professions need to be formulating a response without delay. Complete results of the study will be published in the academic literature in the near future.

The study examined the medical records of over 14,000 patient admissions to 28 public and private hospitals in New South Wales and South Australia in 1992. Around one sixth, or 16 per cent, of the hospital admissions during the year of the study were assessed as involving an adverse event. For about half of these—that is, 8 per cent of the admissions overall—the adverse events were assessed as being preventable.

I should say that the assessments of whether there was an adverse event, and the degree to which it was preventable, was made by two or three experienced medical assessors reviewing each record after an initial assessment by a nurse. In just over half of the adverse events, the resulting disability lasted less than one month; and in another 30 per cent, the disability was resolved in less than 12 months. However, the other 20 per cent resulted in various degrees of permanent disability or even death. For 0.8 per cent of the total medical records studied, the adverse event resulted in death with 0.5 per cent of the total being judged as preventable.

A qualification to these disturbing figures is that, in a proportion of these cases, the seriousness of the patient's underlying condition means they may have died or become severely disabled during the admission, even if the adverse event had not occurred. Nearly half of all the adverse events were associated with an operation, 15 per cent were related to system problems such as inadequate training or supervision or inadequate communication, and 13 per cent were diagnostic errors. About 75 per cent of the adverse events occurred in an acute hospital, with around 8 per cent occurring in a doctor's office.

While the study sample involved just 28 hospitals in two states, the study methodology is rigorous and should allow the results to be applied to the Australian hospital system as a whole. I will table a paper shortly setting out in more detail the background and methodology adopted by the study.

If the study results were generalised to Australia as a whole, 230,000 public and private hospital admissions in 1992 would have involved an adverse event which was preventable. It is of great concern to me that between 25,000 and 30,000 people would have experienced an adverse event that resulted in some degree of permanent disability, and between 10,000 and 14,000 people would have died. It must be stressed that, although the actual timing of many of these deaths may have been preventable, death itself may have been highly likely because of frailty or the severity of the person's illness.

The human implications of these results are clearly a matter of considerable concern to me, as I am sure they will be for all of you and for other health ministers in Australia. As I have said earlier, I have decided to release them now, so that they can be a trigger for effective action. There will be a closer examination of the study when it is published, but I believe that the evidence is sufficiently stark to warrant immediate action.

In addition to the human implications of these figures, these findings indicate another cost as well. The total hospital bed-days attributable to adverse events in 1992 on the basis of the study figures is 3.2 million, with around half of these relating to preventable adverse events. This preventable proportion amounts to over 8 per cent of all bed-days in that year. A reasonable estimate of the cost of these bed-days would be around $650 million.

I believe it is vital that action is taken by the Commonwealth, the states, who are responsible for public hospital management, private hospital proprietors and the professions to address these issues as a matter of urgency. Today I have written to state health ministers and I will be raising these issues at the Health Ministers Forum to be held tomorrow and the Health Ministers Conference to be held on 15 June. I have also taken steps to consult with relevant professional organisations.

The results of the study are not welcome news. They are, however, a call to action. We can be satisfied that we have had the courage to do the study fully and rigorously—few other countries have done so. Now we must respond to the challenge it represents. More analysis is needed of the data obtained in the study before we know the areas of highest priority for action and before proper prevention strategies can be developed. The consortium is proceeding with this analysis at the moment. However, I believe we need a concerted effort from all interested parties.

When, as part of the study, medical reviewers were asked where efforts should be directed to prevent recurrence for each adverse event that had any possibility of preventability, the area of quality assurance and peer review was cited in 56 per cent of cases. The next highest rated area was communication at 11 per cent. So it is clearly this area of quality assurance and peer review that offers the most scope for measures to reduce preventable adverse events.

One can be encouraged in this regard by the experience of anaesthetics which, despite its inherent dangers, was assessed as being related to only two per cent of the adverse events in the study. This seemingly low result can be attributed to the strenuous efforts of the anaesthetists in Australia over the years to establish and continue a system whereby adverse events are reported and investigated—in particular, anaesthetic deaths are individually closely examined and the assessments reported from time to time in a public document. A not dissimilar process has been adopted for maternal deaths.

It is this culture of measurement of outcomes, assessment of the causes of problems and adoption of measures to address them that we need to encourage throughout the system. I will be proposing to my health minister colleagues and to the leaders of the health professions that a task force be established to examine and report to governments and to the professions on the further work that needs to be done and the measures that should be adopted to improve the hospital system's outcomes.

I will propose that the task force be chaired by Dr Bruce Armstrong, Director of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, and that it have a high level membership drawn from the leadership of the health professions, from government, both federal and state, from consumers and from the research consortium which undertook the Australian hospital care study. It should report to the professions and governments within six months.

It is my expectation that this task force will be able to use the results of the Australian hospital care study to develop a set of clear proposals for quick and effective action that hospitals and the health sector can take to reduce the number of preventable adverse events. This study provides a good basis for the health industry to analyse the causes of these adverse events and develop appropriate responses. The study also shows the necessity for the enhanced work on establishment of quality indicators that the government announced in the budget.

The national hospitals outcomes program is a $14.5 million program over three years to develop and implement nationally consistent performance measures for standards of quality and outcomes of care in Australian hospitals. These performance indicators will be used by hospitals and governments for quality assessment and improvement, including benchmarking activities. The program supports demonstration activities that will assist hospitals to respond with quality and outcome improvements and continue to develop incident reporting arrangements.

We can no longer be complacent about the issue of patient safety in health care. It is no longer satisfactory for us to simply assert that we have a high quality health system. We need to measure outcomes and performance. We need to ensure that the system has a clear and strong patient focus. We need to actively address the problem areas. I congratulate those who carried out the study—the challenge of response lies before us. I present the following documents:
History and methodology of the Hospital Care Study, and Australian Hospital Care—ministerial statement, 1 June 1995.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The study that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has outlined is disturbing, but to anyone working in the hospital system I could not suspect that it was surprising or new. In fact, if anything is surprising it is that it is only now we are starting to take account of these things that people have been talking about anecdotally for a long time. Anyone working in the hospital system knows the stresses that are involved and, indeed, these figures that the minister has talked about today are from 1992. Quite possibly, three years later, today, the figures are worse.

PARA.TAB: As I look through the minister's speech I see the implication that a lot of adverse incidents could be prevented. There seems to be an implication that if we do something we could prevent some of these bad results. The minister stated that 56 per cent of respondents said that quality assurance and peer review was the best way to go. I have heard the government talking about quality assurance and peer review for a decade now. It is not unreasonable at this stage to suggest that the government should have something in place which is effective. The problem is about the behaviour of human beings—it is human problems, human failings and the training of humans. The response has to be about getting people to change their behaviour.

The minister's response is long on analysis. That is not a surprise, given that she was talking about a major report. But it is short on solutions. Two things come through to me from her statement. Firstly, there is a lack of a cohesive approach in our hospitals. There has not been a building of cohesive teams, as there might have been. The second issue relates to resources and pressures on the working environment of hospitals. I accept that in this report resources are ranked by only four per cent as a significant issue. Communications procedures are ranked by 50 per cent. I suspect that, when she sits down after the event and looks at the position in the quiet analysis of daytime, she might get a slightly different perspective. My first political involvement in the medical profession was when I found a colleague slumped in a corner of the residents quarters at 4.30 one morning, sobbing because he could not cope with the workload.

In the present budget there is an increase in expenditure for drugs of about 12 per cent, for general practitioner consultations of about 10 per cent and on public hospitals of 2.8 per cent, or a real 0.7 per cent decline. Considering that this report is, in part, about public hospitals, you have to wonder about the allocation of resources. The minister realised this in 1990 when she was Premier of Western Australia. She wrote to the then Treasurer:

SPEECH.PARA: The lower Medicare benefit levels for Western Australia are only partially offset by higher Commonwealth grants to the Western Australian government. . . The Medicare arrangements have placed considerable demands on the State's public hospitals, and it is therefore important that the State not be further burdened as a result of Commonwealth health funding anomalies.

You only have to walk around any public hospital anywhere in Australia—not in one particular state or another—to see that, quite frankly, they are bursting at the seams. That is why the results today may be worse than they were in 1992, which is the year to which the figures in this statement refer. The main reason is probably communications and procedures in hospitals.

PARA.TAB: I hope the solutions looked at here are practical solutions, not theoretical solutions. You can write proposals until you are blue in the face but, in the end, they are no good if they sit on someone's desk. This was very clearly illustrated to me recently in a discussion about the potential of needlestick injuries to transmit HIV in hospitals in New South Wales. Every hospital in New South Wales has procedures. When they tried to find out where these procedures were and why so many potentially damaging needlestick injuries were occurring, they found the procedures sitting on the desks of the administrators.

I hope something good comes out of this statement. I hope blame does not come out of it. I commend the minister for making this ministerial statement. I hope she does not mind if I say that I am awaiting a ministerial statement on the Gregory report and the Baume report. I look forward very much to such a statement.
I very much appreciate her talking about outcomes. I suggest that she might at the same time look at outcomes in the Common

SPEECH.PARA: wealth-state disability agreement and in preventive health, particularly immunisation. She might look at tying outcomes to the better practice program and the national AIDS strategy in Aboriginal health. We would support all of those.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I make the observation that, while, on the face of it, our results appear much worse than those in the United States, it is quite possible that the United States was looking at a much narrower range of potential adverse events, and they may not be readily comparable. I thank the minister for her courtesy in making this report available to me earlier Provided we do not have a bureaucratic response but a practical one that is focused but achievable, the government will have the opposition's support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially, I thank the government for giving me time to make a response, here in the House, to the statement of Senator Gareth Evans made in another place earlier this day. There have been very unfortunate recent discussions publicly in Australia about the Australian intelligence services. Much of what has been discussed publicly in the media, I do not want to canvass here today for very good reasons of national interest. But I want to make three or four points that come out of today's statement by Senator Evans in his response to the Samuels Inquiry into the Australian Secret Intelligence Service.

PARA.TAB: The first thing I would make clear is that the coalition believes that Australia does have an effective and responsible intelligence establishment, and effective and responsible intelligence services, including ASIS. There are some who argue that in the post-Cold War environment there is no need any longer for intelligence services, and that, indeed, the only real value of intelligence nowadays is economic intelligence. That is manifestly untrue.

People who think that gaining intelligence of a wide variety, not just economic intelligence but intelligence on security issues, in particular, is unimportant are people who have no real understanding of this country's national interests. It is vastly important that we have effective intelligence collection, particularly in the post-Cold War environment where we cannot simply rely on the truisms of the past, the one side versus the other. We have to operate in a much more unpredictable and uncertain international environment, and we have to do so much more from our own resources than depend on what used to be described as great and powerful friends.

Australia has real strength in the area of intelligence and should be proud of its intelligence resources. In addition, it has close links with a range of other countries—a wide range of other countries—not least the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and, indeed, to a lesser extent, New Zealand. So we do have a good intelligence capability, we do have a widespread intelligence capability—and that is a national asset which the coalition believes is worth preserving.

Secondly, a large number of allegations have been made over recent months about what the Australian intelligence services have been doing. Consistent with the position of the government, I will not comment on those allegations in substance at all. But I would make this point: there is something wrong—and there is, in particular, something wrong with morale and ministerial administration of intelligence services if these kinds of stories and, in particular, the Four Corners episode of 1994, gained such prominence. I will come back to the government's responsibility and, in particular, Senator Evans culpability in this whole matter.

I say in response to the recommendations Senator Gareth Evans has put forward that the coalition has, via me as the shadow minister, had the opportunity on two or three occasions to discuss these recommendations with Senator Evans. Through those discussions Senator Evans has always been very reasonable in listening to the point of view of the coalition and has been from time to time prepared to make adjustments with that in mind.

In terms of the actual recommendations Senator Evans has announced today—I will not canvass them for we do not want to spend too much time on this matter—the coalition is, in general terms, in support of them. Of course, we await the legislation and I cannot personally make a commitment that the coalition will support in legislation every single aspect of this. It certainly is true that we are happy to go along with the broad outline of what Senator Evans has said today.

The third point, though, is the point about Senator Evans himself and his culpability in this whole matter. The simple fact is that ministers under our system are responsible for departments and agencies within their portfolios. Even on the coalition side as an opposition, we accept that shadow ministers are responsible for what goes on in their portfolio areas as far as opposition activities are concerned. Senator Evans is therefore responsible for what has happened at ASIS which, in turn, led to this judicial inquiry, its report and, finally, the government's response to that report. In administering his duties, Senator Evans has been grossly negligent and totally incompetent. He has also misled the Senate and, I believe, has destroyed his reputation as a public figure through the way he has handled this whole affair.

I come to the heart of what Senator Evans has done. There are four basic points that need to be made. First, Senator Evans has failed to implement an adequate grievance procedure for complaints by ASIS staff until now. The minister has a special duty of care for ASIS because the employees of ASIS do not have the normal appeal mechanisms that apply to the bulk of the Australian Public Service. That means that the minister has on his shoulder a greater weight of responsibility for those people who are employed in ASIS. Senator Evans has quite clearly not understood his special duty of care, nor executed his special duty of care.

There has been evidence since 1990 of gross dissatisfaction within ASIS at the grievance procedures. The minister failed to adopt new grievance procedures for ASIS after ASIO introduced its new grievance procedures in 1991. A model existed, but it was ignored. The minister, importantly, ignored the advice of the Inspector-General to revise and expand the grievance procedure system in 1992. Let the House be well aware of that.

Indeed, Senator Evans was prepared to say earlier today in a television debate with me that he had had representations from the Inspector-General for more resources over quite a period of time in order to improve the capacity of the Inspector-General to deal with grievances, and Senator Evans rejected that application from the Inspector-General.

The minister failed to act on the advice of the Director-General of ASIS in February 1994 when the Director-General advised the minister of the need to hold an inquiry into individual complaints. The minister rejected that advice. That is perfectly clear and unequivocal, and no casuistry by Senator Evans is going to get him out of the trap he has set for himself and walked into.

The fact is that on 10 February 1994 he was advised by the Director-General to establish an inquiry into the complaints and if an inquiry was not established there was a danger the complainants would leak to the media and there would be public exposure and controversy. If Senator Evans had acted on the advice of his Director-General, then it may well be that the Four Corners program and the embarrassment that caused to the Australian government and the Australian people would have been avoided.

But Senator Gareth Evans sat on his hands and did nothing. He told the Senate on 22 February that he had no intention at all of establishing an inquiry into the grievances of the complainants; something that he told the Senate this week he did not do. In other words, Senator Evans misled the Senate on that matter. So, by failing to act, the minister has ended up by being totally responsible for the Four Corners exposure and the embarrassment that occurred to Australia and its people.

Senator Evans's second real point of failure is that he failed to protect national security by refusing to act on the reports that the agents were going to go public. I have made that point sufficiently without having to repeat any of those aspects. I remind the House that at the Senate estimates committee hearing on 22 February 1994 Senator Evans said that he had no intention of holding an inquiry. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Inspector-General's judgment is that those particular grievances have been settled as a result of an extended inquiry process—a very detailed consideration.
That was the Inspector-General's judgment. The Samuels inquiry shows that to have been wrong. Senator Evans went on to say:
It is my own judgment—
not the Inspector-General's or anybody else's, but his—
that those cases have been fully and fairly resolved; I have seen the documentation associated with them. It is not proposed to open those matters for review.

Senator Evans was, therefore, totally responsible. Later, as I have explained, he decided that he had always been thinking of having a review, even though he told the Senate it was not proposed to open those matters for review.

PARA.TAB: The third point—a related point—is that Senator Evans failed adequately to examine the individual cases. I just want to go to the heart of that matter. He repeatedly assured the Senate that there was an exhaustive and exhausting investigation by the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. He took personal responsibility and made a virtue of it by declaring:

SPEECH.PARA: The Inspector-General's judgment is that those particular grievances have been settled as a result of the extended inquiry process; a very detailed consideration. It is my own judgment that those cases have been fairly and fully resolved.
I have seen the documentation associated with them. It is not proposed to open those matters for review.

Thus he assumed personal responsibility after having reviewed the documents himself. If I can put it this way: he certainly fails the McLachlan standard of responsibility which says that a minister must be responsible for acts of staff—more so when, in this case, the minister has exhaustively examined the details and taken personal responsibility before the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The final point I want to make is on the question of the preparation of the psychological report into one of the complainants. This report was prepared and has been a very controversial matter. I do not wish to canvass it at great length, except to say that Senator Evans was aware that this psychological report had been prepared. He was aware that there were allegations that the report had been improperly prepared. Senator Evans decided to leave it up to ASIS as to what should be done with the report. Despite the fact that Senator Evans knew that psychological report had been inadequately prepared—or, at least, that there were allegations that it had been improperly prepared—he decided to leave it up to ASIS as to what should be done with it. He decided he did not really care about the allegations of improper preparation and that he would wash his hands of the matter.

The report was used in the briefing of members of the opposition. As the Samuels commission findings reported, the use of that psychological report was `highly inappropriate'. Now Senator Evans says, `Well, yes, it was highly inappropriate. I couldn't agree more with the Samuels inquiry.' But it is his responsibility that the psychological report was used by ASIS in that improper way because he, Senator Evans, decided he did not care what happened to it.

When you look at the whole catalogue of disasters surrounding this affair, you see that the responsibility falls back on the shoulders of Senator Evans. No amount of circumlocution or casuistry is going to get Senator Evans out of the fact that he is a minister, paid as a minister and believed to be responsible as a minister for what goes on within his own department and its agencies. The simple fact is that the Samuels inquiry, a judicial inquiry, has damned the performance of Senator Evans.

As I said earlier in my speech, the reputation of Senator Evans as foreign minister will be tarnished for all time because it has been revealed yet again that Senator Evans is a man who does not care about the people who work in his department or in agencies under his control. He is a man who has grand visions for multilateral diplomacy—some of which are not only grand but impractical—but he is not a man who cares about the people for whom he is responsible. In this particular case he was especially responsible for them because of ASIS's understandable status.

I want to finish by repeating a very important point: the coalition has acted in a way which could only be described as extraordinarily responsible through these difficult times. There have been plenty of opportunities for us to make political points out of allegations made by people surrounding the Australian intelligence community. We have not been prepared to capitalise on those opportunities because we put the national interest first.

But never let it be forgotten that the extraordinary debacle that has occurred in relation to the Australian intelligence effort has occurred in the last few months under the guidance of Senator Evans, who is totally responsible for matters which have occurred. As I said, his reputation will be forever tarnished by this shoddy affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Reserve Bank Act, the Reserve Bank has its own superannuation fund called the Officers Superannuation Fund, or OSF. Having its own fund is, presumably, a sign of the bank's independence from the federal government—a notion we all encourage. However, there is a problem. Plainly, the Reserve Bank is in possession of market-sensitive information. Indeed, given its control over short-term interest rates and its influence in the bond market, we can fairly say that no institution has more market-sensitive information than the Reserve Bank.

PARA.TAB: To some people—millions of ordinary Australians whose own superannuation funds have done so poorly in recent years—it might seem odd that the bank should have its own superannuation fund when it is potentially in a position to know market movements in advance. This enormous potential conflict could be easily solved by having the OSF managed entirely at arms length so that there is no possibility of the people making the investment decisions knowing anything about either forthcoming changes in monetary policy or the bank's own trading activities in the bond and foreign exchange markets.

Unfortunately, this is not the case. While the equity and property portions of the portfolio are managed outside the bank, the fixed interest or bond portfolio is managed in-house, under the supervision of the OSF's investment committee. What astonishes me is that sitting on the investment committee is the assistant governor for financial markets and a senior officer of the domestic markets department of the bank.

This committee makes the asset allocation decisions for the fund—when to buy bonds and when to buy equities, and vice versa—yet it seems that these two officers are in charge of the bank's own trading. I must ask: how could the Governor of the Reserve Bank allow such a situation to exist?

As if that does not seem peculiar enough, the situation takes a more serious turn when we learn that the investment performance of the OSF has been amazingly good. It has outperformed other funds of an equivalent size by a country mile. Since the financial year 1991-92, its annual return has never fallen below 10 per cent. In the financial year 1993-94, a year when the bond markets went through the floor, the OSF's rate of return was 12.9 per cent—a good deal ahead of the average for funds of its size of 7.6 per cent.

Time does not permit me today to elaborate in any detail on the movements in the weightings of the OSF's portfolio, but I ask members of this House whether they have ever heard of a superannuation fund with no fixed interest assets—no bonds; none; zero weighting. I invite them to look at the portfolio of the OSF for the end of June 1994. Its weighting in fixed interest was zero. I ask: did its consultant, Towers Perrin, recommend a zero weighting? I have my doubts.

Let me say clearly now that it seems very unfair for ordinary Australians that the Reserve Bank is apparently able to engineer for its own superannuation fund a higher performance than what any of the rest of us can ever aspire to in our funds, which have performed so badly. We do not have a zero weighting in bonds when the bond market is going through the floor. For the rest of us, when we put our money in some superannuation funds we may as well bend over, put our heads between our legs and kiss our backsides goodbye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the other chamber on 11 May 1995 Senator Michael Baume stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in the House of Representatives Mr Colin Hollis continued a pattern of personal attack on me.

Nothing could be further from the truth. What I did say was that Senator Michael Baume had misled the Senate by saying that he had never issued defamation proceedings against me. I tabled the defamation order issued in the Supreme Court of New South Wales at Nowra and also a letter from Senator Michael Baume's solicitors. Senator Baume admitted in the same speech that he had been in error.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, imagine for one moment if it had been me or indeed you, or any other Labor member of this House or the other chamber, who had misled, however inadvertently, the parliament. Imagine what hue and cry the good Senator Baume would have engaged in. He went on for several pages in his personal attack on me—all because I pointed out that he had misled the Senate. Senator Baume thinks he can stand in the Senate and make any false allegation against me or members of my staff and we will not respond. Those days are over.

In my 12 years in this parliament I have attacked Senator Baume on only two occasions. Once was some years ago about his having kept a Commonwealth car waiting 1 1/2 hours while he attended a dental appointment, and recently I spoke on the motion condemning him for releasing the confidential tax file number of the state member for Manly, Dr Peter Macdonald. What did Senator Baume expect? That I would praise him for doing this?
I have here in my hand 58 pages—I repeat 58 pages—of personal attacks and denigration on me and often on my staff by Senator Michael Baume. On 30 March 1995 Senator Baume said about me in his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: I advise him—
Hollis—
to apologise to me before my patience with him runs out.

Mr Speaker, can you believe it? Can you really believe it? Who needs an abundance of patience? Me, with two minor attacks on Senator Baume over a 12-year period, or Senator Baume, after having made 58 pages of vicious, inaccurate attacks on me? Senator Baume also stated:
Frankly, I am sick and tired of Mr Hollis attacking me on a personal basis.

But Senator Baume, in his usual way, again raised in his 11 May 1995 speech allegations concerning my former employment at the Workers Educational Association and suggested that I table a report from a Coopers & Lybrand inquiry about me.

PARA.TAB: I suppose Senator Baume believes that if he makes these claims often enough someone might believe him. If he is so sure of his facts, let him repeat his claims outside of parliamentary privilege. This morning I received a letter from the executive director of the Workers Education Association. I wanted to table the letter and, in parliamentary practice, I approached the opposition member at the table, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), and he refused me permission. So I will now read the letter I received this morning into the Hansard. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Hollis,

I have received your letter of 31 May regarding various allegations, made under Parliamentary privilege, relating to the period when you were employed as the WEA Illawarra Regional Secretary. Firstly, I wish to stress, the WEA has not instigated any enquiries against you, secret or otherwise.
No enquiry has been made by the WEA Illawarra into your financial dealings and we have not supplied any information about you or any other former employee to any other person.

I and other members of the WEA have nothing but respect for your work with the WEA. During your employment with the WEA in the Illawarra you raised its profile and made it widely known in the community. I have never seen any hint of irregularity in your work with the WEA, nor am I aware of any minutes in which, it is claimed, you retrospectively approved payments to yourself.

We have the highest regard for your work with the WEA and can only suggest that you request that Senator Baume place his information on the public record. We are concerned that the WEA's name is being used for scoring political points. If you have precise details of the documentation mentioned by Senator Baume I would be pleased to provide them, if they exist.

That letter was signed by Eric Williams, the executive director. I request that Senator Baume repeat any allegation he has made about me regarding my employment with the WEA outside of the parliament. I stress that there will be no more 58 pages to three every time Michael Baume vomits his bile against me or my staff. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight because I noticed in the Hansard that last night the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) made a few comments about the game of rugby league. I think it is right that these comments should be made in this chamber at this time. I would like to also indicate my interest in the game of rugby league, as you would know, Mr Speaker, as vice-president of the very prestigious and very formative rugby league support group in Parliament House. I believe we are a group that can be asked for assistance in support of this great game of rugby league right across Australia, but I hasten to add that we take no position in the current dispute—only to see its end.

PARA.TAB: I join in the spirit of this debate because some 40 years ago I used to play the game myself. I have always encouraged my sons to play, but I can see very little comparison between the game we played then and the game that is played now—except that we played it for the sport of the occasion and not so much for the money. This is one of the changes the member for Werriwa mentioned last night. There have been great changes—a change in lifestyle and a change in social development and the expectations of people—to the code as we know it today. While we might regret some of the things that have happened, I believe they were inevitable.

I say to the member for Werriwa that I too was a great supporter of the St George Football Club when it was in what we knew as the Sydney Rugby League, for the very reason that it was the only club that would travel north during the off-season and play games against clubs such as Mackay. I do not think it ever left Mackay without having a win of something like 70-0 or 80-0, but the club was a great advocate of the game in Sydney and the pinnacle of anybody's support of the code was to look at Sydney.

We know that the Sydney code at that time, 20 or 30 years ago, was an organisation unto itself, and probably was world class. Since then, changing times have meant that it became the New South Wales Rugby League—as we had the Queensland Rugby League—and it has now become the Australian Rugby League.

We ought to look carefully at both sides of this argument to see what can be done to improve the situation. We need to look not so much at where the faults lie but at where the game should go from here. It could be said that the Australian Rugby League may not really have the facilities or the knowledge to take the game from a capital city sport to an Australian sport or, more importantly, to meet the international standards expected today.

Mr Speaker, I hate to mention the State of Origin last night in your presence. It was a great victory for Queensland, who were the underdogs. Even though the New South Wales team had better players, it did not have the teamwork to go with it. Queensland, who was the underdog, played well as a team. My heart goes out to Paul Vautin, to whom I offer my sincere congratulations. He took over what was regarded as an impossible job, and he did it so well. The players combined as a team and supported Paul Vautin last night.

This is a test of where football is in Australia. It is a test for those players who are regarded as Australian players but who missed out because they have gone to Super League or are going next year. I believe the performance of all the players last night demonstrated that second-fiddle footballers who will be called upon from time to time might just give those recognised players room for contemplation in relation to how they play and where they can go from here.

Let us settle this argument, but I believe some pertinent questions need to be answered before we can bring this to a finality. Who is on the board of the ARL? What is their expertise? Do they truly encompass all of Australia? I know that the Raiders and the Broncos have severe reservations about whether they fit nicely into that code. Who appoints the members? Who are they? What is their authority? Where do we go from here? Has the 20-team competition been a success? While the game is still being played, I believe that question has to be answered at the same time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Easson Mrs M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House the situation in the Italian community. As you are aware, Mr Speaker, my electorate of Lowe has a large number of residents who were born in Italy, although they have spent 30 years or more working and living in Australia. The contribution of these people to the growth and development of our country is beyond compare. Our quality of life is as high as it is directly because of the migration of Italians to this country.

PARA.TAB: In the 1990s many of these Australians who were born in Italy are of retirement age. It is incumbent upon this parliament to see that this well-earned retirement is made as comfortable as possible.I have had some personal experience of the difficulties faced by elderly retired persons of Italian sponsored retirement centres. It is a medical fact that, as some people age, their cognitive facilities decline and their comprehension weakens. This is often manifest by a reversion to their original language. Thus it is an actual occurrence—I have experience of it—that people who have lived for 40 years or more in Australia go into a retirement home and revert to their Italian language comprehension only. They lose totally the facility for the second language that they may have spoken for over 40 years. This may sound strange to members but it does occur.

The Scalabrini Village does excellent work in relation to these retirees, but it is hampered by the lack of Italian speaking nurses. It has Italian speaking staff, but nursing staff speaking Italian are needed because the elderly have need of medical attention. I understand that matters dealing with nursing are a state responsibility. I have written to the New South Wales Minister for Health, Dr Andrew Refshauge, and asked for his assistance in meeting this problem.

The matter is one of growing concern within the Italian community. The well-known and highly respected journalist Mr Paolo Totaro recently wrote of this matter in the Sydney Morning Herald. He made the point that Australia has avoided the ethnic troubles of other nations because our policy of inclusiveness was supported in a bipartisan manner and the authorities do not leave groups to flounder in our society.

Care and concern, by individuals and government bodies, have a major pay-off for a nation as a whole. We are a calm and peaceful society because of our superior policies in this field. These policies have been followed by governments of both persuasions for over 50 years. Now is the time for all members to look closely at the problems associated with the retirement of these persons who have come to Australia at our invitation over the past 15 years. Allow me to quote from the Totaro article:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the Italo-Australian community there are an estimated 3,500 Alzheimers sufferers. And there is an explosion of demand for bi-lingual nursing care, generally unavailable in hospitals. With immigration from all Mediterranean countries virtually closed for nearly a generation, there is little hope for those immigrant groups. The Federal government has allowed the entry of many nursers from Ireland. Good. But why not from the other countries.

I remember attending a function at such a retirement village—not an Italian one but another one in my electorate at Strathfield—where an elderly lady took hold of me by the hand. She talked to me for about 15 minutes and she would not let go of my hand. She was talking in a foreign language. When I asked the people who owned the place where she was from, they pointed out that nobody in the nursing home where she had been a resident for two years spoke her language. She spoke a dialect from a part of India, and there was no-one there to speak to her. Mr Speaker, you can imagine her isolation after being there for two years and having no-one to converse with. I may not have understood her words, but I certainly understood her problem. I want to help people like her, and I am sure that honourable members here would also want to help.

PARA.TAB: I think both the federal and state governments, as a matter of urgency, should cooperate and coordinate a policy that will allow for a rapid solution to the problem of the unfortunate lack of bilingual nurses. I am aware of the questions of accreditation and the like, but this problem is real and pressing. I am confident that, with goodwill, we can overcome the difficulties. These retirees enriched our lives and cultures. We owe them a great deal. It will be to our credit if we can ease their retirement and repay a little of the debt that we owe them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening, my colleague the member for Wentworth (Mr Thomson) raised a very interesting question: the mysterious investment record of the Reserve Bank's superannuation fund. Some other aspects of this should be on the record.

PARA.TAB: Over the past two, three, in fact four years, the OSF has been the top performing fund among all government sponsored superannuation funds in Australia. Some clue of the OSF's amazing performance in 1993-94 is to be found in the changes to the asset allocation. At the end of June 1994, just six weeks before the bank changed policy and began raising interest rates, the OSF's fixed interest weighting was zero. Thus the fund was conveniently quarantined from plunges in the bond market caused by the bank's change in policy. While the rest of Australia suffered as the bonds in our super funds lost value, members of the OSF were safe and getting safer.

What needs explanation now is how a superannuation fund can have no fixed interest assets. Did the OSF's investment consultant, Towers Perrin, recommend a nought per cent weighting for those assets? If it did not, why did the investment committee go below the recommended weighting? What did the members of the investment committee know that Towers Perrin and the rest of the market did not?

There is also the question of whether a breach of the superannuation fund law has occurred. It seems extraordinary that the trustees of a fund could legally reduce the fixed interest weighting of such a fund to zero. Such an aggressive investment strategy smacks of the worst excesses of the 1980s and is, on the face of it, highly speculative, especially coming from the Reserve Bank.

Presumably, the OSF's zero weighting in fixed interest assets is not still the case. The bank raised interest rates three times—the last being on 14 December 1994. Accordingly, we must ask when the OSF started buying fixed interest assets again. Did the investment committee buy bonds after 14 December 1994 and, if so, what did it know about the bank's monetary policy? Did it buy bonds before the governor of the bank, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or the Treasurer (Mr Willis) made any comment to the effect that further interest rate rises were unlikely?

What is deeply unfair for ordinary Australians—the vast majority of people locked into superannuation funds as a result of this government's policy—is that the people who managed the OSF are apparently able to engineer a higher performance for their own superannuation fund than that which the private sector funds can achieve for everybody else. Therefore, officers of the bank have to demonstrate publicly that no potential exists which would allow the impression to remain that there may be officers of the Reserve Bank who are apparently able to derive a benefit, while at the same time carrying out their activities on behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this House this week I challenged the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) to answer three simple questions about the $250,000 taxpayer funded sex guide which was published as a supplement to last December's issue of Cleo. My questions were sparked by an article about the controversial sex guide which appeared in the Sunday Mail on 30 April. In the article, the member for Lilley (Mr Swan) is quoted, in a letter to a constituent, as saying that the minister had `apologised for any offence caused by sections of the guide' and `because of concerns raised the guide is no longer being circulated'.

PARA.TAB: I then asked the minister three simple questions: had she in fact apologised for the sex guide, was she responsible for removing 40,000 extra copies from circulation and did she endorse the member for Lilley's reported quote that the guide contains `references to sodomy that should have been excluded'? A simple yes or no answer would have been sufficient. But alas, the minister let fly with a long self-justifying tirade that if we did not like the practices then we should not read the guide.

The minister also said that the guide is targeted at 18- to 35-year-olds. We are all well aware that women as young as 12 or 13 years of age are reading this publication and publications like it. In the Senate yesterday Senator Abetz asked whether the type of content found in the guide would be a suitable matter for discussion for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with his children around the table. To this, two government senators said that he was sick.

I think Senator Abetz made the point well. Indeed, it is sickening to think that the Prime Minister's kids, or anybody's kids for that matter, should be subjected to that sort of material. Although Senator Abetz made the point fairly provocatively, it raised the point that if it is not suitable material for the Prime Minister's kids, it is not suitable for any other kids around Australia.

If 40,000 copies of this guide were withdrawn from circulation and if the minister expended another $20,000 of taxpayers' funds, as a senate estimates committee revealed, on yet another evaluation of the guide ahead of the distribution of 40,000 guides, it says to me that the minister or her department have some grave misgivings about it because otherwise it would be in the marketplace.

Interestingly, 4,000 people in my electorate have voiced their objection to the guide. Senator Herron has tabled in the Senate over 100,000 signatures of people who object to the guide. Of the $250,000, $200,000 went to Australian Consolidated Press and $50,000 was associated with the distribution and publication of additional copies.

It is interesting that in Victoria school teachers were provided with copies of the guide by a well known condom manufacturer. I think this whole sorry episode illustrates that the guide is not something that should be treated with respect. The government is clearly uneasy about it and Senator Herron, a well-known colorectal surgeon, has said it is medically dangerous.

I do not dispute, and never have disputed, the need for genuine sex education. Preferably it should be delivered by parents, but if it is delivered in schools or in responsible publications I would have no beef with it. I do not oppose AIDS prevention measures and the necessary publications that go along with that. I object to a publicly funded guide—available to young people—parts of which promote as acceptable, normative and even titillating, practices that are medically and morally dangerous and arguably run contrary to the government's AIDS prevention measures. I think the reluctance of the minister to answer the specifics of this matter raises questions about whether the government promotes one line for public consumption while its members promote another modified, if not contrary view, to their individual constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today a tradition sacred to all the governments of Australia was broken in the ACT Legislative Assembly by the members of the Labor Party in conjunction with an Independent and the Greens. Today they voted to abolish the public recital of prayer to open the sessions of the assembly. That decision is a great shame and it should be reversed. The assembly has voted to abolish the prayer read by the Speaker at the start of proceedings on each day. Instead, they will be asked to stand in silence and stand in prayer. I say they will stand in shame.

PARA.TAB: The ACT is now the only assembly or parliament in Australia that will not start its day with morning prayer. Indeed, it is the only parliament in the entire Commonwealth, apart from Sri Lanka, that will now not start its day with prayer. Many people have approached the Speaker of the ACT assembly saying that they believe in Christian ideals and that it was good to dedicate the day to God by reciting a morning prayer. However, it would appear that the Labor Party, the Greens and Michael Moore have replaced this parliamentary tradition just to satisfy a minority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) spoke here a few moments ago about the Cleo article which was distributed throughout Australia and mentioned some of the activities of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in regard to this article. I also want to question whether the 40,000 copies of the Cleo article are actually being held within the department, which is my understanding, and whether once the assessment has been done she will then release them. I have the impression that, once the assessment has been done, she will have the reason why it is a good article to be released to the Australian public.
—Self-justification.

—Self-justification, exactly. It is very clear that, in using government funds to promote various practices, the minister is totally out of step with the thinking of Australian parents. It was illustrated in the Senate, as the member for Hinkler has stated, when the reply to a question asked by Senator Abetz was that it was sick for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to consider that he might use any of this material with his family. I guess that will be the reaction of most parents around Australia once they are provided with the material.

PARA.TAB: I wrote to the parents and friends of all the high schools and primary schools in my electorate and asked them whether they would support this type of thing. I will quote a few of the comments made by some of those schools. One of them said:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal government should not endorse an article written in a magazine because magazines use sensationalism.
Another school stated:
We believe sex education should be taught in schools but would strongly oppose this article being available to any school. We also do not support the federal government funding such material.
Again, another school said:
Members of our association were extremely unhappy and even offended such material should be published for young adults to read and therefore do not support the government's funding of such material.
Another one wrote:

The article was viewed by members of our association at our recent meeting and were overwhelming in their view that they did not support the funding of such material by the federal government or any government.

The feeling in the community is very clear from the 50 or so letters I got back from the associations of the schools. Some of the comments from association presidents really told the story. They told me that they usually do not deal with things from members of parliament, or give them much priority, but would hand the material around and let them read it.

PARA.TAB: The rest of the meeting was totally absorbed with this issue because of the abhorrence by parents that governments would be involved in peddling such information out to members of the community. They did not actually have to put the guide on the agenda. As soon it was passed around and the association started reading it, you can just imagine what happened—people's hair stood on end.

So what I am interested in is whether the health minister has actually put these 50,000 copies aside. It is interesting to note that when my office rang the health minister's office we were told there were no copies left. We got talking to Ansell and one or two other people we were associated with and they said, `Ring the department.' When we got to the department we found there were 50,000 copies left. Then we were told that there would be an assessment of the actual article.

I am interested in whether the minister, once she gets this assessment back from whatever group is doing it, is going to release the 50,000 copies of this article. Is she going to continue to promote these types of practices in our community when the overwhelming majority of Australian parents are absolutely horrified that a government would spend $250,000 on this type of junk material going out to Australian people—absolute junk material. There is no doubt about it. A lot of families could do a lot with $250,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Battlers.

—A lot of battlers—exactly—would prefer to see that money left in their pockets rather than taken out as taxation. Yet the government in this budget is going to increase taxation just to fund this type of material. (Time expired).

—This week will see another step in the National Rail Corporation's drive to make Australia's rail system that much more efficient, as we see the standard gauge open between Melbourne and Adelaide, and we know that we can now see a train go on the same gauge from Brisbane to Perth.
—Through your electorate.

—Yes, much of it through my electorate, as the honourable member says. In that context of the bigger picture, I want to talk about 15 people at Port Pirie who have lost their jobs because of AN's decision to close the workshop. It is a very difficult thing for me and for the government to explain to these people, who have met all the conditions of their enterprise agreement and multiskilling—and it is acknowledged that the workshop was highly efficient—why it is closed because it does not quite fit the bigger picture.

PARA.TAB: Naturally enough, in recent weeks I have met with AN, the unions, National Rail, et cetera. I have written to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). I have seen the workers personally. It is not as if they have been offered alternative employment. I think they are only going to be offered redundancy payments. It was very difficult, having seen them very busy, working and confident, to see them again just standing around—the work has been cut off; there is no work—demoralised.

Whilst the bigger picture may serve the national interest, we must be able to find a better way to help those people and to give them a stronger hope in the future. There are many regional towns and cities in this country that have had the guts ripped out of them by this transition over a long period of time. I would like it placed on the record tonight that we have to do a lot better to find these people work so that we can bring a stronger sense of morale and purpose to these regional towns and cities.

The bigger picture, whilst no doubt important in the national interest, has to accommodate these people at all times, particularly since they have fulfilled all the conditions—the enterprise agreement, multiskilling. I repeat: they have done everything right, yet they are out on their ear. Therefore, I bring that to the attention of the parliament. It is something that we all have to work a lot harder at to give these people a fairer deal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis), following the delivery of the budget a few weeks ago, said that they would go to the nation and on the airwaves in an endeavour to sell this document which we now know to be a very fraudulent and dishonest document. This morning the Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand, was interviewed on the very credible ABC radio program AM. Most members of the House, and many people throughout the country, listen to AM every morning. Unfortunately, the Treasurer was not honest on AM. He brought forward a large amount of disinformation. If the people listening to that program believed what the Treasurer said, they would have been misled and would have a different impression from reality. The Treasurer made a number of claims. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The budget was designed to take some pressure off interest rates by means of a fiscal tightening.
The reality is, according to the Commonwealth Bank, the budget does not alter the outlook for monetary policy to any great extent. The Treasurer further claimed:
This sort of growth means that we can maintain the strong approach to employment.

The reality is that the budget forecast of 3.75 per cent growth in 1995-96 is well below the 4.75 per cent annual average growth rate which the green paper stated was necessary to get the unemployment rate down to 5 per cent by the year 2000. The Treasurer said:
We're also seeing the continuance of low inflation.

The fact is that the implicit price deflator for private consumption rose by 1.2 per cent in the March quarter, following a rise of 0.2 per cent in the previous quarter. The Treasurer referred to certain comments made by the American Secretary for Labour. He said:

The United States and its Minister for Labour, Mr Reich, was at the conference complaining bitterly about the adverse effects on the American people of the way in which they deregulated their economy and had very adverse outcomes and lots of working poor. We don't have that problem either.

This nation has 750,000 workless poor. The unemployment rate in the United States is much lower than it is here. It is only 5.8 per cent there, compared with 8.3 per cent in Australia. According to the Union Bank of Switzerland's 1994 survey Prices and earnings around the globe, an unskilled builder's labourer in Los Angeles earns wages 90 per cent higher than a comparable labourer in Australia. The cost of living, excluding rent, in Sydney is 11 per cent higher than it is in Los Angeles. The Treasurer went on:
The government is not pursuing a low exchange rate strategy.

The reality is that in the budget speech the Treasurer boasted that Australia's international competitiveness was now 18 per cent higher than in the September quarter 1990. He said that this improvement in competitiveness was largely caused by a massive 16.6 per cent devaluation in the exchange rate. Why won't the Treasurer speak the truth? Why does the Treasurer insist on misleading those people who listened to the AM program this morning, who watch the television and see him on television and who listen to and read what he says? He went on:
Productivity was growing at 4.1 per cent for the non-farm market sector in the last 12 months.
Throughout the country output per hour worked in the entire Australian economy has grown by only 0.7 per cent over the year to March 1995. The Treasurer also said:
The budget was very much about . . . boosting superannuation in the medium to longer term to give a big increase to private sector savings.

Dr FitzGerald certainly put the lie to that when he said on Tuesday that national savings and investment would remain low unless taxes on savings incomes were deferred or removed. The household savings ratio fell to the lowest level ever recorded in the March quarter 1995. The Treasurer also claimed:
We have had in this nation four years of strong growth.
The GDP growth in the 15 quarters of recovery has been weaker than growth in the corresponding period after the 1982-83 recession. The Treasurer also claimed:
The people of Australia are not suffering reduced real wages.

Real wages in 1995 are lower than they were in 1983. This government has an absolutely appalling record. Is it any wonder that this government has no credibility when the Treasurer is prepared to say absolutely anything? He is misleading the people. He is prepared to put out misinformation in the hope of convincing people that the government has done a good job. (Time expired)
