PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.
Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Punch:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill could be described as an omnibus bill in the sense that it amends a number of pieces of legislation which affect the Australian Defence Force and the organisation of the Australian defence forces. It must be well known to many members in this House that my primary interest in defence stems from the fact that the Puckapunyal army base lies within the federal electoral division of McEwen.

PARA.TAB: In fact, there are a number of people in this House today who were recently at Puckapunyal during the conduct of the biannual exercise known as El Alamein where the Army, in conjunction with the Royal Australian Air Force, showed trainees and foreign representatives and members of the Australian parliament the operation of particular types of weapons. For those who were not there may I suggest that in two years time when the Australian Army again conducts El Alamein they make themselves aware of that fact and seek to be invited by the Army to attend that particular activity.

Whilst I support this legislation there are some matters which do cause me some concern. One such matter is in the area of discipline and it arises from the fact that I am both a former member of the police force and a former practising lawyer. I have often thought that members of the Defence Force have fewer rights in the disciplinary area than ordinary civilians or other people who are subjected to quasi or criminal law or other disciplinary type proceedings.

I suppose that is common in defence forces around the world and I suppose there are strong historical reasons for it. Members of the Defence Force—Navy, Army or Air Force—have always been subject to on-the-spot discipline by senior officers, yet they have not always been allowed access to normal legal rights in terms of these charges that you and I or other people in the community would have. However, it is true to say that over the years there has been an improvement in the nature of military discipline and in the nature of how Defence Force personnel are brought before senior officers, boards of review and court martials to have matters heard.

One of the things I have a concern about in this legislation is the amendment which will allow a person to be charged for failing to provide a body specimen—most commonly a urine sample—on the order of a senior officer. Obviously, the main purpose of this amendment is to exercise a degree of drug control. It would surprise no-one to hear that the Defence Force is subject to the same problems as the rest of society in that many of the young people there use the product of the Cannabis sativa plant, marijuana, and smoke it.

I am the first to agree that I would not like to be out on a live firing range with a person under the influence of any drug, be it alcohol or the Cannabis sativa THC component. I can understand that it would be appropriate and proper for reasonable action to take place to prevent people from engaging in such activities if they are involved with live ammunition, particularly the sort we have today. However, it seems to me that there is no limitation in the legislation on when or where an officer can approach another person in the Defence Force and say, `I want a urine specimen here and now.' Frankly, that worries me, although the minister next to me quite rightly has pointed out that it does provide that the person must be in custody, and it was neglectful of me not to point that out.

Nevertheless, the person might be in custody for a matter which is not relevant to a drug-taking offence and it seems to me that that power should be limited to allegations that the person on whom the order is made has been involved with a drug-taking offence and is not just simply in custody for another purpose. There could be, for example, an allegation of theft, and yet, once the person is in custody, the legislation appears to allow for an order to be made to provide a urine sample which could lead to other charges not related to the reason for the original custody. So I do express some concern on that, though fully understanding that any defence force organisation would want to make sure that people who use drugs which can affect performance in the handling of ammunition are properly protected and properly disciplined or, hopefully, counselled in the use of such drugs in such circumstances.

I must say that having seen, at the El Alamein exercises, what a Leopard tank will do with its 105-millimetre cannon, impact shells, high explosives shells and the rest of its armaments, and the machine-guns it also lets loose with, I would hate to think of any person sitting in one of those vehicles who had a view of the world affected by alcohol or other drugs. So I can fully concur with the need to do something about it. But I really think there should be a bit tighter control in the legislation to restrict the capacity to seek an order to provide a urine sample to areas where there is an allegation, at least, of drug involvement.

There are some other matters which also give me some degree of concern. Whilst this legislation does improve the discipline capacity of the Defence Force and loosens up some of the more rigid procedures that have been there in the past, there is a provision for the appointment of what will be known as `discipline officers.' The discipline officer will basically be appointed to take on the role and the powers of the commanding officer to hear disciplinary procedures against people allegedly in breach of defence or army law or other Defence Force law.

There seems to be nothing in the legislation which would say that the disciplinary officer has to have any particular qualification or any particular training. I know that, certainly in the Army, when the cadets go through officer training they are, in fact, trained in all aspects of defence law and to act as a disciplinary person, particularly with other ranks. That has been a tradition in the Army, certainly, for a number of years. As I know from when I was a young private myself, in the CMF days, discipline was instant and by a senior officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that in the Boer War?

—No, it was not the Boer War. However, it is unarguable that this is a more benign way of handling discipline in the Army than what it was. Nevertheless, it seems to be that if we are going to have specialised officers—officers who are going to be called `discipline officers' and who will take on a specific role in hearing summary matters, not court martial matters, for disciplinary purposes—they should at least have some degree of specialised training before they are appointed. So I must add that that tends to worry me a bit. It would be nice to think that a discipline officer has, in fact, been given some specific training and, when acting in the role of a discipline officer, will have that specific skill and be able to respond accordingly at any hearing that takes place.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of infringement notices is also quite interesting. I must say that it has taken a long while for the Defence Force to catch up with the rest of law enforcement in Australia. But it is good to see that there is the capacity to issue an infringement notice which gives the person to whom the notice has been issued the option of accepting the penalty provided for in that notice—which, as civilians, we all understand, with speeding charges, for example—or to seek a hearing to have that matter dealt with.

I can tell those who do not know that the `red caps'—the military police—at Puckapunyal are certainly very assiduous in enforcing speed restrictions there. The speed restrictions are quite narrow: 20 or 40 kilometres per hour in most of the areas where the establishments are and particularly where the army personnel live. Where the married quarters are in the housing areas at Puckapunyal, for example, from memory there is a 20 kilometres per hour and a 40 kilometres per hour speed limit. I can say without question that the military police there are assiduous in ensuring that people do not speed past those areas. So this will certainly improve the capacity of the Australian Defence Force military police to issue infringement notices and to deal with them. I think the minister would agree that it would also save a bit of money and would be a good budgetary proposal. It might even make a bit of money.

In my experience, since infringement notices came into Victoria for traffic offences, they seem to get issued at twice the rate that summons were ever issued to appear in court. Certainly, the Victoria Police gains 20 per cent of its current budgetary allocation from the money it raises from infringement notices and that tended to worry a lot of motorists in Victoria. You wonder whether the police are there to in fact make revenue for themselves or whether, in fact, they are there—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not just Victoria!
—Is it not just Victoria, then? It is a problem all over Australia.
—You are ruining his political point, Maggie!

—Yes. And I suppose that if we see speed cameras in Puckapunyal, I might go in in reverse, instead of frontwards, because there are certainly enough speed cameras around my roads at the moment. Overall, in looking at this legislation, I have mainly been concerned with the disciplinary matters. I note also that tape recordings of confessions or admissions are now to be introduced into the system. Again, that is something I support. So apart from some concerns that I expressed about the power to force people to provide urine in certain circumstances, and the capacity and training of discipline officers, I think the legislation has a lot going for it and it has my full support.

—My concern is with the morale of our service men and women, the operational efficiency of our armed forces, the wellbeing of the Australian taxpayer and the harmonious condition of society. The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill is very wide-ranging. It deals with many subjects, in particular, the conditions under which our military personnel serve, and even defence housing. In that context, I would like to make a few comments about the relocation of military bases away from North Head and Middle Head in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: Last month, in answer to a question on notice from me, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) declared that the bases were to close and that the land would be sold on the open market for the best possible price. This gives me a number of concerns. First, there is the economic concern. These bases inject $40 million in wages every year into the economy of Warringah. They provide 1,200 jobs and it is inconceivable that any alternative source of employment could be found to match that.

Second, there is the environmental concern. We are talking about—in North Head and Middle Head—the last unspoiled headlands on Sydney Harbour. These headlands are not so terribly different today from what they were when Captain Cook sailed past 225 years ago. These headlands are, if you like, the sacred sites of modern Australia and potentially a symbol of the determination of modern Australia to live, as best modern men and women can, in harmony with our environment. The idea that visitors coming to Sydney for the 2000 Olympics should sail down our harbour and, instead of seeing the bushland on those headlands more or less in its natural condition, should see the glaring neon signs for a Club Med on North Head and a Mirage on Balmoral is absolutely appalling. Yet that is exactly what seemed to be contemplated by the minister's answer to my question on notice.

Finally, we come to the operational concern. Obviously, the defence forces have got to be configured in such a way as to maximise their operational efficiency, but it seems quite clear that moving these bases away from North Head and Middle Head is motivated not so much by better running of the defence forces as by the government's need to improve its budget bottom line. Indeed, real estate agents have estimated that, if all of that land were sold on the open market, something like $2 billion could be realised.

I turn now to the particular case of the school of artillery on North Head. In the wake of the announcement by the Minister for Defence that those bases were to move, he confirmed that the school of artillery is to move from North Head to Puckapunyal within five years. Notwithstanding the many goods works of the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), Puckapunyal is in fact the least favourite destination of Australia's service personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The North Shore is much more popular!

—It is much better represented in parliament, I suppose. But a recent issue of the Army's magazine ranked various bases in terms of their desirability as locations, and Puckapunyal was motherless last. It is, if you like, the defence equivalent of being sent to Siberia. The rationale for shifting the school of artillery is that it needs to be next to a firing range, and I accept the logic of that. The problem is that moving the school of artillery to Puckapunyal will put it next to a firing range, but it is a firing range that lacks any guns to fire! If a battery of guns were to be moved permanently to Puckapunyal to justify putting the school of artillery there, that would effectively double the size of the school of artillery. The school of artillery would have gone from 100 or so personnel, as it is now, to 200 or so personnel, if a battery were permanently based at Puckapunyal to justify this shift.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, shifting the school of artillery to Puckapunyal is going to be an expensive business. It could be $10 million or $15 million: who knows how many millions? However many millions will be involved, the problem is going to be compounded because $2 million has just been spent at North Head to refurbish the school of artillery. Not only that, but the army's maritime school, which is going to be moved from Chowder Bay up to Townsville—a move which, I concede, seems to make more operational sense—has just had $6 million spent on it. So here we have bases that have just been refurbished at very considerable expense and that are about to be closed down. This strikes me as a most serious logistical bungle, in the great traditions of the Crimea. And, of course, it is potentially an environmental bungle, in the great tradition of the government's woodchip decision.

Let me assure this House that the people of my electorate are solidly determined to keep the military there, if at all possible. And they are absolutely determined that there shall be no further development on those headlands. In my electorate, two very well attended public meetings—one of 300 people at Manly about a month ago, and another of 500 people at Mosman about a week ago—have made it absolutely clear that they want no commercial development on North Head and Middle Head and that, if possible, they wish to keep the military there.

If the military goes, the government will not be able to sell that land. These dreams of a pot of gold at the end of its budgetary rainbow are simply dreams. The land will not be sold because, to sell land, you have got to give potential buyers permission to develop it, and there is no way that any responsible government confronted with the reality of the environmental jewels that these headlands are would allow the sort of development that would enable that land to be sold for the sort of price that would make moving these bases worth while.

If the military moves, the reality will be that my electorate will lose 1,200 jobs. The Australian taxpayer will needlessly spend tens of millions of dollars and these bases will, in effect, become military ghost towns. If the government does try to sell that land and if developers do try to put Club Meds or Skase Mirages on it, there will be an environmental ruckus that will make the Franklin Dam fight look tame.

I appeal to the government to see sense on this matter, to rethink its decision to move these bases and, in particular, to rethink the decision to move the school of artillery. As the New South Wales Premier, Mr Bob Carr, has made harbour protection one of the priorities of his government, I appeal to him to show that he wants to protect the harbour east of Garden Island and to show that his concern for the harbour is not limited to areas to the west of Garden Island.

Lest anyone think this is a matter which concerns only the residents of Mosman and Manly, the other day I received a petition which was signed by over 400 people from Penrith. People in the Labor heartland are just as concerned about the threat to Sydney Harbour as people in the Liberal heartland. This issue unites people across the political spectrum. The speakers I have had at public meetings in my electorate include Tom Uren, the former deputy leader of the Labor Party here in this place; Peter MacDonald, the independent state member for Manly; Doug Sutherland, the former Labor Lord Mayor of Sydney; and Barry O'Keefe, the Chairman of the National Trust of Australia. This issue unites people of all political persuasions. It is a message which the government should listen to.

Just the other day the government promised to spend $53 million on coastal protection. I applaud anything that the government does to protect our coastline. The best thing the government could do now is rule out commercial development on military land at North Head and Middle Head. In so doing, it would not be spending a cent of taxpayers' money. I make this commitment: I will seek a pledge from the coalition that the Howard government will say that this is a no-go area for commercial development and that military land on North Head and Middle Head will never be sold.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to speak briefly on the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. For a moment I wondered whether I was in the right place because I could not see any relevance to the bill in the speech made by the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott). I cannot say I blame him for taking the opportunity to latch onto the word `defence' and go off on another tack, but he is lucky that nobody called a point of order.
—They were all so interested in what I had to say.

—Absolutely fascinated. We found out you are a greenie. That is a great surprise. I do not know what the honourable member has against Club Med, but I do not think there is going to be one built on the Sydney shoreline. In the lead-up to talking about the bill, I want to talk about the Australian Defence Force generally. This year we commemorate the 50th anniversary of the ending of World War II. It is also the 80th anniversary of the landing on Gallipoli and the 20th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War. Our service personnel and ex-service personnel have been in the limelight. They have been attending commemoration services and other functions and have been very much in evidence.

PARA.TAB: Australia has a proud record in its defence forces. Even before Australia was a federated nation, we were sending troops to foreign wars. Most of the wars that our troops have been involved in have been other people's wars. From the Sudan and the Boxer Rebellion through to the Vietnam War and the Gulf War, and through two world wars, we have lost a total of 94,000 of our service people. For a small country, that is a huge contribution in lives. Working with the United Nations, our troops are now very much involved in peacekeeping efforts throughout the world. For the size of our country, that contribution has been disproportionate.

The defence forces also play a strong community role. I thought the member for Warringah might have alluded to that when defending the defence forces in his electorate. In my electorate, RAAF base Richmond carries out a very strong role in the local community. I do not think anyone could have not been aware of the bushfires of January 1994. The RAAF personnel, as well as the army and navy personnel, who came to my electorate, played a very strong role in hazard reduction, firefighting and looking after evacuees from nursing homes. Several nursing homes in my electorate were evacuated to HMAS Nirimba at Quakers Hill, which has now been turned into an education facility, and to the RAAF hospital at Richmond. Of course, the Richmond area is more often prone to floods than to bushfires, and defence personnel have done a very strong job in that field also.

Coming from a service family myself, I know what it is like to have a father who is hardly ever there—a man who walks in wearing a uniform, about whom a child has to say, `Mummy, who is this man?'. Of course, it disrupts family life. I am sure that those, like myself, who went through the war years with a father absent will know that one can never really develop a strong relationship with a person with that kind of disruption in the family. I think it is very important that we be aware of those things.

Our services, like the British services on which they were modelled, have been built on tradition. I know that those in the services will still talk about some of the quaint traditions of some of the services. But those things, even though they might be nice historic things, have to change as we progress into a more modern age, to bring them in line with civilian life and life in the broader community.

One example is the number of women who are now joining the defence forces. When the previous chief of the defence forces, Admiral Beaumont, visited RAAF Richmond, he made it very clear to the personnel there that change was happening and they would have to accept change. I think he went as far as to say that, if they did not like the change towards more women coming into the services, they ought to consider another kind of life. I think the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) alluded yesterday to the fact that we might one day have a woman in one of those senior positions in the defence forces. I hope it is in the not too distant future.

When we look at those traditions, we have to move on. When I was reading the explanatory memoranda of this bill, one of the phrases that jumped out at me concerned officers holding their appointments `at the Governor-General's pleasure'. What immediately came into my mind was a court where somebody was sentenced to jail at the Queen's pleasure. Perhaps some officers might consider it to be some kind of incarceration! I think that is among the anachronisms that we have to work through and to change.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the President's pleasure, perhaps.
—At the Prime Minister's pleasure.
—It will not be at anybody's pleasure, if this bill goes through, and it will go through.

PARA.TAB: Those kinds of practices are not in line with modern employment practices in the public service or in the corporate sector. I think that change to the way appointments are made, to bring them more in line with the contracts for specified periods that happen in other fields, is a move forward. That minor change which allows the minister to appoint acting senior officers when the Chief of the Defence Force and his or her deputy are absent for some reason is also a very good move.

So are the limited tenure promotions for particular projects. Those might be looked at askance by some people. But, if they look at the legislation, they will see that those people do have a right to refuse. That is something that happens elsewhere, particularly in the public service: people act up in higher positions for a while, then either look for other positions at that grade or move back to their substantive positions. I think that is another way of moving forward, to bring the service life into line.

That also goes for the early retirement provisions and the termination provisions. We have all heard and I am sure we all know of people who have been, as we say, `promoted beyond their capacity' because there has not been a facility to move them on if they are not performing well or if what they are doing has reached the end of its shelf life. I think those provisions are about moving into line with modern life.

I noticed that my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) focused, considerably, on the discipline provisions. I think it is appropriate that the government has announced in its justice statement that it is making the law more accessible to people. It is taking out some of the traditional systems so that people can get access to the law much more easily, and so that situations can be mediated and settled without the need for a court. In this case it will mean that some of those things can be dealt with without the need for a court martial. So those are the main provisions. I do not intend to talk about them at length because I think the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Punch) has done that very adequately in his second reading speech.

The bill includes some other small measures. For example, the measure relating to Defence Force home loans fixes up the gap that some people fell through. Unfortunately, those things sometimes happen but, fortunately, we catch them and fix them in legislation. There are also some superannuation provisions in the bill. Superannuation is considered by the government to be something that is extremely important. The provisions that we brought in in the budget will ensure that more people are involved in saving for their retirement in schemes that will provide them with a decent living when they cease working. Of course, the defence forces have always had a superannuation facility but these provisions will bring them more into line with the broader community. This bill is one of a number of measures which the government introduces to bring previous legislation and regulations up to date and keep us at the level of 1995. I commend the bill and thank the House for the opportunity to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse some of the changes in the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill; I think they are overdue. The disciplinary area becomes simpler and allows for matters of smaller or lesser disciplinary importance to be conducted at the appropriate level. I do not look forward to the day when we have members of the armed forces appearing in a civil type court with legal defence but we are moving in that direction.

PARA.TAB: The ministers will say, `What is wrong with that?' I say that, up until this point in Australia's history, we have looked upon the defence of Australia as a profession that is somewhat different, where persons in some instances have to, without hesitation, respond to a direction. Perhaps it is the intention of the government that we have public service type meetings in the Department of Defence before we do anything. If that is the government's intention, it will achieve that objective. I see elements of that process in the way in which the government has brought forward this legislation.

I need to go through the legislation in some detail. These changes are about getting the pyramids right, basically. The pyramids are out of shape. A number of personnel at various levels within the Defence Force are capable of adjusting, but it can be done only by a slow process because we have permanent commissioned officers in the services. The government has got the system out of whack and now it is going to provide some sort of temporary term of tenure, a renewable contract to get the pyramids right.

In 1990 the government reduced the Defence Force from 22,500 to 17,500. In that process the pyramids went out of shape, and at that time it had to introduce a way in which it could get rid of some of the people at the top. It was stuck with an executive class, an executive level of management above what was required. At the same time as it was pursuing this process, it was proclaiming what an efficient and brilliant defence force Australia had. Those opposite adopted a typical Labor approach to defence, cutting defence at the same time as saying that they were improving it, and in fact they were going on balancing the budget. Where did that practice get us? The military has provided a lot of dollars to the Australian economy. The savings made in defence alone are very large indeed, if we look at the number of personnel that have been moved out of the system. The government has decided to move them out of the system, and it has gone on with record deficits, record bankruptcies and record unemployment.

So the sacrifice, if you want to put it in those terms, paid by one section of Australia's security system has been substantial, and to no avail. The government has not been able to produce the results in cutting defence that, for instance, Thatcher was able to produce in Britain or the successive American regimes have been able to produce in that country, because they have gained advantage for the whole nation by reducing their military commitment. But the Australian Labor Party does not see things in that light, because what it does see is the need to stay in power no matter what the cost or who pays. Nothing is too good for the worker or his representative. That is the theme.

Dealing with the legislation before us, it is about the whole process that I have outlined, about the reduction at the whim of the government of a certain level of defence personnel. It is seeking to get its pyramids right, and I see it as a breakdown of the permanent commissioning of officers. There is no doubt about that. It is a public service approach to managing defence. The government wants to move in that direction, but I do not agree that it is the best direction for us to take. I think that we are getting people in there who adopt the attitude of `Is this a temporary career or a permanent career for me?', and they are in and out of the military as they are in and out of the Department of Environment, Department of Treasury, Department of Finance or wherever their career may lead them.

We are getting to a point, I would suggest, where we are going to have a pick-up approach. It is not mercenary—that is an overstatement—but it is `Come and join the team, because we have got a thing going at the moment, and we will pay you off when the event is over.' The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Punch) can shake his head, but the fact of the matter is that he does have to acknowledge that there are term contracts, people are going to be paid out at the end of those terms, and there is political interference to a degree that I have not seen before, with ministerial interference. I refer to the explanatory memorandum. Where does the minister's role come in, in the decisions regarding brigadier and under brigadier, two stars and under? The minister has a say in that process. That has not been the process until now, as far as advancement, selection of personnel or termination is concerned.

The trouble is that it is a politicisation of a career structure that should not have politics played in it. One of the proud things that Australia has had is a military completely divorced from politics. The minister thinks that it is all right to put people in positions that he wants them to be in. You meet them in a mess or in a ward room and you say, `He is a nice guy and he is politically onside. Why do not we see him move a little quicker through the system?' That politicisation will ultimately destroy the relationship between the military and the political wings of government. It is what happens in every other nation, but it is not a worry to the Australian Labor Party because, again, anything it does in its cause is justified. And I believe that that is what it is doing with this legislation. It is clear to me that ministers now have a role in the promotion and careers of people in the military. The government can apply its will to that process.

My understanding is that previously the only role a minister ever had as the chief of the Defence Force was in choosing a candidate from a list put forward by the military asking which one the minister would prefer. The minister would not necessarily get his preference as chief of defence. Now we are going to have ministers who want to manipulate and who want to play games by interfering at a lower level. I do not think that this is in the best interests of Australia.

What we are moving towards is the politicisation of the military. This will produce a politicised military process in 20 to 50 years time. We will have the situation that exists in Papua New Guinea, and everywhere else where the military can decide that it is in politics, saying, `These guys at the top are not doing what we want and we want to take an active role.' Just think of where we are moving: it is a direction that we should not contemplate.

Having received all the advice, the minister will come back to me and say, `It really does not matter; it is a small thing; there used to be interference in the past.' I understand how it has been explained to you, and I understand your response.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were trying to work out what you were saying.

—But my point is that your explanation will not satisfy me. We move to conditions of service. I want to make a plea to the government to stop pursuing the course of making the military a public service type organisation. It is resented by everybody on the ground. They may be called upon to give their lives. They may be required to go to any part of the world at any time. Yet the government expects the military to adopt conditions of service which are increasingly like those of the public service. The government is aligning the whole of the military process to the public service. This is occurring step by step.

PARA.TAB: For instance, there is the family allowance supplement for below award employment. What did the government do with that? The public servants said that these military employees were below award, and the government decided to give them the family supplement. That was a good decision. But then the public service said, `They are getting subsidised housing.' It might be a dog box somewhere, anywhere that they are sent to in Australia. Because those employees were getting subsidised housing, the public servants wanted to include the value of that subsidised housing in the process, saying, `We cannot let them get one little edge on what are seen as the Canberra bureaucratic standards,' and so that was brought into the system for other ranks.

Have a look at what these people have done. We are listening to people who have an envy factor built into their decisions and their advice. They do not look at what is happening on the ground. People are required to live anywhere, move anywhere at any time and give their lives at any time. To take away that subsidised housing—say, subsidised housing in the Northern Territory at Tindal—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong.
—No, I am not saying you have, but it is counted as part of their benefits and you have removed the family supplement for some—
—Wrong.
—You have removed for some the family supplement—
—Wrong.
—Because you are now considering—
—You are wrong.
—Nothing has changed—
—Wrong.
—You are not considering subsidised housing?
—Wrong.
—You are considering subsidising housing?
—You are dead wrong.
—You are considering subsidising housing?
—To you, what happened 12 months ago is news.

—Come on! Are you considering subsidised housing? Come on! You tell me that you are not; that you have restored everything exactly. If that was your intention, you changed your mind. You changed your mind because you had done something that was wrong. What about the Tax Commissioner? Subscription to a mess is not a tax deductible item. Are you going to deal with that? That is a popular one round the service. Union fees are deductible, but subscription to a mess is not deductible. Tell me about that one. The minister is happy to keep that one running. He is not going to advance the cause of other ranks, or of anybody else in that regard. He is quiet on that one; he changed his mind on the other one. Twelve months ago, the minister had to change his mind because of reaction in the service. On this one, he will not change his mind; he is silent on it.

PARA.TAB: Let us now deal with the concept of shift workers and penalties. What are the government's comments on that? Forty hours work is paid at a lower rate. There is an allowance paid for extra hours of work, but at nothing like overtime rates. Most servicemen do not mind, except that the government then plays on that and expect officers to take time in lieu. Maybe that is a good way to go. As the government runs down the whole process, regrettably the demand on personnel becomes stronger and stronger. Maybe the Australian Labor Party thinks this is good legislation and that this is the way the defence forces of Australia ought to go. I am sorry, but I do not think that way.

I believe that the permanent commissioning of officers is something that has given us a good professional service, and I have yet to have it explained to me why that is not so. I would like the minister to explain to me how there is not a degree of politicisation in this. I would like to know why the Defence Force is now going to start to answer to government instead of to a chief who is above that process. The member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) seems to think that not having an indefinite Commander-in-Chief is a good thing. I do not know whether that concept is a good one or not.

To make the decision as to whether or not to go to war, we have something of a unique process in Australia. We have not got a president who makes that decision. Maybe that is where the government wants to go: to have a president or a prime minister who will make that decision. Nobody knows what the government's views are, because it will not talk about them. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will not even say what he believes the republic should be about. So where does the concept of Commander-in-Chief fit into this? Do government members know? Have they worked it out? No, they have not. They do not know where that process ends. Maybe it stops with the Minister for Defence. Is that where it stops? There are questions being asked out in the community because nobody knows what the government's answers are. Such questions are being asked, and the people want to know. I do not believe that the government has the answers, because it has not thought through the matter of where this stuff takes us.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Before moving into committee to deal with the government amendment, which is a relatively minor issue, I should take the opportunity to rebut, as far as one can, some of the things that have been said, particularly this morning, by the opposition, and also yesterday by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). It can all be best summed up by the fact that the right honourable member for New England, as only he can—no matter how long he has been here, there are still not many that are better, one has to say—in his finest rhetoric, yesterday referred to the old traditions of the rum and the lash. I hope the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) is not going; I have got a lot to answer—
—You are going to sell North Head, aren't you!

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Order! The member for Mitchell has had his turn!

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) came in this morning and talked about the finest traditions of the Crimea. Nothing in this place can illustrate more how far behind the opposition is in matters of defence, in comparison with the government. What we now have in this country is in complete contrast to 20 years ago, when those people on the opposition side of the House could reasonably be said to have described themselves as the natural party of government in terms of defence and defence issues. No longer is that so: the roles are reversed. Clearly, not only do opposition members not understand what is going on in the defence forces but also, judging from the level of their contributions this morning, they do not have any interest.

PARA.TAB: Some opposition members have not even bothered to do their homework to check up on a few things—in stark contrast to the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who is the shadow minister, and in stark contrast to the right honourable member for New England, who bothered to acquaint himself about a whole range of issues. Let me deal with a number of points, and firstly with those of the member for Mitchell, who has scurried out of this place. If I had been he, I think I would have done so, too. His first point was that we seem to want to make the military like the public service, that we are going to `public service-ise' the military. But anyone who had read the white paper would know that nothing could be further from the truth.

The government is setting out to explain to the bureaucracy and both sides of politics in this town, and, more importantly, to the public, that military service is like nothing else. As it gets more and more technically oriented and more and more demanding, the public, the bureaucracy and both sides of politics must accept that military service is like nothing else. It has to be treated differently, with all sorts of different allowances and discretions. That is in the white paper; it comes from the government. A lot of what is in that chapter was written by my good self. The contribution on that point from the member for Mitchell could not be further from the truth.

The same honourable member went on to talk about reduction in numbers. I do not know whether he reads the international press but, if he had a look at what the British, the Americans, the Germans and so many other countries are doing, he would see that they are reducing their armed forces by numbers far in excess of Australia's. Savings from our 15 per cent force structure review reduction in numbers from the early 1990s have been ploughed back into defence on capital expenditure and increased personnel costs which we will have to continue. The honourable member ought to have a good hard look at that.

Let me take the opportunity to shatter, once and for all, a few of the salient myths that the opposition likes to cling to about defence expenditure and `them versus us'. The front page of the Australian on 21 November 1991 stated, `Defence budget to drop by $500 million.' That is the opposition's policy. The opposition is still wedded to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was yesterday.

—Successive defence spokesmen have not had the smarts that the right honourable member has had to walk away from it. That is the opposition's policy. The opposition is stuck with it and I am going to keep reminding them of it.

PARA.TAB: Further, let me say—here is a little shocker for you—that what the opposition ought to do is go back to the Department of Defence and ask it for the defence function outlays in constant dollar prices. The member for Mitchell will find that the government has spent more every year on defence, in constant dollar prices, than the opposition did in seven years. In constant dollar terms and 1995 prices the highest the opposition got was $8,142 million. This year it is $9,992 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about wastage.
—The opposition has a major credibility problem with this issue.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Order! The members present are not helping.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Mitchell went on to say that our troops were out there in the scrub living in dog boxes. The honourable member obviously has not been near a DHA housing estate for a long time. I will give honourable members another little statistic. The government is spending six times more on defence force housing than the opposition spent. The member for Mitchell has the audacity to stand up here and say that defence personnel are out there living in dog boxes.

PARA.TAB: The member went on to say that when the social security changes were brought in the lower ranks lost their family supplement. I think he meant to say that the lower ranks lost their extra family payment. He is quite right. That situation threatened the lower ranks for a short while. About 12 months ago we resolved that situation by reversing and changing it. On our best advice, none of them are affected. That was done in full negotiation between myself and the Minister for Social Security. So, again, the honourable member is wrong.

The member for Mitchell raised the issue of the tax commissioner and mess fees. He should know that I have personally discussed this with the tax commissioner and that there is a working party between Defence and the Taxation Office. The member ought to know that, if push comes to shove and we cannot get our way on this, the defence forces will challenge the taxation ruling on mess fees. We will not hesitate; we will not blink. So he is wrong on that too.

Then the honourable member talked about overtime and the service allowance. Again, he has missed the news. There has been a relatively recent increase in the service allowance. It was not a couple of dollars; it was 16.6 per cent. I invite the honourable member to go back and find out whether that ever happened under the opposition.

Let me turn to the matters raised by the honourable member from Warringah. I have to give credit where credit is due. He is pretty good at beating the drum when an election is approaching. As one professional politician to another, I have got to say that I respect that ability. But, just in case the truth gets in the way of a good story, I want to correct the record.

`Club Med on North Head': a good Sunday paper headline special, is it not? Let me say publicly what we have said before and most directly to him. This government is committed to the preservation of the natural bushland areas on North Head. Any transfer of those areas will carry enforceable obligations to ensure their bushland state. We are ensuring, and will ensure, that the significant historic sites and buildings are preserved.

In a similar situation at Middle Head, our department has joined with the local councils and the New South Wales Department of Planning in undertaking management strategies for that area before disposal. The central objective of the study is to provide what options and guidelines will be needed. That is going to rest very squarely on community consultation with provision for the community, including the councils, to have their say.

Of course, a steering group has been established, which includes community representatives, state and federal MPs—including the honourable member for Warringah—the mayor of Mosman, the Heritage Commission and the National Parks and Wildlife Service. If Club Med ends up on North Head or Middle Head, it will be with the concurrence of the Mosman or the Manly council and the honourable member for Warringah. So let us end this rot.

He also went on to say that we should keep the artillery school at North Head. I have to say that it is somewhat inappropriate to have an artillery school which is a long way from the field firing range in the middle of the city. It just does not work. This situation has been recognised for many years. Honourable members will recall that, in the early 1980s, when the government was trying to acquire a site in Bathurst-Orange area, this idea was dropped.

The honourable member for Warringah's central point is in regard to the sort of support that will be available and what it will be. I want to place on record that the relocation of the 103rd medium artillery from Holsworthy to Darwin will precipitate a situation, and has always been going to precipitate a situation, where the army would be forced to address the field artillery support for the school regardless of its location. The provision of a depot support battery is, of course, being examined as part of the army structural review.

The honourable member for Warringah, I must admit in much less spectacular fashion than the honourable member for Mitchell, is way off beam. He has not done his homework; he does not understand the issues.

In the rest of the time available, I will seriously address the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. The right honourable member for New England raised a number of points yesterday. These points were quite worth while and they should be answered. Far from what the honourable member for Mitchell was saying about political interference, political appointments and senior armed forces people, I think it has to be stressed in this place that the move to have acting appointments made by the minister as opposed to the Governor-General is for short-term vacancies only. It has to be said that these are where difficulties have arisen in the past and they will obviously continue to arise if an acting appointment is required at short notice. Of course, there are precedents for this approach. The acting appointment as Judge Advocate General under the Defence Force Discipline Act is made by the minister through substantive appointment, although the substantive appointment, as is the case here, continues to be made by the Governor-General.

So there is absolutely no substance to what the member for Mitchell was saying. But in response to the member for New England one has to emphasise that these are short-term appointments and are designed to make the system work far better. A number of members raised the disciplinary issues. I think the member for New England did also and he, in particular, raised the question of whether there should be a quasi-judicial hearing in relation to the suspension from duty. I think the crux of the matter is that the refusal to submit to a medical examination will be an offence where a person is already in lawful custody. So it is a very serious issue already.

TALK.START.PARA: —No problems with that.
—Yes, and it is in respect of a service offence—
—It is drawing pay and allowances, and other matters like that.

—Yes, I will come to that. In response particularly to the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), the provision only applies to persons in custody and under investigation. Very clearly, they are serious service offences and they are for testing. The provisions can only be used for drug testing and the member must be first warned that refusal to submit to examination or to supply a specimen will constitute an offence. I must say here that we should not be confusing this with the random urinalysis program which is also aimed at the drugs issue. I will also take the opportunity to note in passing that the normal testing regime for the presence and concentration of drugs in the blood will not in any way, I am informed, reveal the presence or otherwise of the AIDS virus. So this is not some subtle way of trying to get around it.
—Why not?
—The government has made a decision that that is not what we are about.
—What a weak, pusillanimous response to a serious health situation in the community.

—No, I say to the member for New England that we are wrestling with this problem as we speak. In relation to the payment situation, the fact of the matter is that section 100, as it stands now, provides that a member does continue to be paid. This is, of course, contrary to the rules for members of the public service who have been suspended from duty. But, more importantly, the amendment to section 100 will contain a provision for cases of proven hardship. Where a member suspended from duty will not normally be entitled to the payment of salary and allowances after he or she has been charged with an offence, a member who is suffering hardship can apply for the payment to be continued. In practice, those charges will only come about after service or civilian police investigation and legal advice that the member should be charged. So in fact there will have been quite a process, as is the standard with any charge in that situation.
—No procedures, no magistrate's court—and what about housing?
—No, I do not think housing will be a problem. I will just seek some advice on that.
—So if the person is in a remote location—
—I do not think housing is a problem.
—Order! We exercise a fair bit of flexibility in this chamber, but we might wait until we get to the committee stage.
—I am pretty sure that this relates only to pay and allowances.
—Would the minister mind looking at it? It is a very important issue.

—Yes, we will look at it; I acknowledge that that is a good point. On the other issues that have been raised, I must say that in relation to the management-initiated early retirement provisions—which I understand the opposition is supporting, although some speakers have had some reservations about it—the point about it is that it is an extremely limited platform. It is confined to officers who have completed 20 years service or more, have three years in their current rank, and have attained the rank of lieutenant colonel or above. So it is extremely limited and we believe it is needed in these times to make sure that the relatively limited number of senior positions that can be created are left there to be broadened and for the experience of grooming officers for promotion into the most senior ranks.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will find that this is supported by the younger officers at senior levels—people of about my age—who have served in the military for some time. They have been in uniform for some time—as opposed to lengthy service in the uniform that we wear around this place—and they support this. They are making career decisions about whether they stay or whether they go. Promotion, and the increased opportunity that MIR will offer, will mean that the Defence Force will keep a lot more of its best and brightest people.

Limited tenure appointments are needed for flexibility, particularly in areas of high speciality such as medicine and law, where we find it very hard to recruit and retain people. People on limited tenure appointments will fill a particular appointment at the rank of colonel or equivalent and above. It will be for a set period, which would normally be a minimum of three years, and on the basis that the officer would not otherwise have been promoted. This is a rational management tool for our human resources.

The issues we are confronting in the 1990s for the military, in terms of hardware, software technology, position in the region—in a foreign affairs sense—are all well on track. The hard work has been done. The money is coming through the system, and the work is being done well. The challenge is to continue to attract and retain the sorts of people we need to run our military systems. That will increasingly occupy more of the time of and require more effort from the Defence Force.

Honourable members opposite would be aware of the Glenn review that will be on my desk, hopefully, by the end of July. That is the broadest, most wide-sweeping personnel policy review of the military ever undertaken. That review is similar to reviews of human resource policies undertaken in the private sector. Our aim with that review is to update our practices and to retain and attract the type of people we need for the 1990s and beyond. I suspect that the review will show that a lot of the things we are doing now in terms of human resource management in the military will have to be changed. We will not hesitate to do that.

I sincerely hope that, when we leave aside `Club Med on North Head' and the rest of the rhetoric we have heard this morning, we will have bipartisan support on this. It is important. We need to get it right. The government is spending a lot of time, money and resources pursuing those human resource issues. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Messages from the Governor-General recommending appropriations announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Title, page 1, after "relating to defence" insert "and the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988".
(2)Clause 3, page 2, line 8, omit "Schedules 1 to 5", substitute "Schedules 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 5A".
(3)After Schedule 5 insert the following Schedule:
"SCHEDULE 5A

PARA.TAB: Section 3

SPEECH.PARA: AMENDMENT OF THE SAFETY, REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION ACT 1988

PARA.TAB: Omit the subsection, substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: "(2) If, at any time, whether before, on, or after, 1 December 1988:

TAB.TAB: (a)an employee to whom this section applies received or receives medical treatment paid for by the Commonwealth; and
(b)as an unintended consequence of that treatment the person suffered or suffers an injury;

SPEECH.PARA: the injury to the employee is taken to have arisen out of, or in the course of, the person's employment, whether or not the person has remained an employee to whom this section applies.".

This is a proposed amendment to the bill to insert a provision that will amend the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. Members may recall that in 1994 various amendments were made to that act in association with the introduction of the military compensation scheme, which I am sure members of both sides of the House regard as a great step forward for our serving people. One amendment provided an entitlement for compensation for an injury that arises from medical treatment provided at the Commonwealth's expense where that injury is an unintended consequence of the treatment. These things do not happen often, but when they do happen they can be pretty awful.

PARA.TAB: I am informed that an unintentional effect of this amendment was that it did not cover the period between the enactment of the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act in 1988 and the introduction of the military compensation scheme in 1994. This amendment which is being proposed by the government will fill the gap, so there is no period of defence related service to which the entitlement does not apply. It will enable us to address—hopefully, reasonably quickly—about 20 outstanding claims, which have an estimated cost of about $1 million although there will be considerable offsets in the avoidance of litigation. This is, unfortunately, one of the technical amendments that are needed to give legal auspices to a payment of moneys which is thoroughly deserved and warranted. A couple of the cases are particularly severe and I would urge the support of both sides of the House on the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is, obviously, no dispute on this side of the House that this amendment should be accepted. However, it is really quite ridiculous that the Department of Finance in this instance has not been prepared to follow a practice that has gone on for years. Where there has been a general intent demonstrated within legislation, and where there is demonstrable need for the payment not to have been made on a discretionary basis, the practice has been, through supplementary appropriations, for the funds to be disclosed as they should be and for the matter to be regularised.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I do not know whether this situation is a product of the government running scared because of the proper Auditor-General's scrutiny of departmental expenditure, or whether it is some new fad within the Department of Finance, but it is quite regrettable that in this instance, as I understand it—the minister, quite properly, has not identified at least one of the cases involved—there has been inconvenience and some disquiet for the persons affected. That has occurred simply because of the failure of the Department of Finance to accept that there was an inhibition or restriction within the amendment to which he has referred, as first passed, and, consequently, an apparent ineligibility, although demonstrably there was responsibility by the Commonwealth for compensation to be paid to the persons affected.

It is essential that some commonsense be exercised within the Department of Finance in circumstances of this nature. The opposition believes that it is appropriate for this amendment to go through, but I would suggest to the officers within the Department of Finance that it would be far more appropriate—and certainly it would seem to me to be in the manner of common government obligation—that, instead of requiring a person to suffer until the amendment has gone through, the payment be made and subsequently appropriate legislative approval, if necessary, or supplementary appropriation funding be provided as has been the case in the past. In this instance I think it is regrettable that that commonsense was not used by the officers of the Department of Finance.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to introduce amendments to the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985, the Wool International Act 1993 and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993.

PARA.TAB: The amendment to the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985 allows for a system of fees and charges to be instituted for the processed foods industry which are in accordance with that industry's wishes.

AQIS develops charging methodology and fee levels after consultation with relevant industry groups. Recent consultation with the processed foods industry has confirmed that it wishes to continue with the current mix of charges applying to that program.
The proposed amendments correct some minor anomalies and provide a more appropriate legislative basis for meeting industry's wishes.

There are two amendments to the Wool International Act 1993. The first of these is to make special arrangements for the registration of low value sales. Under the present act, Wool International is required to keep a register of all wool-tax payers. The register will become the basis for the issue of equity in Wool International when it is eventually privatised.

Experience has shown the upkeep of the register involves the registration of a significant number of low value sales. The industry is concerned that the cost of recording these low value transactions and issuing annual statements will be very significant relative to the worth of the tax accruing from them.

At the request of the Wool Council of Australia, other wool industry representatives and Wool International, the government has agreed to make provision in the act for the regulations to specify an amount for individual transactions below which Wool International would not be required to automatically register the transaction. However, if a person asks Wool International to include such a payment on the register, Wool International must do so. A request may relate to payments made between the date of the regulation and the time of the request.

The second proposed amendment to the Wool International Act 1993 relates to information held by Wool International on carpet wool-tax payers. The purpose of the amendment is to allow the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, AWRAP, to obtain access to the information held by Wool International on the taxpayer. AWRAP will require the consent of the carpet wool-tax payer to obtain the information, in the same way that information in respect of other wool-tax payers is obtained by AWRAP from Wool International. The information may only be used to determine eligibility to attend, and voting rights at, annual general meetings of AWRAP.
There are two amendments to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993.

The first of these is to remove the present requirement that AWRAP board meetings be held within Australia. The reason for the amendment is that the operations of AWRAP have been amalgamated with those of the International Wool Secretariat to provide a more focused wool promotion and research and development effort. The board of AWRAP has been appointed to the board of the International Wool Secretariat. There will be occasions where it is appropriate that the board of AWRAP meets overseas in conjunction with meetings of the International Wool Secretariat. Accordingly, the chairman of AWRAP has asked the government to remove the existing restriction on where board meetings may be held.

The second proposed amendment relates to the matching of payments made by the Commonwealth to AWRAP for research and development. At present, matching payments are not to exceed certain limits within the financial year. One of these limits is the amount paid to the organisation by way of income from the collections made under the wool tax acts for wool research and development. The effect of the amendment will be to allow the Commonwealth to match expenditure in subsequent years from tax collections where these are not all spent in the year of collection. The ceiling for the government's matching of expenditure in any one year will remain at 0.5 per cent of the gross value of shorn wool produced in Australia in the financial year. I commend the bill to honourable members.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by putting it on record that the coalition supports the legislative amendments before us. The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 is an omnibus bill which amends the way in which export inspection charges are imposed on certain fish exports to accord with industry wishes, which essentially relate to ensuring equity in the way in which AQIS charges are applied.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it removes the need to register the wool tax payments on very small amounts of wool. There are hobby farmers and others out there who occasionally remit very small amounts of wool and the recording costs for the relevant authorities are unnecessarily complex and time consuming, and it seems pointless to insist that they go on recording those very small amounts of wool when they are sold by individuals.

Thirdly, as the spokesman for the government has indicated, it provides a rollover of wool tax collected for research and development in one year to later years. I freely confess to having been a little concerned about that proposal when I first looked at it, but when we worked it through we came to the realisation that it was a perfectly reasonable thing to do.

By way of background, before I move on to some general comments about primary industry which I do want to make today, in relation to the change in the way in which export charges for AQIS inspections are levied, we currently have a situation where exporters pay AQIS a registration fee, they pay a direct service charge when an inspector is present and they pay $15 per tonne of fish exports. However, exports have been going through brokers who are in fact not charged the $15 a tonne. This legislation will ensure not only that that tonnage fee of $15 will come down to $10 from 1 July this year but that it is also paid by brokers and others who are currently avoiding payment. The industry has requested these changes, they are sound and they will ensure a greater degree of equity. We support them.

In broad terms, in relation to the wool industry, when that primary industry was restructured, with the full cooperation and input of the coalition, the government promised that Wool International would be privatised in 1997 and that growers who had paid wool tax for debt repayment between July 1993 and the date of privatisation, July 1997, would be given shares in Wool International, the privatised company, to follow the current statutory arrangement, according to their equity, and that equity was to be determined by calculating the amount of wool tax that growers had paid during that period. Wool tax, for the purposes of debt servicing and repayment, is set at a level of 4.5 per cent of sale price.

The wool industry has been concerned for some time about the cost of having to register the name and address of every person who sells wool, many selling very small amounts. It has had a concern particularly in relation to those who sell less than perhaps $500 worth of wool a year. It might be the fellow out the back who has a few killers and shears them; it might be the fellow who has got a bit of wool left over in his shed from the days when he had sheep but no longer has them; it might be the hobby farmer from my area of Mudgee—whoever it happens to be, the cost of collecting and collating the information so that these people can take up their shares in Wool International really outweighs the benefits. Often they are hard to find, often they are people who sell wool once and may not sell it again.

There can be considerable expense involved in tracking small lots which might have come, as I say, from the shearing of just a few sheep on a hobby farm. The industry is quite happy that these people can, if they so desire, be registered for the purposes of establishing their eventual equity in Wool International, but it believes—and I think this is quite fair enough—that the onus ought to be on those people themselves to ensure that they supply the necessary details.

The amendments to this bill make provision for the regulations to specify an amount below which Wool International will not be required to automatically register wool tax payments. However, it ought to be made perfectly plain that provision is made for any individual who sells a small amount of wool to ask Wool International, in writing, to register the payment, and that action will be acted upon.

There are some further amendments here which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Bevis) touched on. They provide, for example, that, where Wool International has details about a person who has paid wool tax imposed on carpet wool, the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, AWRAP, may, with the consent of the person, request Wool International to allow AWRAP access to that information, or a copy of or an extract from that information.

As the minister also mentioned, the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993 is to be amended to allow the board to meet outside Australia. For the reasons that the minister outlined, it is appropriate to allow that to happen with the amalgamation of AWRAP and the International Wool Secretariat. It is likely that from time to time it will be commercially and strategically prudent to meet in locations offshore from this country.

Other amendments bring the manner of paying research and development funds from the government for wool into line with the other research and development corporations by providing a rollover provision to ensure that the government matches dollar for dollar the amount contributed by woolgrowers for research and development up to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of gross value of production. We initially had some concerns about this because it appeared to us that if the industry did not spend all of the money contributed by the industry and the government for research and development in any given year the shortfall might be found missing the following year. But in fact it will not work that way. If there is a difference between what is contributed by growers and the amount actually spent on research, should the industry then spend that difference in the following year—the carryover, if you like, on research—then the government will match it. So we express our satisfaction with that position.

There are a couple of other broader comments I want to make. We have seen—and it is a source of great satisfaction to me and I dare say to the previous minister for primary industry, now the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean)—the substantial recovery of this nation's mighty wool industry. This is an enormous relief to Australians, or ought to be, because although I suspect that they pay very little attention to Australia's enormous trade deficit problem and although I suspect that many of them would take the view, perhaps technically correct, that we no longer in a sense ride on the sheep's back, the fact of the matter is that the wool industry is still a major export industry with enormous capacity for expansion in the future.

The wool industry is one of the few industries that has the capacity to make a significant difference in a relatively short period of time to Australia's crippling export deficit problem. It is interesting to note that only one, so far as I am aware, major media outlet has recorded that the improved performance of the wool industry has prevented the current account deficit from being even worse than it has been in recent months. I commend that media organisation and point out that what it says is quite true.

We in this place need to remember that some two-thirds of Australia's export earnings are still derived essentially from the efforts and the production of those who live in rural and regional Australia. In fact, despite the quite heroic contribution they make to the nation's wellbeing, their efforts are often under-acknowledged, not only in terms of public perceptions but in terms of the policy settings of this government. I want to place on record my basic optimism about the future prospect for Australia's rural industries. It is often said that primary industry is not as important as it used to be—it contributes only about four or five per cent of gross domestic product and about 25 per cent of our export earnings. That overlooks several very important factors.

For one thing, the reason that export earnings in many ways are at lower levels than they might otherwise be is that commodity prices are at low levels. As I will indicate in a moment, that is about to change. I think you will find that primary industry will have a significantly greater contribution to make to export earnings in coming years.

Another thing is one often not recognised when we constantly hear of Australia's improved manufacturing performance and the greater performance or contribution to export earnings that our manufacturing sector makes. That is usually said by people who either forget or do not understand that the major manufacturing sector in this country is the food value adding sector. In other words, the major manufacturing sector is dependent upon the primary industries to provide it with the raw materials that it needs to do its job and to employ hundreds of thousands of Australians.

There are some very different views emerging on the future outlook for commodity prices and for derived value added product. In brief, they can be summarised by referring to the World Bank, which has recently put together a publication which argues that the world has become so flexible in its production of agricultural merchandise in its various forms that it is unlikely that there will be any substantial increase in real terms in prices for agriculture commodities over the next few decades. The essential position is that, should a shortfall develop in one aspect of the world's grain supplies, for example, production will be lifted or substitutes found for that shortfall in such a flexible and rapid fashion that there will be no particular push on prices such as there normally is on response to a supply shortfall.That is a gloomy outlook for Australia's farmers and for the nation, which is still so heavily dependent upon export earnings.

However, there is another view of world commodity prices emerging. It is put forward by people like the economist Lester Brown, of the Worldwatch Institute. He argues that such is the coming explosion in demand for agricultural product in Asia in general, in China in particular and so forth, that the emerging gap between supply and demand will be so great that for agricultural products we will see prices with which we are simply not familiar in our generation emerging in the very near future.

The widely respected principal of Orange Agricultural College in New South Wales, John Chudleigh, takes a middle view. He argues very strongly, and I am sure he is right, that, given the problem with tightening world supplies of grain, emerging increasing demand in Asia and so forth, whilst we will not see the absolute explosion in prices—which could be quite dangerous—that the Lester Browns of this world talk of, we will see a significant improvement in agricultural prices. That is for the very simple reason that, in order to increase production to the levels that demand will likely dictate in the next few years, farmers in the Western world, particularly in this country, will simply have to receive a higher price for their product in order to justify the increased investment in their industries that will be needed.

That is very much the case, just as this country, under current Labor Party policies, has one of the oldest car fleets in the world, pumping out all sorts of nasty emissions from their exhausts. And when we ought to be encouraging more people to get into new cars, the government pushes up the sales tax on cars. That is pretty typical of their approach to encouraging investment in agriculture, and we now have a frighteningly ancient fleet of tractors and of agricultural implements across the nation, and it is reflected in the uptake of new technology. So higher levels of investment will be needed and that will only be made possible by higher prices received on farm for agriculture products.

The real issue, then, becomes whether the farm sector will be able to capture the benefits of improving commodity prices. I would have to say that the record of those in power at the moment would not lead you to believe that there was any great hope of that happening. And this is a very serious issue indeed for economic, social and environmental reasons. The environment is very important in this regard. The only way in which we are going to ensure that Australia's major environmental problems of land and soil degradation—and they are different things—and the attendant water quality problems, and so forth, are adequately tackled is to ensure that the nation's land-holders are in an economic position where they can do what they want to do—that is, to look after their land. Whether that is through contour banks, or more sophisticated rotations, or the uptake of modern farming technologies and what-have-you, farmers have to have adequate returns in order to restore past damage to Australia's agricultural lands and to move to sustainable production for the future.

So I come back to the question I posed earlier: what are the chances of farmers being able to snare enough of this sort of money that might flow from improved commodity prices and, hopefully, a breaking of the drought, in order to address these very real economic, social and environmental problems? The answer is that the signs are not at all promising, because the government cannot help itself—it will always tax an emerging, successful industry. I will give another example from the budget. One of the major problems we face in this country is transport—the tyranny of distance and all the rest of that. The government often tells us that our petrol is amongst the cheapest in the world.
