It never remembers to say that, by global standards, we tax our transport fuels at very high levels indeed.

That is a particularly stupid thing to do because of the distances we have in this country. As I understand it, we tax diesel fuel more highly than the Americans, the Canadians and the South American countries—those that have vast distances to travel, like us, and are dependent on transport fuels to the degree that we are. But we also tax diesel fuel more highly than places like the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Japan. And what do they do with these transport costs? They continue to increase them; they continue to use transport as a milch cow.

Towards the end of last year, we had an unbelievable situation. We are the world's major global exporter of meat and we have the unbelievable situation where a potential importer of American beef can land the product in this country for less than we can produce the stuff ourselves. This is despite the fact that the Australian farmer produces for a great deal less—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they don't.

—Yes, they do. No-one has challenged the figures. It is about $5.80 here for American rump, compared to $6.20 for Australian product, and this is despite the fact that the Australian farmer gets very significantly less for his product in the first place than does the American. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) ought to have a good look at his own Industry Commission, because that is where the evidence is that this is the case. So how do they do it? Well, it is all about things like industrial relations, where the government refuses to move, where it leaves an obstructionist us-and-them approach locked into place. But it is also about taxation levels and cost structures forced on important parts of our infrastructure.

PARA.TAB: Part of the reason the Americans can land the product here so much more cheaply than we can is that in round terms the per kilometre tax, in our terminology, on a big truck taking that container of beef, or whatever it is, to the waterfront is about 10c a kilometre. In Australia, it is 27c a kilometre. That is getting on for three times the American level of tax on transport—on the rig, on the parts, on the tyres, on the fuel. You name it, it is there. What is the government doing in this area? The answer is short: fuel costs continue to rise and the sales tax on transport continues to rise. This is not sound economic and social management of the Australian community for the Australian community. It is, as one commentator observed in relation to the budget, short-term politicking at the expense of the long-term interests of Australia's working men and women and their families. It is also, of course, a major risk for Australia's primary producers.

I am optimistic about the future but no farmer in this country nor anybody who is involved in rural industries—and there are vastly more of them than is generally acknowledged—should be deluded into believing anything other than that this government does not understand the need to ensure that primary industries are internationally competitive. That is a proposition that simply cannot be argued: there is no evidence to suggest that the government understands the need to make our primary industries genuinely, globally competitive.

The losers are not just our primary producers, they are the hundreds of thousands of Australian workers who are dependent on primary industries for their jobs—whether it is abattoir workers, fruit canning workers, transport workers, the wharfies themselves, or the people who work in Australia's scouring plants and top making plants, such as they are in this country. The fact of the matter is that they have a vested interest in securing the removal of a government that has no understanding and no commitment to genuine long-term reform. The government is only interested in short-term political gain. On that note, I conclude that we support these minor amendments before us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Anderson) has to leave the chamber. We on this side of the House are very fond of the support that we are getting from the Deputy Leader of the National Party for these amendments. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. Let me refer to a few of the deputy leader's arguments. This government is very proud of the restructuring that has taken place in the wool industry. There is no doubt that it was something that only this government could have achieved with the support of the wool industry. I am sure that the deputy leader is very much aware of the support that was given to Senator Bob Collins when he addressed the Wool Council in Adelaide the week before last. There is a positive feeling that the wool industry has recovered and that things look good. That is because of Wool International and because of the initiatives of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and his successor.

PARA.TAB: I would like to digress, just as the Deputy Leader of the National Party did. It was claimed that this government is not supportive of the rural and regional sector of Australia. Another thing that this government is very proud of is that it is the largest representative of rural and regional Australia. There is no doubt about that. Have a look at the seats that we hold in rural and regional Australia: we do it very well. The reason that we are representative of such a large section of rural and regional Australia is that we get out there, we talk to the people and we make sure our policies reflect their needs.

A few comments were made about transport and transport infrastructure. It is very interesting to note in today's Financial Review that the growth in the transport and storage infrastructure sector of Australia over the past 12 months has increased and that the investment in it has increased by 10.6 per cent. That is not insignificant and it reflects the confidence that this government is giving to the transport industry.

The claim was also made that rural and regional people are paying too much for their fuel. I am sure that all honourable members of this House are aware that, two years ago, when there was an increase in excise in fuel, the cost of petrol, in particular, was then about 75c a litre. I know that, around my electorate, most retailers of fuel sell petrol for considerably less than that today. Some two years later, the effective cost of fuel is less than it was. In regard to diesel, let me remind everyone that most diesel in this country is imported simply because our crude oil does not satisfy the needs of refineries to convert it into diesel.

As a government, we are continually being reminded that we must reduce our deficit. Diesel fuel is one of our big import costs. It is logical that such a commodity is carefully guarded by the government to ensure that we do not have further blow-outs. In relation to another rural commodity, our beef exports, I note that the government was being chided over the potential of American beef producers to bring their beef to Australia cheaper than local producers can supply the trade. I was in Japan last year and I was very proud of the fact that Aussie beef is on sale in most retail outlets in Japan. We are now the major providing nation of first class beef in Japan at a very reasonable price. That gives a return to our producers, and this is growing. Similarly, we are expanding on the Korean and the Taiwanese markets and others due to the ingenuity of Austrade and our primary producers.

I started by saying that this government is very proud of the relationship that it has with Australia's rural sector and the way it reflects the needs of rural producers. I conclude on that point. We have a record that is second to none. We have a record that has brought about change which will take our rural industry into the next century. We have done it well and I can assure people that we will continue to do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise in support of this Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. I would like to address my remarks to the export side of the legislation. We do need inspection facilities for our exports but more importantly we need more exports. Australian exports have to grow and they will make a difference to the economic wellbeing of the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I want to comment on one of the areas in primary industry which is now starting to use export opportunities, and that is the timber industry. The timber industry is a large industry in my area. It produces sawlog hardwood and pine plantation timbers and products. It converts hardwood and pinewood to pulp and it is produced into paper by the Amcor company, one of Australia's large paper producers.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware, along with a lot of other people, that development of this industry has been a major concern to many people. It has been a hotly debated issue not only in relation to the environment but also in relation to the development of the industry itself and its move into export opportunities. It has also involved debate on products which should be processed in Australia as value added products before export. It has always been a major issue that Australia has for many years been a mine and that the country has lived off the sheep's back. Too often, our produce has gone overseas. This government has certainly put a lot of effort into making sure that we turn that around so that this country becomes a substantial manufacturer. We have certainly achieved that in the development of our economy since 1983.

However, I want to raise a few issues in the chamber today which are giving me grave concern in relation to the development of the timber industry and the potential of getting those exports. That includes the campaign that is being waged against the hardwood industry in Australia, a campaign which never seems to cease regardless of how much effort the government puts into the national forest policy statement and national policy negotiations. There are groups of people in this nation who believe that we should not harvest at all in our native forests and who are determined to continue campaigning down that path. They have every right to do so, and if their arguments can be sustained then governments will take them on board, but to this point in time certainly their arguments have not been sustained. Every report that has been produced for the government has indicated that we do have the capacity to have a native hardwood industry in our native forests, and it is certainly the policy of this Labor government to continue down that path.

We are in the process, of course, of further development of forest agreements in order to eventually try to placate the opposition to these issues in this nation. To that end, there have been certain measures taken in order to try to bring on board all organisations in the industry and in the environment movement, to have them discuss rationally the issues and come to an agreed position. My concern is about the methods being used to do that and what is going on in the system at the present time.

The government received a request from Environment Victoria, the new business name for the Conservation Council of Victoria, now operating under the state jurisdiction of an incorporated association rather than its former company operation under the Australian Securities Commission. It has taken a leading role in opposition to the hardwood industry and has been very, very active in trying to convince city people that the hardwood industry should cease. It has caused a fair bit of political agitation and the political campaign has probably had more substance than the ecological or the environmental productions that it has used to justify its position.

I want to raise in the Main Committee a concern I have with an action taken by the government through the minister for the environment. A study proposal was put to the government by Environment Victoria entitled `National plantations: environment, industry development and employment'. It was first submitted to the department of the environment in June 1993. Matching funding was sought at that time from the minister for resources and the minister for industry, technology and regional development. That was in February 1994. Both ministers chose not to provide any support.

On 4 May 1994, following receipt of a revised study proposal, the minister approved funding of $166,563 for this study. However, the decision was withheld, pending further action until late July and receipt of Environment Victoria's audited financial statement for the grants to voluntary conservation organisations program for 1993-94 and until questions that I had raised in the parliament on the extent of departmental funding to these organisations were answered. Following that work, the grant was made available.

It is understandable that governments will put grants out to organisations to develop work on their behalf on particular issues, but this is where my concerns start to really be raised. This report has gone to Environment Victoria, an organisation which has a very strong position in the field of opposing the hardwood industry. In a previous opportunity it was funded by the Victorian government to have a consultant produce a plantation report. The report, by Ms Judy Clarke, was found to be very poor in methodology, and a lot of the information provided in it was quite inaccurate. It was understandable because there was no discussion with industry. The report was done just from documents available in libraries and what have you, or public documents from newspapers, and therefore was not considered to be a sensible and rational report.

My concern with this $166,000 grant to Environment Victoria is that the same consultant has been employed—some seven months ago—and commissioned to do another plantation study. That is reasonable enough: the government is still probably within its rights to provide this money to this organisation to have a report done, and that report would be taken on board and assessed by the government in decision making in the future. However, to do the report, the consultant was also required to obtain information on all plantations in Australia—from the private sector as well as the public sector—and hence was encouraged to approach Amcor, one of the largest plantation operators in Australia, which operates the paper mill in my electorate. It was quite amenable to doing some work, if that was necessary, to provide its information, confidential information even, to the government in a properly constituted study.

The company then sought, of course, the terms of reference for the study, and I was approached as the local member to see what I could find. An approach to the minister's office clearly indicated, after many requests, that there were no terms of reference in relation to this study, that the only information that the minister had was a study proposal from Environment Victoria. On the request from this organisation, the money was allocated—not acquitted, but allocated as part of the budgetary process to have the work done that the organisation had put in its study proposal.

What has occurred since? With the approach from Amcor, a senior adviser in the minister's office saw fit to accompany the consultant from Environment Victoria and approach Amcor, very much raising the stakes of the credibility of this report, from something being done by Environment Victoria to the minister's office being heavily involved in seeking the information from Amcor.

Amcor was not prepared to respond, unless it had the terms of reference. With no terms of reference, it has failed to respond, and the information is not available to the consultant. We already know, from that information, that this study, when it is produced, will be very similar to the first one produced by this consultant in Victoria: it will be flawed, and very much so, possibly even in methodology, as well as lacking in the information that will be required for the report to have any substance.

My concern is what is going to happen with this report. I have documentation of what Environment Victoria is doing in relation to this. It intends to use this Judith Clarke report as the mainstay and the catalyst for its campaign against the hardwood industry and to revive the environment issue on the front page of the newspapers before the next election. This government is funding this proposal to achieve this objective.

SPEECH.PARA: I am asking the government to seriously consider the position that it is placing the industry in and the serious position it is placing itself in, in relation to bringing forward these sort of funds to organisations whose intentions are not to provide the information sought by government.

PARA.TAB: If the government wishes to have a national plantation study which includes private company involvement, then there are ways and means of doing that. The ways and means of doing that are to have terms of reference and to seek tenders from appropriate and qualified people to do the work so that the industry has the confidence to put that report together.

Here we are now, seven months into the process. A report, funded by the government, which is obviously very, very flawed from the beginning, because it cannot achieve its objectives, is set to be used as the catalyst for a major campaign against the hardwood industry and to get this issue back onto the front pages of our newspapers. Anyone can see how that is going to occur. Yesterday we saw the first breakthrough in getting on the media in relation to The World Today, following Peter Cook's interview after the discussion here in Canberra on the forest industry this week.
In the last 10 minutes I would like to run through a few issues. A meeting report from Environment Victoria states:

SPEECH.PARA: -Victorian marginal seats to be targeted are Jika Jika—Peter Staples . . . Clyde Holding's seat, Melbourne Ports . . .
This is an environment group, of course! It is not a political party, is it? The document continues:
-A joint letter will be sent to all Liberal and ALP marginal electorates outlining current green position.
-The Wombat Forest Group will be targeting the seats of Ballarat and Bendigo.
-Judy Clarke's Plantation study report due for release on June 7th.

I am pleased to say the release of the report will not be occurring next Wednesday because it is now deferred to 21 June. I hope that this government puts it aside, and puts it away completely, because it is not the way to go in relation to this. The date of the next forest summit that the group was working on was to be 17 June. It will be interesting to see whether it goes ahead now if it has not got Judith Clarke's report. The document continues:
At this Summit, greens, Democrats, Liberals and Young Liberals will be invited to put forward their forest policy for the next election.
In the industry area the group is talking about running a consumer campaign, to boycott companies which sell native forest hardwoods. The document states:
Starting the campaign now and running it flat out for the next 8 weeks.
It also states:
Jill Redwood—
from East Gippsland—
is proposing action to stop logging in native forests. This action will be taken up by all Environmental groups.
On that issue, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have seen the documentation of what is proposed. I put out a press release on 30 May which I would like to read into the Hansard. It states:

PARA.TAB: Labor MHR for McMillan, Mr Barry Cunningham, has recently written to environmentalist groups across the country calling on them to cancel their plans for a major blockade of East Gippsland's hardwood timber industry which is predicted to occur on a massive scale in October this year.
Mr Cunningham said he had written to the leaders of all relevant organisations to express his concerns "at the direction taken by sections of the environment movement."
Mr Cunningham was first made aware of the blockade plans through a leaked document arising from a Canberra-based meeting of environmental groups earlier this month.
The document outlined the blockade's objective as `disrupting resource security, undermining economic confidence and educating the workers.'

In the letter he circulated this week Mr Cunningham said he was "genuinely concerned that this sort of situation, which has been shamelessly engineered by elements of the green movement, could result in a situation in which the safety of worker and protester alike could be placed in jeopardy."

"There are greater environmental issues in our world that are far too important to be sidetracked by an unnecessary campaign against the hardwood timber industry. A campaign which has no scientific basis and as such no credibility . . .
He further encouraged organisation leaders to use what influence they had "to pursue an approach to the environment which was in keeping with the views of the majority of Australians."
Mr Cunningham said he believed the blockade would only serve to create a needless confrontation between protesters and workers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am genuinely concerned about this issue. I am very concerned that the government has seen fit to give $166,000 to Environment Victoria. I am further concerned that this study is the only study that is proposed at this stage to be taken into consideration. I further call on the government to produce other studies on the plantation issue, which will include all plantations, before the community out there is given the impression that this Judy Clarke study is a government sponsored study.

PARA.TAB: The fact that one of the senior advisers to the minister has joined with the consultant to visit the private organisations to encourage them to participate in this study horrifies me. I believe it has created the situation where those people genuinely are saying, and will be able to say, that this is a government inspired and sponsored study. Away this campaign will go. There is no doubt that this study is crucial to the campaign, because I also have documentation here of the consumer boycott campaign.

It is proposed that the consumer boycott campaign could have four planks, targeting major builders, the public, timber outlets and architects. The suggested strategy is to approach major builders—maybe 50 around Australia—making the following points:

SPEECH.PARA: -There is a National Scheme about to be launched which is backed by the entire Aust environment movement.
-We are giving them an opportunity to respond to overwhelming consumer demand for forest-friendly homes.
-We are currently researching the percentage of Australians who wish to use plantation timbers, using a major national opinion poll/survey/company.
It goes on and on, talking about the methods that should be used. Another reads:
Design a very simple leaflet to answer the most common questions asked about using pine to replace native forest hardwood timbers.

That is happening in the normal economics of the world at the present time anyway, but there is a place for both industries and this type of attack should be put to one side. Environment Victoria is making no bones about its position in relation to it. Yet another method reads:
An image to be designed which will link a piece of 4x2 hardwood timber to its effects on forest (bloody possums etc).
Use this constantly.
We have seen this campaigning before. We saw it start previously from a campaign project where this same consultant produced a plantation study, and we are about to see it happen again.

PARA.TAB: My concern is such that I could not keep quiet on this any longer. I have asked people to do something about it and nothing has happened. So I am prepared to go public in the parliament and call upon this parliament to put this study aside. It is flawed; it should not be allowed to be used as a catalyst for a fraudulent campaign; it should not be allowed to be used in the way these people intend to use it, in order to convince city people on an issue where they do not have a lot of knowledge. It is an emotional issue and the information being provided to them is emotional; the planning to use this is emotional; and it is causing tremendous problems in an industry in Australia. It is an industry where we are in position to move forward and to push offshore with $1.8 million worth of exports in timber and paper products that we can and should be producing in Australia with our own capital, our own product and our own workers.

As I said before, I call on the government to get some alternative reports which have substance and are done by proper people. I call on the government, if it intends to do another one of these studies, to get some terms of reference, to do a tender project and to get somebody to do the job properly so that when the information goes out to the public we can all be assured and confident that the information being used is accurate and fair and has been sought from a proper base. The information should be available to everybody in Australia, not only to part of an environment group in Victoria calling itself Environment Victoria, which, at this stage, has been taken over by a group of radicals who are running the show in such a way that it is not doing the environment movement any good.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Motion (by Mr Punch)—by leave—agreed to:
That this bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Les Scott.
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, you will be very interested to hear my comments about this particular report, given your participation in the Public Accounts Committee and in many other committees in the parliament as well. This is the 336th report from the Public Accounts Committee. It is titled Public business in the public interest. This is a very important subject and is something that we have a keen interest in. I am pleased to have the opportunity to rise and have a further discussion in this chamber. We tabled this report recently in the main chamber. In my tabling speech I outlined the principal findings of the committee's inquiry. In the report, the committee reached conclusions in a number of key areas and this afternoon I would like to give a brief overview of five of them before commenting on two other issues in greater detail.

PARA.TAB: The performance of public interest functions by commercial bodies and privatisation are the ones I wish to make further comment on, particularly the privatisation issue which is of interest at the moment.

The principal motivation behind the introduction of commercialisation of provision of goods and services to the public sector was the government's desire to increase the efficiency with which these services are provided. Evidence before the committee clearly shows that substantial gains in efficiency and effectiveness can be produced by commercialisation. We have all seen where that has been very effective. These gains stem from the administrative changes introduced by commercialisation and corporatisation and from the accompanying improvements made to the market environment. Competition is a pertinent force for bettering performance. We have all seen that.

For the most part, appropriate frameworks have been established for the operation and oversight of the Commonwealth GBEs and the government should be congratulated for that. These frameworks will be enhanced considerably by the passage of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 which is currently before the Senate. Honourable members will be well aware that the Public Accounts Committee is very keen to see that bill become law as soon as possible.

By contrast, however, business units and departments are more recent developments in the commercialisation spectrum, and that is what I would like to focus on at the moment. Consequently, they are not as well placed as GBEs to operate successfully on a fully commercial basis because they are quite clearly different. The framework for their operation is less well established and is still being developed in a lot of cases. The Department of Finance, of course, has a significant role in this process and, indeed, should be playing a more prominent role than it has to date in monitoring the problems that have arisen and in disseminating best practice through those various departments.

Business units and departments are currently disadvantaged by the requirements imposed by being part of a department of state, and that is understandable because they have still got some of those shackles of a department on them. But, given that corporatisation provides increased flexibility of operation, the committee has recommended that successful business units should be corporatised. That is the next step, I believe, to make them the efficient and effective operations that I think we would want.

Both GBEs and business units need to have clearly defined and non-conflicting objectives. Although this principle is generally understood by the various organisations concerned, it was clear to the committee the principle has not always been fully translated into practice. Some examples which the committee identified were the Civil Aviation Authority, Auscript and Auslink. Confusion between the commercial and public policy objectives creates the risk of uncertainty in the minds of staff, clients and competitors with the likely outcome of reduced efficiency and productivity. Of course that is the main drive in producing efficiency and productivity in moving to the commercialisation process.

The arrangement for ministerial oversight of all government businesses needs to be clearly stated and consistently applied. Although the committee concluded that at present there is no compelling evidence to support major change to the Commonwealth model of GBE oversight, the more centralised developments in other jurisdictions such as New Zealand and some Australian states were of considerable interest during the inquiry. The ongoing review and evaluation of developments such as these is a necessary pre-requisite to keeping the Commonwealth's own ministerial oversight and monitoring arrangements for GBEs relevant to changing circumstances.

That was a particular area of interest to the committee, as I mentioned. We had the opportunity to actually see how things operate in New Zealand. Certainly committee members took a very keen interest in that. We had some additional hearings with the public sector, but at the end of the day we were not convinced that the New Zealand model was the best one for Australia and were content to remain with the same conditions as we have now.

There are some other aspects I would like to talk briefly about as well before my colleagues take the opportunity to add to this relating to the public interest functions carried out by commercialised bodies and of course privatisation, as I mentioned earlier. The one area which I emphasised in my tabling speech was the need to safeguard the public interest functions that were once delivered by the predecessors of today's government businesses; in other words, by various government departments and agencies. The committee made a number of recommendations aimed at ensuring that community service obligations, better known as CSOs, and other public interest activities are identified, costed, funded and delivered appropriately.

The committee spent a lot of time on the examination of the special considerations applying to public interest functions delivered by GBEs and business units. In relation to business units the committee agreed with the Department of Administrative Services, DAS, when it stated that the definition of what should be seen as a function of the public sector rather than the private sector is constantly changing, and that is something I believe we need to continually monitor all the time. But an increasing trend over the last 10 years or so towards setting up commercialised business units, contracting out, corporatisation and privatisation provides ample proof of that proposition.

In looking at public interest activities, the committee was keen to ensure that such functions are not abandoned in the face of commercial imperatives. All of us on the committee were mindful of the impact that CSOs have on particular members of the community, given that many of these CSOs relate particularly to rural and remote communities and to the less well off in our society. There is certainly a need for CSOs in our rural and remote areas. There is an impact on people living in those areas particularly, whether they be farmers on the land or Aboriginal people living in the various communities. Depending on how the CSOs are actually applied, people in those more remote and rural areas actually share the same benefits that Australians have across the board.

The committee recognised the importance of ensuring that, when public sector agencies commercialise, universal access to these essential services is maintained. It is very hard to identify those CSOs because there are a lot of things that we tend to take for granted but we need to be able to clearly identify them. Prime examples of the essential services are Telstra's telephone service and the standard letter service provided by Australia Post. I would like to give Australia Post a pat on the back while I have the opportunity. In my observation, Australia Post is one of those extremely well-run Commonwealth GBEs. Australia Post provides a tremendous service and its representations to the committee indicated that. I think we can be very proud, as a nation, of the success story of Australia Post. It provides a universal service right across the country and it is one of the most efficient and effective Commonwealth GBEs.

Further examples are provided by DAS and the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, AQIS, both of which are required by the government to clearly recognise public interest services as distinct elements of their business regimes. In 1993-94, DAS businesses received approximately $39.3 million to meet their CSOs. Similarly, AQIS received approximately $50 million in its 1993-94 budget allocation to provide CSOs such as meat inspection services and barrier control functions for quarantine purposes.

The committee has therefore made a number of recommendations designed to ensure that public interest activities are continually reviewed, and appropriately costed and funded during the move towards commercialisation in the Commonwealth public sector. The committee also saw a greater role for community groups than exists at the present time in defining and monitoring the delivery of CSOs. We felt that community groups needed to have a bigger say and have an input into what CSOs are, how they can be best identified and how they can be funded. For this to work effectively, there needs to be better information about the goods and services provided than is currently available: for example, the standards of CSO delivery, such as those which have been published by Australia Post and Telstra.

As well, the committee recommended that, contrary to current practice, the Commonwealth Auditor-General should monitor the operation of the CSO system by carrying out performance audits on GBEs with public interest obligations. Once again, we are trying to identify—in case anyone gets confused about it—the CSO area that the Auditor-General needs to identify, particularly where services are delivered by GBEs. At the present time, the Auditor-General does not have the right to do performance audits on GBEs. It is a particular area that needs to be emphasised and I hope the government will give it fair consideration as it is a valid point. If we want to assist our people in the rural areas, we need to make sure that our CSOs are effective. I should have mentioned that CSOs are not restricted to rural areas. They are in our urban areas and they are often not identified enough there either. It is something that we should focus on in order to ensure that all Australians share, on an equitable basis, the wealth of our nation.

I now turn to an interesting subject which I am sure my colleague the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) will want to focus on later. It concerns the question of privatisation. I am sure he, and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) will add something to it later. The many interesting issues which emerged during the inquiry included the whole question of privatisation and Professor Hilmer's report on competition that my colleague has just alluded to. The related question of whether the government should be involved in businesses at all is one that often comes up. The member for Lyne was one of the main people to contribute to the name of our report: Public business in the public interest. I think it is a very good title and I thank him for his contribution towards that. He also added something to the substance of the report, I have to admit. He did not just have something to say about the front cover. I am sure he will pick me up on that as well.

In recent times, the government has sold a number of GBEs. The program of asset sales has been based on considerations of whether the public interest is still best served by the government actually owning these businesses. As well, as we all know, the budget contains plans for selling the government's remaining equity in the Commonwealth Bank, in two stages, by 1997-98. The committee believes that the government's commitment to continuing examination of its direct involvement in businesses is appropriate. It is, of course, because things change, circumstances change, affecting whether a government needs to be particularly involved in a business or not. When there is an area in the community where there is a shortfall, where the private sector is not providing the services that are needed, then I think that government obviously needs to step in and get those businesses up and running. But then, over a period of time, when it clearly no longer needs to be involved and when the private sector or other community elements pick up those areas, there is no real need for the government to remain involved.

There is definitely an argument on both sides: there are cases where the government needs to be involved in business, and there are others where it probably needs to decide to opt out of it. But that is something that needs to be kept under constant review to ensure that the Australian taxpayer's dollar is spent in the best way and that the services the Commonwealth provides are pushed through in the best way to the end users. I do not think it is just a matter of flogging things off for the sake of flogging them off. It is more a case of assessing whether there is a real need for the government to remain involved in a particular area. Are the services being provided by the private sector just as efficient or effective? Or is there a need for the Commonwealth to remain involved?

Unfortunately, some of the media commentators, notably the Financial Review, were not exactly very kind to us about our report. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, from your own involvement in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, it is without doubt the most effective committee in the parliament. All the members, to their great credit, work very effectively together. We ensure that we work very much on a bipartisan basis to bring through the best results that we believe can flow on to the Australian people through the government adopting our recommendations. The fact that a lot of the recommendations from our report on the Taxation Office have been accepted by the government has clearly shown the good work that this committee does. That is not taking anything away from other committees of the parliament. The committees are a very effective means for members of parliament to make a contribution and should be well supported.

To pick up on what the Financial Review had to say, it suggested the committee had actually squibbed on this issue of privatisation. I suggest that we certainly did not. It was an area that had to be canvassed and was well canvassed. The points I have already made this afternoon indicate the sorts of feelings that are coming through from our members on the need to consider that question. As I say, it is not just a matter of deciding whether to flog things off or not. It is a matter of using a bit of commonsense and really assessing the role of government in public enterprises. I think that is more the point. We took a very serious approach to this question and certainly did not come up with anything that would suggest that the committee squibbed or anything like that. The committee made it perfectly clear that the retention of public ownership in a commercial enterprise is a matter for continuing review and for assessment on a case by case basis. That is particularly important.

In our assessment, there are a number of roles which the committee identified as being appropriate for the government vis-a-vis business activities and I will run through these particular points. They include: providing services that are not available from the private sector; fostering emerging markets, but withdrawing from them as the private sector develops sufficiently to compete effectively; facilitating the private sector's work through joint ventures, export enhancement and technology transfers—that is very important; monitoring and regulating, except where the government businesses compete with the private sector; and developing appropriate policies for Australian businesses to flourish. That is an important part—to ensure that Australian businesses actually do flourish. In a lot of areas, a lot of our GBEs are very successful. One, of course, is Telstra, which has now moved very much into the international market. That is a great thing for Australia in terms of expanding our export opportunities in the goods and services area, the technology that goes with it, and the great benefits that we can provide, particularly to our region where Telstra plays a very important part.

To carry out these tasks, the government requires access to well-honed expertise which, in many cases, is maintained by ongoing involvement in business. Whilst some of the necessary expertise may be available from private sector consultants, this may not always be so. In addition, it is necessary to have a sufficient number of skilled people in-house to monitor the quality of the work carried out by consultants, to assess the significance, and to encourage a degree of consistency in the approach taken by the government.

Judging the appropriate level of direct involvement that the government should have in business is difficult and, of course, is subject to change over time. That is the important part, as I mentioned earlier. Each case should be looked at on its merits. There is no one model which can be applied either universally or without periodic review. It is important for us to do that.

To conclude, I pay tribute to the sterling efforts of all the committee members, and certainly the member for Lyne and the member for Corinella who are here today, and our deputy, the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), who certainly made a fine contribution. I also pay tribute to the staff of the committee who worked extremely hard and put in a tremendous effort in ensuring that the papers were well prepared for us. The advice we get from them is always first class and very professional. This is a good opportunity to give them the acknowledgment that they deserve.

The bipartisan spirit with which my colleagues worked on this was important in bringing out the best of the various aspects of this report. I hope that members of the House will read it. I look forward to a positive response from the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I probably will not speak for as long as the member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) did on the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Public business in the public interest. However, it is important that we have had the opportunity to bring this motion from the main chamber to the Main Committee room so that we can express more extensively our views on what was a very extensive and important inquiry as far as the future of public policy in Australia is concerned.

PARA.TAB: As the chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Oxley, alluded to, there was a great spirit of bipartisanship during most of the inquiry and in terms of the recommendations that are contained in this report. I had the opportunity to speak briefly on this when the report was tabled in the House in budget week.

A number of important elements arising from this report need to be noted. Firstly, I will take responsibility for the title, Public business in the public interest. The member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) and I were in competition as to whose name for the report was going to get up, and in the end my title was used because public business in the public interest is what the report is basically about.

This inquiry started when I first came into this place a couple of years ago. It was set up to look at the effectiveness, efficiency and appropriateness of the commercialisation of government business enterprises. It has been an interesting inquiry in that we have been able to have a look at the process that government departments have been through in developing strategies for change. Some of the GBEs that have moved away from being line agencies have undergone a major metamorphosis. They have moved into operating as a private sector enterprise, but they are still a government business enterprise, where the Commonwealth government is the shareholder, with the portfolio minister carrying that responsibility, as well as his responsibility as far as policy over that area is concerned.

That is one of the points I want to touch on this afternoon. I do not think the point can be laboured too much—and it was also mentioned by the member for Oxley—that it is important to recognise the existence and the continuation of community service obligations in these areas. I do not think anybody on either side of this chamber will argue about the fact that on both sides of politics we are rapidly moving down the path of the corporatisation and commercialisation process and, ultimately, on to privatisation—for whatever reason.

The reason given by the member for Corinella will be different from mine and different from the reason given by the member for Oxley. The important thing is that these sorts of inquiries are in place and that the evidence contained in these reports be used as reference documents as we go through that process. Regardless of whether it is a Labor government or a coalition government, the process will continue.

The honourable member for Corinella will have a different reason from me, as will the honourable member for Oxley, but the important thing is that we have these sorts of inquiries in place. The evidence contained in these reports will be used as reference documents as we go through that process. Regardless of whether it is a Labor government or a coalition government, the process will continue, as we have seen recently in the budget. I am sure it was a great surprise to a lot of the left-wing members of the Labor Party to hear about the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. But if the process is put in place properly it is certainly nothing to be frightened of—and you would agree with me there, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon.

Some of the elements of this report address those issues. A very fundamental issue, particularly as far as regional Australia is concerned, are the community service obligations. We do not have to have a publicly owned body providing CSOs, provided the portfolio minister can clearly identify the CSOs that the government of the day wants to provide. They should be costed. They should be put on line in the budget and kept separate in the accounting structure as far as the GBEs are concerned or the privatised body is concerned. In that way we can maintain the provision of that CSO to the community. As you and I are well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, given the electorates that we represent, CSOs are very important, particularly as they relate to Australia Post and Telecom.
There were some very important and interesting recommendations in this report with regard to CSOs. Recommendation 11 says:

SPEECH.PARA: In identifying new community service obligations, the Department of Finance, in conjunction with relevant government business enterprises and portfolio departments, should:

PARA.TAB: (a)seek and consider input from relevant community groups and interested parties; and
(b)analyse the proposed new community service obligations in the light of the Government's broad social justice policy objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: That is very important in getting as much input as possible from the community. If in the process of corporatisation and commercialisation a lot of that consultation work was done at length at an early stage, it will certainly eliminate a lot of the disputation later on in the process. We cannot highlight enough the importance of clearly identifying those CSOs. It is going to be a matter of government policy, whoever is the government of the day, as to the extent those CSOs go to. In recommendation 13 it says:
Before the future of the airports currently operated by the Federal Airports Corporation is settled—
and the government has budgeted to sell these about three years in a row—
the Departments of Transport and Finance should:

PARA.TAB: (a)identify and assess any `implicit' community service obligations in the operations of the airports; and
(b)agree on appropriate methods for the future delivery and funding of the community service obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: This is incredibly important to both you and I, Mr Deputy Speaker, in that we have regional airlines operating out of our electorates into KSA in Sydney. Honourable members will recall that the Prices Surveillance Authority had a look at the charging structure of the FAC and said that there should not be cross-subsidisation between the aviation activities and the commercial operations, the shops and the like and the lessees in the building, because they make a big profit there, and they then cross-subsidise the avionics. It means that landing charges, particularly during shoulder periods, are much more affordable to those regional airlines.

PARA.TAB: We got quite a fright at one stage when we were looking at paying a lot more for airline tickets between our areas in regional New South Wales into KSA if we wanted to land in a shoulder period. At the moment, that seems to have slipped off the agenda a little whilst the main game is focusing on the privatisation of the Federal Airports Corporation.

We must be extremely vigilant towards that. Along with my colleague the honourable member for Corinella, the maintenance of those community service obligations is an aspect of this report that is dear to our hearts. They can be provided regardless of whether that entity is a line agency, whether it is a government business enterprise operating in a corporate form or whether it ends up getting privatised. They can still be provided if government identifies what it is that it wants to provide and they provide the funding directly from budget.
The other interesting aspect that the honourable member for Oxley touched on with CSOs is that we have recommended in recommendation 18:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Finance should consider whether to recommend amending the Auditor-General Bill 1994—
which is before the other place at the moment—
to allow the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of the community service obligations of government business enterprises.
That is intended to enable the government to maintain a handle on what is going on there.

PARA.TAB: One of our recommendations in another report was with regard to the Auditor-General having access to performance audits on GBEs. I do not want to labour the point too much, but a very important element of that is that, although the portfolio minister is the shareholder, the taxpayers of Australia own the business. The Auditor-General is our watchdog. This parliament should have a right for our watchdog to be able to report back to us what that GBE is doing. Presently, he cannot do that. As I say, that is the subject of another recommendation in another bill that is being kicked around in the other place.

Finally, during the process of the inquiry some members of the committee had the opportunity to go and have a look at the New Zealand model. Unfortunately, I was not one of them. In New Zealand, with GBEs, the portfolio minister is not the responsible shareholding minister. They have a minister for GBEs or whatever they call them in New Zealand—government trading enterprises or government business enterprises. That was discussed at length. There was not a clear recommendation made in the report in that regard.

I still have a very firm belief that they should be separated. That was evidenced in my mind in the problems that arose last year and at the beginning of this year with the Civil Aviation Authority. I congratulate the government and the minister for making the decision to separate the responsibilities of the CAA between air traffic control and safety regulation. The CAA, in operating as a government business enterprise, was operating directly under the control of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) who, as the portfolio minister, had responsibility for setting policy while also extracting the profit from his GBE. In that regard, there is a conflict of interest. When it comes to the safety of the travelling public of Australia, it is very important that that be identified and highlighted. At the moment, those activities are being separated and, quite frankly, safety regulations should be brought right back under the control of the department.

Let air traffic control be a commercial enterprise and a money making objective for the GBE. The question that will be asked continually is whether it is a good aspect of public policy to maintain a portfolio minister who is setting policy over a GBE and the way they operate, while also being the shareholding minister for the government and wanting to get his dividend out of the GBE. A future government may address that aspect of it.

It is interesting to note the interest that this particular report has created, not just within the Commonwealth of Australia but also overseas. Earlier this year I had the opportunity to participate in a political exchange program to the United Kingdom. The people that we had the opportunity to speak to in this area of government in the United Kingdom were very interested in what we were doing with report 336 and the recommendations contained therein. The British auditor-general visited Australia last year. Unfortunately, I did not get the opportunity to speak with him when he was out here, but I did go and visit his office in the UK. They were very interested in what Australia was doing as far as this sort of financial management is concerned and the path that we are going down. We would all agree that the Thatcherites made a number of mistakes—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—My colleague from the Left agrees. They made a number of mistakes, not about what they significantly privatised but about the pace at which they ran it. They just jumped into government and said, `Right, we're going to privatise all these things. There's no need for these bodies to remain in public ownership.' They were privatised without any regulatory framework being established to control them. Now the British government has not got control of them and it is in all sorts of strife trying to enact legislation to regulate the activities of what are now private enterprises that provide a monopoly service, previously having been a government activity providing a monopoly service.

PARA.TAB: As we pursued this inquiry, the process should be to take it from a line agency to a government business enterprise, give it a corporate structure and have it operating commercially so that it is operating in the same ilk as any other corporation out in the private sector.

At that point, if the government of the day believes that a GBE is not necessarily meant to stay in the public ownership, it could be sold. But before selling it, if it is providing a monopoly service, all the government has to do is identify the CSOs and create the regulations to control what it is doing. It has done it as far as Telstra and Optus are concerned and, heaven forbid, if we end up with another Labor government after the next election, Telstra might be sold next. It would be interesting to see how the Left performs then, because it did not have much to say about the Commonwealth Bank out in the public arena.

I commend the report to the House and I am sure that it will be used as a reference document well into the future. Certainly I am keen to stay as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and I am sure that we will refer to it during future inquiries that we are going to undertake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —What can I say regarding some of the comments of the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile)? There is much that is left unsaid in just a few words in this House against what occurred at many of those committee meetings. We are here today to take note of report 336 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Public business in the public interest. I have already spoken on this matter once in the House and so I will not take too much of the committee's time in making some further comments on this report. I think it is a good report and it forms the basis for the consideration of government action in the years to come. It addresses some of the key issues which relate to the whole question of commercialisation and that movement within government and within the parties on both sides of the House towards changes in the operation of government business enterprises. As a basis for further consideration of change that may occur, it is well worth a good hard look.

PARA.TAB: I would like to concentrate first on the question of community service obligations. There are about 33 recommendations in the report, and around one-third of those recommendations relate to community service obligations and questions of the public interest. What came through clearly in the evidence that the committee took and the submissions that it received is that this is a key issue with respect to the operation of government business enterprises as they move from a more traditional Public Service environment into a more competitive environment, and we need to look at the whole question of what happens to those community service interests and whether they are maintained and how that in fact is addressed.

One concern which came up in some of the evidence we received was that, as some enterprises became more commercially oriented, perhaps the community service obligations were being eroded. That was a real concern to many members of the committee. Also what came through is that there is sometimes confusion about what a community service obligation actually is and how far it should go. Many of these things have, if you like, evolved but have not been clearly defined, and the definition is a key aspect of ensuring that accountability occurs and that relevant comparison and relevant surveillance can occur in the meeting of those obligations.

We have said in the report that there needs to be clarity in the consideration of community service obligations and a situation where they are clearly identified and defined. There needs to be, if not broad agreement on what they are to be, certainly a broad understanding of what they are meant to be. If that is changed, that is an issue of policy. It is an issue that any government should be accountable for and judged on accordingly, but it has to be in circumstances where those things are clear. That is a very important issue in rural Australia, to low income earners and a range of other elements which make up today's Australian society.

I certainly believe that there needs to be that clarity, and we need to have, if you like, watchdogs which go beyond even the Auditor-General in many industries to ensure that those CSOs are monitored properly and accountably. There needs to be a greater support network for community groups in considering the operation of community service obligations. There need to be, where possible, budget outcomes for community service obligations. They need to be clearly costed and well defined, and all of that needs to be part of what is on the public record.

However, in its considerations, the committee found that there are some issues and that there are some occasions on which it may well be difficult to clearly define community service obligations or to cost them and to put them in a budget scenario. Australia Post is the clearest example where that is raised. The question of cross-subsidisation, which occurs with respect to many Australia Post services, may well be an issue which will not lend itself to a clear budget costing, but where the community service obligation remains a key aspect of government policy, and, in many respects, a bipartisan policy position. Any erosion which may occur in areas such as Australia Post has to be watched.

Although the budget outcome approach and the clear costing of CSOs is a desirable outcome on many occasions, on some occasions it may not be applicable and, therefore, there may be other approaches that need to be made.

The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) has already mentioned the question of the separation of regulatory and business functions, and he uses the example of the CAA. That is a very important issue with respect to the operation of services that may have a regulatory role as well as an actual corporate business interest.

The committee found that, most certainly, those regulatory versus business functions should be separated, which follows on from the argument and debate around the question of community service obligations. It is possible, in a situation where the business bottom line is the ultimate goal, that you can have an erosion occurring around not only community service obligations but also regulatory functions. That is a real danger, and it is something that the government should be looking to avoid wherever possible.

The honourable member for Lyne also referred to the question of the Hilmer report, which is the subject of some debate within the committee; a debate which is often between myself and everybody else, I might add. Nonetheless, it is an issue that raises some real concerns with respect to the operation of commercialisation. On the question of the Hilmer report, I do not oppose competition policy as such; my concern is the operation of competition policy with respect to the real world. Getting competition through as a role to improve the operation of business entities is not a bad thing. The danger is that it is used as an excuse for a range of other activities, whether it be privatisation or other issues that have been canvassed over time on the question of the Hilmer report.

The issue which relates to the Hilmer report attracted some comment in the Financial Review of 12 May 1995 in an article to which the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) refers. Quoting from the Financial Review on the question of the report of the committee, the journalist, David Shires, said that the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . squibbed on the hard question of whether government should be running businesses.

I have a fair bit of respect for David Shires in terms of his comment, but, on this occasion and with respect to that particular issue, he is a bit harsh on the committee. We did not squib on the hard question of whether the government should be running businesses; we found that there is not an easy answer to the question. Essentially, doctrinaire approaches with respect to the operation of government in the business environment are not appropriate. There are times and there are circumstances when government should be involved in business, but it should be viewed on a case by case basis.

PARA.TAB: The committee said that it depends on the circumstances and that there is certainly a role for government in business if it is providing a service that the private sector is unwilling or unable to provide and where there may well be a need for a form of competition from government with respect to private sector involvement. The committee also said that, on some occasions, there will be a strategic need for government to remain involved within a particular business environment for the sake of the country. There is a range of examples on that basis, but, essentially, any case should be viewed with respect to those particular points.

The role of government in business is something that can occur on wider occasions, and we should not necessarily be saying, `Let's get out,' wherever there is private sector involvement. I do not think that that is necessarily good for the country.

Many of the other recommendations of the report relate to the question of the operation of and the process around commercialisation. Essentially, what came through from the hearings and from the submissions is that there is a need for development of best practice with respect to the procedure by which organisations proceed with the process of commercialisation. There are some very good examples of how this process has been carried out effectively, and, to some extent, there are some very bad examples. There needs to be a greater hands-on role in terms of developing processes and in terms of producing a handbook on how to achieve this process through the Department of Finance and through the Department of Administrative Services. There are lessons that can and should be learned so as to ensure that the commercialisation of business enterprises is carried out in the most effective and efficient way possible and so that the most desirable end result is achieved.

One aspect that came through from that was the question of a loss of skills. That is a real concern with respect to the movement in this process. Quite often, in the movement to commercialisation, there will be a downsizing of organisations and often a loss of staff. One thing that came through was that often departments and business units lost their best staff through that process. That was very unfortunate in the actual business operation, post-commercialisation, and was also a real concern with respect to expertise within the government and departments, in terms of particular specialised areas. I know from discussions that I had with representatives from the metalworkers union that this was a real concern within the Department of Defence. That skill loss that they believed was occurring, and could show was occurring, was impacting on the results within Defence in terms of their tendering processes and in terms of the need to have expertise within the department to ensure that the results of tenders were the best for the government and the country.

Another issue that the committee addressed was the need to support Australian industry wherever possible and wherever it was sensible. With respect to the operation of commercialised business entities, there was evidence to show that on occasions, when commercialisation had occurred, there became, if you like, a view that buying Australian was not really the way to go. It was not their version of best practice. But often these decisions were taken without considering whether there were good Australian alternatives. This is an overall problem which the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) highlighted in his report on government purchasing. I think it is an important issue. Where possible, Australian industry should be utilised so that we do not have an unnecessary level of imports and so that we can have a situation where Australian government supports Australian industry and helps provide Australian jobs.

I think the report provides a reference point for further activity in this area. It is an area which will continue to be of interest to government because there are still more aspects of government that will move down this track in the years to come. I think it provides a reasonable guide when looking at and considering those issues and in terms of getting the best possible result from these changes that occur.

I would like to thank the staff of the committee. They were tireless in their efforts to assist the committee members, in providing us with good quality information and in assisting in the construction of the report. They also went through the many hours of deliberations over the report in order to finalise what I think is a very important document for public administration in this country. I also thank the committee members from both sides of the House. It was a constructive process. It was a very long one but, as I said, a very effective one in the end. I commend the report to the House. It is a document that can play a good role in the development of policy for government for many years to come.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Asylum Seekers in Australia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, on notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What benefits are provided to asylum seekers in Australia.
(2) How many asylum seekers are in Australia.
(3) What is the average time taken to process an application for refugee status lodged by an asylum seeker.
(4) Will the Government seek compensation for Commonwealth expenditure incurred by asylum seekers from the governments of their countries of origin; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: I am advised that:

(1) Asylum seekers who are in hardship and who have waited for 6 months or more for a Protection Visa decision, may be eligible for assistance under the Asylum Seeker Assistance (ASA) Scheme. Payment under this Scheme follows a stringent needs analysis conducted by the Australian Red Cross, and eligibility for continued payment is reviewed on a regular basis. Maximum benefits under this Scheme average 89% of the Department of Social Security's package of benefits which includes Special Benefit, rental assistance and family payments.

Application assistance is available to asylum seekers in the community in greatest need, and to Protection Visa applicants in detention to assist them in the preparation, lodgement and presentation of their claims for protection.

Interpreting services are available to asylum seekers as they are for other departmental clients. Limited assistance is available to asylum seekers for the treatment of urgent or life threatening medical conditions.
(2) At the end of April 1995, there were 11,135 protection visa cases (15,088 clients) awaiting primary decisions and 5,089 cases for review before the Refugee Review Tribunal.
(3) During 1993/94 new applicants were processed, on average, within four months and people in detention, on average, within ten weeks of lodging an application.
(4) No. There is no international precedent to seek compensation for Government expenditure incurred by asylum seekers from the governments of the country of origin.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Amateur Radio Operator's Licence

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Spectrum Management Agency increased the cost of an amateur radio operator's licence from $36 to approximately $70; if so, why.
(2) How many amateur radio operators' licences are held in Australia.
(3) What was or will be the cost of an amateur radio operator's licence in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95 and (c) 1995-96.
(4) Has the Government decided to repeal a licence fee of $18 for citizen's band radio operators; if so, (a) why and (b) what sum in revenue will be foregone as a result.
(5) What is the cost of administering the amateur radio operators licence system.
(6) How many public servants are employed in administering the system.
(7) Has the Government evaluated the voluntary contribution made by amateur radio operators to the Australian community; if so, what is the monetary value of the contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under the apparatus licence fees structure introduced by the Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) amateur licence fees are $51 as of 3 April 1995. Under the previous fees structure the fee was $37.

The SMA is responsible for managing the radiofrequency spectrum, including setting licence fees for use of the spectrum. The new fee structure has been determined by the SMA following its inquiry into the apparatus licence system.

The inquiry included an extensive process of public consultation. The inquiry concluded that as far as possible the apparatus licence fees structure should be equitable and transparent, with fees properly reflecting the value of spectrum used and SMA costs.

This conclusion is consistent with the recommendations of the October 1991 House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport and Communications Infrastructure (HORSCOTCI) Report on Management of the Radiofrequency Spectrum. HORSCOTCI concluded that the then existing approach to levying charges for access to spectrum had little if any effect in managing demand, did not promote efficient use of the spectrum and was not transparent to users. HORSCOTCI concluded that any changed structure should:
(a) ensure that actual costs incurred by the Spectrum Manager on behalf of individual users are identified and recovered from the individual users;
(b) enable costs not attributable to any specific user to be recovered using a flat charge, or based on some measure of amount or value of spectrum used; and
(c) clearly identify the taxation component
(2) The SMA has advised that there are approximately 18,000 amateur licences on issue in Australia.
(3) As advised by the SMA, the annual cost of an amateur licence for
(b) 1994-95 was $36 for licences issued before December 1994, $37 for licences issued between December 1994 and 2 April 1995 and $51 for licences issued after 2 April 1995;
(4) On 3 October 1994 the SMA introduced the "Citizen Band Radio Stations Class Licence" to replace the existing apparatus licensing arrangements for this service.

A Citizen Band (CB) Class Licence is a standing authority which permits anyone to operate a CB transmitter providing they comply with the operating and technical conditions applicable to the Class Licence.
There are no licence fees applicable to class licences. The fee applying to CB equipment under the previous apparatus licensing arrangements was $18 per set per annum.

(a) A class licence was introduced for CB operators because it is a more effective and efficient way of managing spectrum where a large number of operators share use of a common limited set of frequencies and where all operators are subject to common licence conditions. There is no need for technical conditions to be set for every individual operator and thus no need for individual licensing.
(b) Prior to the introduction of the CB class licence, the SMA has advised that there were approximately 354,124 CB licences on issue attracting licence revenue of about $6,374,000.

The SMA has advised that considerable costs were incurred in the administration of this service through, for example, finding and prosecuting unlicensed operators, aside from the direct costs of processing such a volume of licences. These costs effectively negated the revenue.
(5) The SMA has advised that the cost of licensing amateurs is estimated in excess of $800,000 per annum.

(6) The SMA has advised that as at 8 March 1995 there were 266 public servants in the Customer Services Group and 38 public servants in the Business Directions Group of the Spectrum Management Agency involved to varying degrees in administering the apparatus licensing system including amateur radio licensing.

(7) In determining amateur licence fees by the SMA recognition was given to the voluntary work of the amateurs through the charge of the minimum tax component in the licence fee. Nevertheless, it should be noted that amateur radio operation is a hobby which is pursued for individual interest and pleasure. Safety of life or emergency services provided by amateurs are incidental to the primary use of the equipment for hobby purposes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Excise

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 2 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Government continue the rebate of excise on diesel fuel, including blended fuel, purchased for use in (a) mining operations, (b) primary production, (c) residential premises, (d) hospitals and (e) nursing homes or similar institutions and houses for aged persons; if so, what principles and criteria does the Government follow in determining each case.
(2) Is it a fact that in the extreme temperatures encountered in the Australian snow fields, if fuel is not blended straight distillate waxes and ceases to flow.
(3) Will the Government extend the coverage of the rebate to blended petroleum products used in the Australian snow fields; if not, why not.
(4) What would be the cost to the Commonwealth of extending the coverage of the rebate to equipment used in Australia's ski resorts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The provisions of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme apply to blended fuel containing diesel which is dutiable at the diesel fuel rate when the fuel is used for an eligible purpose under the Scheme.

The Government will continue the rebate of excise on diesel fuel, including blended fuel, purchased for use in (a) mining operations, (b) primary production, (c) hospitals, and (d) nursing homes or similar institutions and houses for aged persons. The Government announced in the 1995/96 Budget that the residential premises category is to be abolished, but with compensation arrangements to be put in place for indigenous communities. It was also announced in the Budget that there are to be changes to the eligibility criteria covering mining operations, and agriculture which falls within the category of primary production.

The Government does not make individual determinations about eligibility for the diesel fuel rebate. The Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme is administered by the Australian Customs Service in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901.
(2) Advice received suggests the answer is yes.
